lead_paragraph: THE southern Italian city of Naples, capital of the Campania region, has a reputation sullied by corruption and crime, both petty and organized. But change is afoot. A new mayor has ushered in initiatives to clean up the city, beginning with the unclogging of streets by disposing of uncollected trash and redirecting chaotic traffic flows. A thriving contemporary art scene — in museums, galleries, and even metro stations — is propelling the city’s cultural revival. Make no mistake: problems persist, but those who remain aware of the vices in this spirited, ancient city will be rewarded by its virtues.

headline: Wall Street’s Elite, Including Ina Drew, Honors JPMorgan’s Former Leader
abstract: A gala held at the Museum of American Finance in Manhattan to honor William B. Harrison Jr., former chairman and chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, attracted a number of old-school Wall Street celebrities.
lead_paragraph: Ina Drew has kept a low profile since she left JPMorgan Chase last year after the bank’s multibillion-dollar trading loss.

headline: Video: Kelly Reilly, ‘Flight’ Newcomer
abstract: Kelly Reilly, a breakout star of “Flight,” says her family in England hasn’t seen the movie and is under the impression that since she doesn’t appear in the trailer, she’s been cut out of the movie.
lead_paragraph: It has been a banner year for some actors, even if they’re not Oscar hopefuls. Kelly Reilly, a British actress, made her first appearance in a movie shot on these shores, and opposite Denzel Washington, no less. Here, Ms. Reilly talks about securing her breakout role in Robert Zemeckis’s “Flight.”

headline: Talkin’ ’bout Stimulus
abstract: My panel at the AEA.
lead_paragraph: Somehow Brad DeLong has managed to produce a pretty good transcript of Sunday’s panel discussion. It’s inaccurate in one respect: I can’t believe that I was actually that grammatical. But I think it give you a very good idea of what I at least said.

headline: Obama Will Take Oath to Sounds of Beyoncé, Kelly Clarkson and James Taylor
abstract: Beyoncé will sing the national anthem, Kelly Clarkson will perform “My Country, ‘Tis of Thee,” and James Taylor will sing “America the Beautiful” when President Obama takes the oath of office at a ceremony on the Capitol steps later this month.
lead_paragraph: It would not be an Obama inaugural without a little celebrity pizazz.

headline: Court Seeks More Public Input on Nuclear Safety
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Indian Point Nuclear Power Plant (NY)', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Suits and Litigation']
abstract: An appeals panel asks the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to explain why it did not seek public comment on fire safety measures involving a reactor.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court has ruled that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission must either allow more public participation in its decisions about fire safety at the Indian Point 3 nuclear reactor or to show why such input is impractical or inappropriate.

headline: Across Borders of Memory and Photography
abstract: Karen Miranda-Rivadeneira plays along the edges of memory and documentary photography, staging scenes from her childhood in Ecuador. She is among several photographers featured in a Brooklyn show.
lead_paragraph: In Guayaquil’s Parque Seminario, iguanas are everywhere. Karen Miranda-Rivadeneira grew up terrified of them.

headline: Feeling Bullied by Parents About Weight
abstract: Overweight children are routinely bullied at school, a study in Pediatrics reports, but many also feel bullied by parents, coaches and other trusted adults who think they are “only trying to help.”
lead_paragraph: Nancy Keefe Rhodes, a therapist and writer in Syracuse, N.Y., has struggled with weight all her life. So when the uncle she idolized asked her, at age 10, if she went to “Omar the tentmaker” for her clothes, she was devastated. “When I begged him to stop, he said he was just trying to help,” she said.

headline: In Your Face(book)
abstract: In the old days, there were parties to which you weren’t invited, and it didn’t matter because you didn’t know about them. And if you did, at least there were no pictures.
lead_paragraph: A friend’s son got married a while back, and because of an unfortunate rift with my friend, I was not invited. I did, however, have the pleasure of looking at the Facebook pictures and seeing how old my friend had become.

headline: Cuomo Looks to Curb Assault Weapons
abstract: The Times’s Clifford J. Levy discusses Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s push for a restrictive ban on assault weapons in New York.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Clifford J. Levy discusses Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s push for a restrictive ban on assault weapons in New York.

headline: Obama’s Pick for Treasury Is Said to Be His Chief of Staff
abstract: President Obama will announce on Thursday that he intends to elevate Jacob J. Lew to be the next secretary of Treasury, officials familiar with the decision said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With his choice of Jacob J. Lew to be the secretary of Treasury, President Obama on Thursday will complete the transformation of his economic team from the big-name economists and financial firefighters hired four years ago to budget negotiators ready for the next fiscal fights in Congress.

headline: Hackers Target American Banks
abstract: The Times's Quentin Hardy discusses a recent computer hacking attack, which American officials have linked to Iran, that targeted banks in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Times's Quentin Hardy discusses a recent computer hacking attack, which American officials have linked to Iran, that targeted banks in the United States.

headline: New Target in Finger-Pointing Over Housing Bubble
abstract: The same critics that assailed the government’s role in the boom and bust in the housing market are attacking the Federal Housing Administration for its lending standards.
lead_paragraph: No matter how many times people debunk the notion that government policy created the housing bubble, it doesn’t die. It’s part of what the blogger Barry Ritholtz has called the “big lie” of the financial crisis. Now, we are having another argument about whether the government is creating a new housing disaster for taxpayers.

headline: James M. Buchanan, Economic Scholar and Nobel Laureate, Dies at 93
abstract: Dr. Buchanan, a professor emeritus at George Mason University and a conservative thinker on taxes and size of government, won the 1986 Nobel in economic sciences.
lead_paragraph: James M. Buchanan, a scholar and author whose analyses of economic and political decision-making won the 1986 Nobel in economic sciences and shaped a generation of conservative thinking about deficits, taxes and the size of government, died on Wednesday in Blacksburg, Va. He was 93.

headline: Have a Good Day
abstract: Three new picture books honor the boundaries of the 24-hour lifetimes of young children.
lead_paragraph: A new year, a new day. For very young children, there really isn’t much difference. Each morning seems to bring a whirlwind of emotion and possibility, hope and disappointment. And it takes a good long while to get to bedtime. Three new picture books honor the boundaries, as so many picture books do, of the 24-hour lifetimes of young children.

headline: G.M. Chief Expects To Regain Market Share
abstract: Daniel Akerson, the chief executive, said a number of new products should help G.M. gain traction this year after it posted its lowest United States market share in decades.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Despite steady profits, last year was a rocky one for General Motors, raising questions about the strength of the company’s comeback from its bankruptcy and government bailout.

headline: PATH Trains to Resume 24-Hour Service
abstract: Starting tonight, the PATH will run in both directions from Newark to 33rd Street via Hoboken from 10 p.m. to 5 a.m. for the first time since Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: Seventy-two days after Hurricane Sandy devastated the PATH system, PATH trains are resuming some round-the-clock service Wednesday night, Governors Chris Christie of New Jersey and Andrew M. Cuomo of New York announced.

headline: C.E.S. 2013: After Delays, Pebble Wristwatch Will Ship Jan. 23
abstract: After several delays and setbacks, the makers of the Pebble wristwatch, a device that can wirelessly link to a smartphone and that raised more than $10 million on Kickstarter, say they are finally ready to start shipping to eager customers.
lead_paragraph: Pebble, the much-hyped wristwatch designed to connect wirelessly to smartphones to display information like text messages, whipped the Web into a frenzy last May when the project raised more than $10 million through Kickstarter, one of the crowdfunding platform’s largest campaigns to date.

headline: Are There Really No Good Job Applicants Out There?
abstract: A third of small businesses say there are few or no qualified applicants for open jobs, even though more than 12 million people are looking for work. What gives?
lead_paragraph: The latest Small Business Optimism Index data from the National Federation of Independent Business — a major industry group for small businesses that surveys a sample of its members each month — is very disappointing. The report, issued Tuesday, showed business optimism to be near recessionary levels in December. Hiring plans in particular weakened substantially.

headline: Cash for Hay Driving Thieves to Move Bundles
abstract: Drought and grass fires have pushed the price of hay to near records, making it an increasingly irresistible target for thieves or desperate peers.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Across the West, ranchers, farmers and county sheriffs are grappling with a new scourge: hay rustling.

headline: Ada Louise Huxtable Leaves Estate to Getty Trust
abstract: Along with the legacy of first-rate criticism she left to the world, the pioneering architectural critic and historian Ada Louise Huxtable, who died at the age of 91 on Monday, has bequeathed her estate to the J. Paul Getty Trust.
lead_paragraph: Along with the legacy of first-rate criticism she left to the world, the pioneering architectural critic and historian Ada Louise Huxtable, who died at the age of 91 on Monday, has bequeathed her estate to the J. Paul Getty Trust in Los Angeles. The bequest followed the trust’s purchase of her archives in December; at the same time, she donated to the trust the archives of her husband, Garth Huxtable, an industrial designer. The archives will be housed at the Getty Research Institute.

headline: For Americans Under 50, Stark Findings on Health
abstract: Younger Americans die earlier and live in poorer health than their counterparts in 16 other developed countries, according to a new analysis of health and longevity in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Younger Americans die earlier and live in poorer health than their counterparts in other developed countries, with far higher rates of death from guns, car accidents and drug addiction, according to a new analysis of health and longevity in the United States.

headline: In India, Solar Ambitions Are Suddenly Outsize
abstract: States propose to add solar installations at such a frenetic pace that doubts have arisen over the projects’ viability.
lead_paragraph: After years of lagging behind China and the West in the adoption of solar power, some states in India are proposing to build solar farms at a galloping pace that leaves them at risk of falling short of electricity (a familiar problem here) or of paying higher prices for it.

headline: Barry Manilow’s Return to Broadway Is Extended
abstract: Producers are promising a nostalgic production full of Mr. Manilow’s greatest hits.
lead_paragraph: Barry Manilow’s return to Broadway for a limited engagement at the St. James Theater has been extended for an additional 10 nights because of a strong demand for tickets, the producers have announced.

headline: Image of the Day: Jan. 9
abstract: A protest in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: Even Fewer Geriatricians in Training
abstract: The number of doctors planning to become geriatricians has fallen again. At this point, it’s likely there will never be enough of them.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of each year, Christopher Langston, program director of the Hartford Foundation, undertakes a discouraging task. He wades through the statistics on graduate medical education, published annually in The Journal of the American Medical Association, and digs out the bad news about geriatrics.

headline: Seems Warm?  Expect a Record High (for the Year So Far)
abstract: A local weather buff has been reviewing past numbers, and he has many observations about 2012.
lead_paragraph: Just think: If the forecast is right, Wednesday will be the warmest day of the year.

keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: After President Obama took office in 2009, Jacob J. Lew became a deputy secretary of state within days. Gene Sperling was serving as an adviser to the Treasury secretary. Austan Goolsbee, a longtime Obama adviser, was serving on Mr. Obama’s Council of Economic Advisers. Alan B. Krueger would become an assistant secretary of the Treasury within a few months.

lead_paragraph: Kingston Digital, a company that makes flash drives, is at the Consumer Electronics Show promoting a new flash drive that can hold a terabyte of data.

abstract: The Sanitation Department’s annual curbside collection, in which Christmas trees are turned into compost, will end on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Here’s an urban version of the tree-falling-in-the-forest question: If you don’t leave your Christmas tree at the curb by Saturday, will it be recycled?

headline: Khuzami, S.E.C. Enforcement Chief Who Reinvigorated Unit, to Step Down
abstract: Robert Khuzami, a former terrorism prosecutor who revamped the Securities and Exchange Commission’s enforcement unit after the financial crisis, is stepping down from the agency, ending a four-tenure that included significant actions against some of Wall Street’s largest firms.
lead_paragraph: After becoming the public face of Wall Street oversight and reining in firms like Goldman Sachs, Robert S. Khuzami is walking away from the spotlight.

headline: Why the Founder of a Start-Up Chose to Give Up Control
abstract: The terms were stark: an investor wanted 75 percent of the company. In return, he offered a $250,000 infusion of capital and the opportunity to earn back 15 percent of the business if certain financial goals were met.
lead_paragraph: Last week, we published a case study about a start-up founded by a young Australian expatriate who faced a difficult choice — just how difficult was revealed by the scores of conflicting reader comments that poured in to this blog. The choice belonged to Jacqui Rosshandler, who was about to run out of money: she could mothball her breath freshener business, Eatwhatever, and find a job, or she could accept the financial lifeline offered by Arthur Shorin, longtime owner of the Topps Company, who had sold his company and was nurturing start-ups.

headline: ‘Cotton Club Parade’ Will March Onto Broadway
abstract: The musical revue is scheduled to open on Broadway in the fall.
lead_paragraph: After two popular engagements at City Center, “Cotton Club Parade” – a musical revue celebrating the Harlem nightclub during the Duke Ellington era – will move to Broadway this fall, its producers announced on Wednesday. With minimal spoken text, this 90-minute show recreates many of the big-band swing and blues numbers of the Cotton Club during the 1920s and ‘30s, with the score including works by Jimmy McHugh and Dorothy Fields (“I Can’t Give You Anything but Love”), Harold Arlen (“Stormy Weather,” “I’ve Got the World on a String”) and Ellington (“Rockin’ in Rhythm,” “Cotton Club Stomp”).

headline: A Family Circle Spins Around the Oval Office
abstract: Billed as a new “Modern Family,” the NBC presidential-family sitcom “1600 Penn” seems more like “Growing Pains,” a time capsule of the Ford, Carter and Reagan eras.
lead_paragraph: There is something funny about “1600 Penn,” but mostly in the sense of odd. It’s an NBC sitcom on Thursday about a fictional first family that the network is promoting as a blend of “Modern Family” and “The West Wing.” Actually “1600 Penn” seems more like a time capsule of the presidencies of Gerald Ford, Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan and period sitcoms like “Growing Pains.”

headline: Far From the Spotlight, Parenthetical History Made
abstract: Benjamin Balleret (ranked No. 636) and Guillaume Couillard (not ranked at all) played the longest tiebreak in men’s singles history in Florida on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: While the elites of tennis gather in Melbourne to compete for a record first-place prize of $2.5 million at the 2013 Australian Open, a different sort of record excess was created on the opposite sides of the globe and the tennis pantheon, at a Futures tournament in Plantation, Fla., with a total prize pool of just $10,000 to be divvied up amongst all competitors.

headline: Below the Line: The Light and Dark of ‘Zero Dark Thirty’
abstract: Greig Fraser, the cinematographer of “Zero Dark Thirty,” discusses shooting the raid sequence for the film.
lead_paragraph: One of the many challenges  of making  “Zero Dark Thirty,” Kathryn Bigelow’s drama about the hunt for Osama bin Laden, involved  how to shoot one of the  climactic scenes: the SEAL team raid on Osama Bin Laden’s compound. The moment would be low in light, yet high in tension, so securing a cinematographer who could effectively shoot in near darkness was essential for Ms. Bigelow. She decided on Greig Fraser, an Australian director of photography who shot two other 2012 releases: “Snow White and the Huntsman” and “Killing Them Softly.” Those films also used darkness and light in interesting ways but were  more stylized in their approach. Mr. Fraser was recently honored by the New York Film Critics Circle  for his work on “Zero Dark Thirty.”

headline: Keeping Score: Pacers Lead Central Despite Offensive Woes
abstract: The Pacers, who will host the Knicks on Thursday night, have kept winning without their leading scorer, Danny Granger, thanks to defense and a favorable schedule.
lead_paragraph: The 2011-12 N.B.A. season was an unqualified success for the Indiana Pacers, who finished with the third best record in the Eastern Conference and put a scare into the Miami Heat before bowing out of the conference semifinals in six games.

lead_paragraph: Between the devil and the deep blue sea. Or a rock and a hard place.

abstract: A box made from gold and quartz was stolen Monday from the Oakland Museum, which also lost items during a November break-in.
lead_paragraph: A box created from gold and quartz at the time of the California Gold Rush was stolen early Monday morning from the Oakland Museum, in the second theft from the museum in two months, according to reports in California newspapers.

headline: Away from Headlines, Boston’s Bradley Makes an Impression
abstract: Avery Bradley of the Celtics was a question mark as a rookie, but his defense has made him a major force.
lead_paragraph: Monday night’s game between the Knicks and the Celtics will be remembered for several reasons: its playoff atmosphere; Paul Pierce’s vintage Knicks-felling performance; and a dispute between Kevin Garnett and Carmelo Anthony that has dominated headlines since Boston’s victory.

headline: If Marlon Wayans Asks You to His House, Think Twice
abstract: In his new horror spoof, a bachelor pad gets crowded.
lead_paragraph: “A Haunted House,” a film that opens Friday and stars Marlon Wayans, is ostensibly a parody of the “Paranormal Activity” franchise, down to the found-footage style and the setting in a generic Western tract house. Mr. Wayans’s character buys a video camera to document his girlfriend’s move into his bachelor pad, only to discover she’s brought a demon with her.

headline: Censored Newspaper Returns to Publication Amid Struggles
abstract: A compromise deal appeared to bring a tentative peace to Southern Weekend’s newsroom, as another Chinese newspaper faced a crisis on Wednesday over the forced publishing of an editorial.
lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China — Propaganda officials in the southern province of Guangdong have agreed to loosen some controls over an embattled newspaper whose struggle against censorship has galvanized free-speech advocates across China, according to journalists at the newspaper. But the paper’s weekly Thursday edition went to press late partly because of internal disputes over content, one senior editor said.

headline: Anti-Semitism Charge Provokes Furor in Germany

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Simon Wiesenthal Center has prompted an outraged debate in Germany after it included a prominent German journalist’s remarks in its annual top 10 list of anti-Semitic and anti-Israel slurs.

Still, officials warn that the danger is not over and that hot conditions have moved further north. On Tuesday, Australia recorded its highest average temperature yet: 104.59 degrees Fahrenheit. headline: Bringing the Calendar Up to Date
abstract: Why are digital calendars still modeled after paper ones when modern design, features and flexibility cry out to be used?
lead_paragraph: You know what’s kind of wild? We can identify products by their container designs. You’d know a ketchup bottle, even if it was empty and unlabeled, no matter what the brand. You’d know a pickle jar, or a milk jug, or a bottle of salad dressing, or a cereal box just by their container shapes.

headline: Boeing Says 787 Is Safe Despite Recent Problems
abstract: After three incidents in three days, the aircraft’s maker says its record is comparable to that of other new planes.
lead_paragraph: Boeing defended the safety of its 787 Dreamliner airplane on Wednesday after three incidents in three days, saying it had “extreme confidence” in the innovative design and technology used in the plane.

headline: Queens Man Dies Just Shy of 111th Birthday
abstract: Carl Berner, who was thought to be New York City’s oldest man, once said of his longevity: “I have no secret. I live a normal life.”
lead_paragraph: Carl Berner, a former toolmaker, toy-maker, factory owner and civic activist who achieved his greatest fame for simply staying alive, died at his home in Middle Village, Queens, on Monday, 20 days shy of his 111th birthday.

headline: A Historic Jazz Label Gets a New Life
abstract: OKeh Records, the label that released historic early recordings by Louis Armstrong, King Oliver and Duke Ellington, is being revived under the corporate umbrella of Sony Masterworks.
lead_paragraph: The major-label landscape hasn’t been hospitable to jazz in recent years, but there’s a bit of good news on the horizon: OKeh Records, the label that released historic early recordings by Louis Armstrong, King Oliver and Duke Ellington, is being revived under the corporate umbrella of Sony Masterworks. The new OKeh roster will feature contemporary artists, including the guitarist Bill Frisell, the saxophonist David Sanborn and the pianist and keyboardist Bob James; its first release will be “A Different Time,” by the pianist John Medeski, on April 9.

headline: Nightmare Week for Dreamliner
abstract: Dreamliners this week have been dogged by glitches.
lead_paragraph: Glitches on Boeing’s Dreamliner airplanes have surfaced every day since Monday, our colleagues in the Business section report. That includes an All Nippon Airways aircraft at Yamaguchi Ube Airport in Japan whose on-board computer on Wednesday erroneously showed problems with its brakes; a plane operated by Japan Airlines at Boston’s Logan Airport that had a fuel leak on Tuesday; another Japan Airlines plane at Logan that had an electrical fire on Monday. None of the problems occurred in-flight and none caused injuries. “While the problems so far do not point to serious design flaws with the airplane,” Jad Mouawad and Bettina Wassener write, “they represent an embarrassment to Boeing’s manufacturing ability.”

headline: Executive Action on Guns
abstract: Most changes will have to come through legislation. But President Obama can do some work on his own.
lead_paragraph: At a White House meeting about gun control this morning, Vice President Joe Biden said his boss was fully prepared to take executive action to reduce gun violence, an important but limited way to bypass the inevitable Congressional roadblocks.

headline: ‘Les Misérables’ Soundtrack Storms to No. 1
abstract: In a slow sales week it edges out “Babel” by Mumford & Sons.
lead_paragraph: The soundtrack to the film “Les Misérables” is No. 1 on the latest Billboard album chart, beating out Mumford & Sons by a hair in the sleepy sales week after Christmas.

abstract: The presence of genetic material from two other cancers in Pap smears, used to detect cervical cancer, suggests it may become possible to look for three diseases with one test.
lead_paragraph: The Pap test, which has prevented countless deaths from cervical cancer, may eventually help to detect cancers of the uterus and ovaries as well, a new study suggests.

lead_paragraph: Beliebers didn’t want to believe. His nearly 33 million Twitter followers were stunned. How could their squeaky-clean idol let them down? Others were less charitable.

abstract: When you are ready to start planning your spring vacation, sites like Kayak and Google’s revamped travel-search tools can help you shop more efficiently.

The experimental Google Flight Explorer page now lets travelers compare potential trips with multiple destinations and varying lengths all at once — and also shows baggage fees and which flights have Wi-Fi service.

headline: It’s Anybody’s Guess Now, So Whom Would You Nominate?
abstract: Predictions by veteran Oscar watchers are all over the map — the perfect time for you to tell us who you’d nominate.
lead_paragraph: With only hours to go until the Academy bigwigs, telecast host Seth MacFarlane and actress Emma Stone announce the nominees, the race is still not settled. Even veteran prognosticators are split on what will make the cut for best picture – “Lincoln”? “Argo”? “Zero Dark Thirty”? “Les Miz”? “Life of Pi” is creeping up in the game too, with its DGA nomination for Ang Lee, and the Bagger keeps hearing raves for “Silver Linings Playbook.” Other indicators, like the cinematography society nominations, are only muddying the field, at least when it comes to handicapping. If you’ve got money in the game on the nominations tomorrow, check some of the round-up sites here and here, and otherwise, prepare to be surprised. Who do you want to see on the list of nominees tomorrow morning?

A sign of how important these showings are, creative directors were in attendance: Peter Copping of Nina Ricci, Clare Waight Keller of Chloé, Alber Elbaz of Lanvin. Store chiefs turned up as well, along with editors and a few celebrities.

abstract: How widespread is sexual harassment and sexual violence among teenagers, and what role does social media play? In this lesson, students take an anonymous survey about their experiences, then discuss several recent articles about sexual harassment and assault.

In this lesson, students take an anonymous survey about their own experiences. headline: Taking in Paris Any Day, Any Century
abstract: “Paris 3D” lets viewers see an interactive, 3-D, “virtual reality” representation of the city through the ages.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In a 1789 painting of the Bastille, the French artist Hubert Robert portrayed that Paris fortress as a huge, seemingly impregnable structure and the Parisian revolutionaries who razed it as small, vulnerable human beings. More than two centuries later, thanks to 3-D modeling software, a different picture of the Bastille emerges. In its recreated setting it is the Bastille that seems small, even vulnerable.

headline: FM Radio on Cellphones, Long Sought by Broadcasters, Comes to Sprint
abstract: Sprint Nextel will make local FM radio signals available on some of its smartphones, the first such deal with a carrier after years of pressure from the major radio broadcasters.
lead_paragraph: For years, the radio industry has watched with worry as consumers snap up all kinds of electronic gadgets — from cellphones to tablets to set-top TV boxes — that deliver seemingly every kind of media but that old standby, terrestrial radio.

headline: Mobile Chargers Ease That Feeling of Powerlessness
abstract: Smartphone and tablet users can choose from an array of mobile chargers for times when a wall socket is unavailable or inconvenient.
lead_paragraph: You undoubtedly know people so smitten with their smartphones and tablets that they experience separation anxiety when asked to put them away, even if it’s just long enough to get through dinner. But that is nothing compared with the angst they feel when their devices’ batteries are getting low. Think tremors and rending of garments.

headline: A.I.G. Rejects Shareholder Suit
abstract: The insurance giant won’t join an opportunistic lawsuit against the very government agencies that saved it.
lead_paragraph: The American International Group has wisely chosen to avoid joining a shareholder lawsuit against government agencies that bailed it out with $182 billion in loans and capital. In an unequivocal statement released Wednesday afternoon, the company said its board would not join a case brought by Starr International, the investment vehicle controlled by A.I.G.’s former top executive Maurice “Hank” Greenberg, in courts in New York and Washington.

headline: No Caution in the Eye of the Storm
abstract: Linda Lavin, the actress and singer, demonstrated passion, vigor and versatility in her show at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: “I’m in love again!” To watch Linda Lavin, wearing a rapturous smile, toss back her head, throw out her arms and shiver with delight while delivering the title phrase from a sexy Cy Coleman-Peggy Lee ballad was to observe a singer deliriously consumed by the lyrics’ celebration of second and third romantic chances. Her performance on Tuesday evening at 54 Below made you ponder what the term “in love” means in the 21st century, when in the 20th it was assumed to be the divine state to which everybody aspired with an implied happy ending.

abstract: Christoph Waltz, Rachel Weisz, Sally Field, Kathryn Bigelow and others share thoughts on a moment in the Academy Awards spotlight.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday morning the Oscar nominees will at last be revealed, giving shape to what has been an unusually multidimensional race. The stars and directors of contenders like “Lincoln,” “Argo,” “Zero Dark Thirty,” “Silver Linings Playbook” and “Django Unchained” have been making the rounds to drum up support. For some of them by Thursday afternoon it will be time to pack up the borrowed finery and the studio-approved talking points, and go home. For others it will be the next leg of the race: a six-week sprint to a finish line that involves potentially hefting a gold statuette on Feb. 24 and delivering an embarrassing (or sweet, or funny, or ideally, all three) acceptance speech. As a primer for those left standing — and entertainment for those following along — here are some memories of Oscar experiences from previous winners and nominees, excerpted from interviews at premieres and galas this season.

headline: Remembering Richard Ben Cramer
abstract: When I first took Richard Ben Cramer out to ask his advice on a book I wanted to write, I forgot my wallet. I couldn’t even buy my own lunch, let alone his.
lead_paragraph: The first time I met Richard Ben Cramer, who died this week at 62, I was seeking his advice about a book I wanted to write, and so I called and invited myself down to Maryland’s Eastern Shore. That’s where Richard lived, about a two-hour drive from Washington, in a couple of weathered farmhouses – one for living with his companion at the time and later his wife, Joan, and one for writing. He said sure, come anytime and we would get lunch, he wasn’t doing much of anything, which of course was never true.

headline: Creature Feature
abstract: The Pig on the Wings stool pays homage to Meret Oppenheim and Pink Floyd.
lead_paragraph: A meeting of a Swiss Surrealist and a British rock band in the imagination of an Italian designer was the genesis for Pig on the Wings. The cloven-hoof stool by Michael Breschi, founder of the Milan-based (and soon to be Miami-based) studio Gentle Giants, pays homage to Meret Oppenheim’s 1939 Traccia table, whose legs terminate in a pair of bird feet. And the name is a slightly scrambled reference to “Pigs on the Wing,” a two-part love song on Pink Floyd’s 1977 “Animals” album. (Mr. Breschi listened to “Animals” a lot while designing the piece.)

lead_paragraph: Quirky, the online developer of household products, has introduced a new way to separate raw eggs. Pluck (about $13) is a silicone bulb with a removable plastic nozzle. Crack an egg into a bowl, position the nozzle over the yolk and give a little squeeze. The yolk slithers up into the bulb, ready to be released with another squeeze.

headline: A Deadpan Gaze at the Down and Out in China
abstract: An unlucky man and his friends live in a kind of down-and-out glamour in “Beijing Flickers,” directed by Zhang Yuan and presented as part of Global Lens 2013.
lead_paragraph: “I regret eating glass,” San Bao, the depressed young hero of Zhang Yuan’s “Beijing Flickers,” says in a voice-over, the bottom half of his face covered in a white bandage. More things he regrets: checking into a hospital, where he can’t pay the bill, and also checking out of the hospital. After all, life in the big city isn’t going so well. His girlfriend has left him (for a richer man), he’s lost his job, and his dog — Lucky, no less — has run away. He can’t even kill himself properly — a suicide attempt on a train track turns into a Buster Keaton gag.

headline: Less Is Not in Store
abstract: “Isn’t It Romantic: Contemporary Design Balancing Between Poetry and Provocation” opens at the Museum of Applied Art in Cologne.
lead_paragraph: Can modernist design be dreamy? A show that runs Tuesday through April 21 at MAKK, the Museum of Applied Art in Cologne, Germany, makes a strong case for the affirmative. “Isn’t It Romantic: Contemporary Design Balancing Between Poetry and Provocation” focuses on what its curator, Tulga Beyerle, considers the softer side of a rigorous aesthetic movement. “Design is escaping from functionalism,” Ms. Beyerle said. “Young designers are critical of industrial production.” Included are projects by newcomers like Julien Carretero from France (his ladder, above right, which is made from oak excavated from a medieval Dutch city wall, will appear in a section devoted to concepts), but also work by established designers who have turned away from modernist strictures. Among the veteran offerings are Maurizio Galante’s Cactus sofa for Cerruti Baleri (above left) and Studio Makkink & Bey’s Birdwatch cabinet (above center). The catalog (about $32) is available at dermuseumsshop.de. Information: 011-49-221-2212-3860.

headline: Drapery Through the Ages

lead_paragraph: “If it had not been for the Parisian designer, we in the West would be hanging rags in our windows,” said the design historian Gail Caskey Winkler, author of “Capricious Fancy: Draping and Curtaining the Historic Interior, 1800-1930” (University of Pennsylvania Press, $85). French design ideas fired up the English and spread from there, leading to tented beds, swagged windows and portieres.

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Wish List
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Minimum Wage', 'Campaign Finance', 'State of the State Message (NYS)', 'Editorials']
abstract: The governor offered many ambitious plans for New York, but he should start with real gun control, a minimum-wage increase and campaign finance reform.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo vowed on Wednesday that New York would soon enact the “toughest gun assault weapon ban in the nation. Period.” New Yorkers should hold him to that promise. He made stronger gun laws an urgent priority in his annual State of the State address, but he will need to present the specifics quickly to a divided Legislature and push lawmakers to act. The supporting documents for his speech suggest that he plans to tighten the ban on large magazines and require all gun owners to reapply for a permit every few years, replacing the lifetime permits allowed in some counties. He also wants mental health professionals to be able to report if someone is dangerous, allowing law enforcement to confiscate the individual’s firearms. And he would make the process of licensing guns more efficient while increasing penalties for use of guns illegally.

headline: A Step Backward in Bank Regulations
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials']
abstract: New watered-down rules suggest banks are again dictating public policy in ways that could risk another crisis.
lead_paragraph: A committee of central bankers and regulators from more than two dozen countries, including the United States, has disappointingly given in to lobbying by big banks and watered down important rules meant to strengthen the global financial system. The change will let banks include risky financial instruments like corporate bonds and mortgage-backed securities as part of their liquid asset reserves, which are meant to cover up to 30 days of cash outflows during crises. And the banks have until 2019, not 2015, to comply fully with the easier standards. Each nation will decide when and how to implement the rules.

headline: Mexico: Killer Dog Case Widens
abstract: A pack of feral dogs may be responsible for the deaths of as many as five people in a Mexico City park, the authorities said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A pack of feral dogs may be responsible for the deaths of as many as five people in a Mexico City park, the authorities said Wednesday. Last week, the police said dogs had killed four people, including a woman and a baby boy, whose mutilated bodies were found in the park in December. Now, prosecutors are investigating if the wounds found on a fifth person, a 15-year-old girl who died in December, are consistent with dog bites. The authorities have captured several dogs, spurring an online campaign to save them, but it is not clear if any are the culprits.

headline: S.E.C. Seeks to Penalize 2 Auditors in Bank Case

lead_paragraph: In its first case against auditors stemming from the financial crisis, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday took action against two KPMG employees who had given a clean audit opinion to a Nebraska-based bank holding company that later failed because of bad loans it had made to real estate developers in Nevada and Florida.

headline: Brazil: Prosecutor to Analyze Testimony by Suspect About Former President
abstract: The businessman convicted in an embezzlement and vote-buying scheme tied Brazil’s former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, received a 40-year sentence in October.
lead_paragraph: The prosecutor general, Roberto Gurgel, said Wednesday that he would analyze testimony in which a businessman convicted in an embezzlement and vote-buying scheme tied Brazil’s former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, to the scandal. The businessman, Marcos Valério de Souza, received a 40-year sentence in October after he was found to have operated much of the scheme, the mensalão, or “big monthly allowance,” named after payments received by legislators. The Supreme Court’s trial of suspects in the scheme resulted in the conviction of senior figures, including Mr. da Silva’s former chief of staff, who was sentenced to nearly 11 years in prison. In testimony, Mr. de Souza said he deposited funds in 2003 for Mr. da Silva’s “personal spending,” in an account controlled by another aide to the former president. After Mr. de Souza’s assertion, Mr. da Silva said he could not “respond to a lie.” Mr. Gurgel said no decision had been made on a formal investigation.

headline: Despite No Direct Tie to Steroids, Piazza Falls Short

Caught in the middle was Mike Piazza, who hit 396 home runs as a catcher, more than any other player at the position, but who was never directly linked to steroids or human growth hormone.

To be honest, you’re not going to be seeing a whole lot of cake and Champagne. Time magazine recognized the occasion with a downbeat cover story. (“They’ve Been Losing Ever Since.”) Gallup polls suggest support for abortion rights is fading, particularly among young Americans, and that more people now regard themselves as “pro-life” than “pro-choice.”

headline: Robert Bork’s Tragedy
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Constitution (US)', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Judge Bork was a tragic figure, not because he was dealt an unjust hand when he was rejected for the Supreme Court — he wasn’t — but because of his inability to understand what had happened.
lead_paragraph: Even before Robert Bork died last month, he had achieved something close to martyrdom. In the quarter-century since the Senate rejected his Supreme Court nomination, successive generations of conservative lawyers and activists have carried the torch, depicting his defeat as an injustice of historic proportion. Following his death at the age of 85, liberals mostly maintained a respectful silence while conservatives dusted off old complaints about the conduct of the confirmation hearing and the unfairness, in their view, of the “borking” the nominee received. Clearly, the Bork Battle survives Bork.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: A Late-Night Ratings Race, and a Controversial Puppeteer Resigns
abstract: Jimmy Kimmel joined the 11:35 p.m. late-night sweepstakes with Jay Leno and David Letterman on Tuesday night, but it was Mr. Leno who won the night’s ratings race; the man behind a Puerto Rican puppet that was the subject of a media firestorm in November has resigned; Lipton is launching a new advertising campaign for the company’s black tea that urges consumers to “Drink positive.”
lead_paragraph: It was Jimmy Kimmel who joined the 11:35 p.m. late-night sweepstakes with Jay Leno and David Letterman on Tuesday, but it was Mr. Leno who won the night’s ratings race. Mr. Leno on NBC pulled in 3.27 million viewers, edging Mr. Kimmel on ABC, who had 3.1 million. The total for Mr. Kimmel was his second highest. It also put him in second place, ahead of David Letterman on CBS, who had 2.88 million viewers. As Bill Carter reports, Mr. Leno was also the winner in the audience of most interest to late-night advertisers — viewers between the ages of 18 and 49. Mr. Leno had 1.084 million viewers in that group to 887,000 for Mr. Kimmel and 683,000 for Mr. Letterman.

headline: A Statement on Steroids, but What Does It Say?
abstract: Hall of Fame voting would be criticized no matter what because baseball never actually dealt with the steroids era.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most remarkable thing about the great Hall of Fame shutout of 2013 is, no matter which way the election voting had gone on Wednesday, the outrage would have sounded remarkably similar. Today’s injustice — that the Hall of Fame path of some of the game’s greatest players, led by Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens, was blocked at least for now in the name of protesting the steroids era — would have been replaced by the injustice of ignoring the steroids era. The Hall’s credibility, now under attack for omitting such obvious superstars, would have been assailed for welcoming players everyone believes cheated the game on a massive scale.

headline: Every ’Wich Way
abstract: The (almost) forgotten art of the sandwich.
lead_paragraph: For something that has almost unlimited potential, the sandwich has become staid and unimaginative. In part this is because we don’t have as many leftovers as we once did (we don’t cook as much), so a meatloaf sandwich is nowhere near as common as it once was. But it’s mostly because we’ve allowed sandwich-making to become something that is either done by someone else or a task to be squeezed in between breakfast and taking the kids to the bus.

headline: The Spectacular Rise and Fall of Fitz John Porter
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Arrogant and incompetent, or a Civil War hero wronged by a petty former commander?
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 10, 1863, a military tribunal of nine Union generals found Maj. Gen. Fitz John Porter guilty of two charges stemming from his actions at the Second Battle of Manassas the previous August. Eleven days later, Porter was dismissed from the Army and “forever disqualified from holding any office or trust or profit under the Government of the United States.” After signing the order cashiering Porter, President Lincoln remarked, “In any other country but this, the man would have been shot.” His uncharacteristically harsh assessment reveals the controversy and political machinations that surrounded Porter’s court martial as well as the lingering drama accompanying the recent removal of his friend and patron, George McClellan, from command of the Union armies.

abstract: In “The World Until Yesterday,” Jared Diamond holds up tribal societies as a mirror for our own lives and asks what we might learn from them.
lead_paragraph: The custom among the Pirahã Indians of Brazil is that women give birth alone. The linguist Steve Sheldon once saw a Pirahã woman giving birth on a beach, while members of her tribe waited nearby. It was a breech birth, however, and the woman started crying in agony. “Help me, please! The baby will not come.” Sheldon went to help her, but the other Pirahã stopped him, saying that she didn’t want his help. The woman kept up her screams. The next morning both mother and baby were found dead.

headline: One Screen, Two Points of View
abstract: At the Museum of Modern Art, the Japanese video artist Meiro Koizumi explores the idea of blindness in the installation “Defect in Vision,” part of the new exhibition “Projects 99.”
lead_paragraph: It would be hard to find another work of contemporary art that protests war with such soulful grace and understated wit as Meiro Koizumi’s “Defect in Vision” (2011), the main attraction of a small show at the Museum of Modern Art. Projected in somewhat different versions on opposite sides of a single screen in lustrous black and white, Mr. Koizumi’s 12-minute video meditates on the doomed, myth-saturated mind of Japan’s warrior class in the last days of World War II.

headline: American Eden, After the Fall
abstract: What about the painters who had turned the American landscape into a national symbol? “The Civil War and American Art” explores how they responded to the bloodshed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “It is a beautiful country. I never had the pleasure of seeing it before.” So said the abolitionist John Brown gazing out over the Shenandoah Valley in Virginia, on a December morning in 1859. Americans have always reacted that way to their native land. It was their great possession. Europe had history stretching back into time. America had earth, here and now all potential, paradisally green.

headline: Portable Navigation Learns Some New Moves at C.E.S.
abstract: One company that is taking a page from built-in car systems to appeal to smartphone-addicted buyers.
lead_paragraph: Portable navigation devices aren’t dead yet — at least not at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. Several makers are promoting their wares this week, including one company that is taking a page from built-in car systems to appeal to smartphone-addicted buyers.

headline: A Google+ Hangout on Modern Slavery
abstract: A Google+ Hangout on modern slavery with Somaly Mam, Rachel Lloyd and Nick Kristof.
lead_paragraph: Today I participated in a Google+ Hangout with two of my heroes, Somaly Mam of the Somaly Mam Foundation, and Rachel Lloyd of GEMS Girls. Both have devoted their life’s work to fighting sex trafficking, and here’s our discussion. Let me know what you think in the comments section.

headline: Chinese Newspaper Protests End, but Battle Over Censorship Is Unresolved
abstract: The publication Southern Weekend appeared on newsstands, but the newspaper remains at the forefront of the dispute over government control.
lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China — The demonstrations have died down, and the reporters and editors are back to work at China’s most prominent weekly newspaper. Its latest issue was published more or less on schedule. But the paper, Southern Weekend, is sure to remain a crucial battleground over Communist Party censorship.

headline: Wet Wrinkled Fingers Evolved for Better Grip
abstract: New research suggests that prunelike wrinkles on fingers and toes may have evolved to give early humans an advantage in wet conditions.
lead_paragraph: The prunelike wrinkles that result from a long, hot bath may have an evolutionary purpose, researchers say.

headline: Richard Nixon’s Legacy
abstract: Wednesday would have been his 100th birthday.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, on the occasion of what would have been Richard Nixon’s 100th birthday, many journalists rehearsed an argument that goes something like this: To one generation of Americans (who grew up, as I did, in the 60s and 70s), Nixon was the personification of political evil. But his achievements, and his liberalism by the standards of today’s Republican Party, may ultimately prove more significant than his failings.

headline: Making Scrimshaw a Sea Companion
abstract: Stuart Frank, a curator at the New Bedford Whaling Museum, has written a book detailing the scrimshaw carvings of sailors on 19th-century whale ships.
lead_paragraph: Sailors on 19th-century whale ships faced oppressive boredom, interrupted by occasional life-threatening storms and hunting expeditions. As a kind of distracting therapy, they carved whale teeth and bones into everything from dominoes to bird cages, pieces that are collectively known as scrimshaw.

headline: Low Lights, Good Drink and Welcoming Soundtracks
abstract: Bar’Lees in Mamaroneck and the Gnarly Vine in New Rochelle are enjoyable entries in the Westchester wine-bar invasion.
lead_paragraph: It seems to have been something of a stealth invasion. The Gnarly Vine in New Rochelle, which opened in 2007, was the first of the wine bars in southern Westchester County, followed by the rather luxe Vintage 1891  in Larchmont, the cozy Crush on the other side of that town, and then, last month, Bar’Lees in Mamaroneck on the increasingly lively Mamaroneck Avenue.

headline: These Law Enforcers Will Stop at Nothing
abstract: “Gangster Squad” is a throwback to another time, with some character voices reminiscent of McGruff and Offissa Pupp thrown in.
lead_paragraph: “Gangster Squad” is less a movie than a costume party run amok. Set in a late-’40s Los Angeles painted in cartoon colors rather than noir shadows, it is a hectic jumble of fedoras and zoot suits, stockings and cigarettes, and red femme-fatale dresses. The accessories of choice are guns of various calibers and styles, deployed to drown out — or perhaps to emphasize — knucklehead dialogue and inept storytelling.

abstract: Pharmacies face shortages of liquid Tamiflu because its supplier cannot keep up with demand, officials say.
lead_paragraph: As influenza cases surge around the country, health officials say they are trying to stem a shortage of treatments for children.

headline: Raised by Political Activists in a Dictatorship’s Shadow
abstract: Benjamín Ávila’s film is a semiautobiographical story about a 12-year-old being raised in the late 1970s in Argentina by activists opposed to the ruling military junta.
lead_paragraph: In “Clandestine Childhood” a 12-year-old Argentine boy is forced into playing a dangerous game of pretend. It’s 1979, three years after a military coup d’état at home and exile in Cuba with his family. Now the boy, Juan (Teo Gutiérrez Moreno), who will go by Ernesto, is returning to Argentina with his parents, Charo (Natalia Oreiro) and Daniel (César Troncoso), and his baby sister, Victoria. “We think,” Charo tells Juan, “it’s the right time to carry on fighting.” In between changing diapers she and Daniel will soon be fighting Argentina’s right-wing military dictatorship in the name of freedom and country — and saluting fallen compañeros with rousing cries of “Perón or death!”

headline: No Exit for Returning Son Who Upsets His Family’s Expectation of Vengeance
abstract: “Sumeida’s Song,” the first opera by the young Arab-American composer Mohammed Fairouz, is a four-character opera based on the play “Song of Death” by the prominent Egyptian writer Tawfiq al-Hakim.
lead_paragraph: It took more than four years for “Sumeida’s Song,” the first opera by the young Arab-American composer Mohammed Fairouz, to have a staged production. He finished the score in 2008, when he was 22, having been possessed by its source, the play “Song of Death” by the prominent Egyptian writer Tawfiq al-Hakim, who died in 1987. On Wednesday night at Here Arts Center “Sumeida’s Song” inaugurated Prototype, a new festival of boundary-blurring musical-theater works produced by Here and Beth Morrison Projects.

abstract: Three of every five cigarettes consumed in New York State were smuggled in from lower-tax states in 2011, according to new estimates.
lead_paragraph: Three of every five cigarettes consumed in New York State were smuggled in from lower-tax states in 2011, according to new estimates from the Mackinac Center for Public Policy, a free-market research organization in Michigan. That is the highest smuggling rate in the country.

This was two months before the couple, professional adventurers, were married at the Explorers Club in New York in December 2010. And the image was not of an embryo but of the R-12, a Navy submarine that had been lost for nearly 70 years.

headline: Man in Plastic Ball Dies on Russian Ski Slope
abstract: Two men plunged off a ski slope while strapped into a zorb, an inflatable ball, earlier this month. The accident has generated concern over unlicensed attractions on Russia’s ski slopes.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — It is called a zorb, an outsize inflatable ball in which people strap themselves, then bounce down a ski slope and, presumably, have a good time doing so. But when a zorb veered off a ski run high in Russia’s Caucasus Mountains earlier this month, there was little anyone could do but watch as the two men inside careened along a jagged ridge and then plunged over a precipice.

headline: As Sea Gulls Hover, Three Old Friends Reunite for a Funeral
abstract: In Tom O’Brien’s “Fairhaven,” three old friends from a Massachusetts fishing village are reunited for a funeral.
lead_paragraph: There isn’t a dishonest moment in “Fairhaven,” Tom O’Brien’s piercing, wistful portrait of three longtime buddies in their mid-30s who reunite around a funeral in a southeastern Massachusetts fishing community. It is the dead of winter, and Peter Simonite’s exquisite cinematography captures the bluish snow light with such acute sensitivity to atmosphere that even in the warmth of a theater you may shiver. A line of sea gulls hovers above a red-gold ribbon of a sunset on the horizon, signaling the distant promise of spring. But for now Fairhaven (a town of about 15,000 near New Bedford) is a place of hibernation.

headline: A ‘Rigoletto’ Reunion Just Might Save the Day
abstract: “Quartet” assembles a posse of lovable geezers in a palatial residence for aged artistes and entangles them in the mildest imaginable comic and dramatic situations.
lead_paragraph: In a charming, only somewhat condescending scene in “Quartet,” Reginald Paget (Tom Courtenay), a retired opera singer, lectures a room full of hip-hop-loving teenagers about the similarities and differences between his favorite music and theirs. Opera, he explains, is about the expression of intense emotion through song. Rap, he surmises, sort of does the same thing. There is more to it than that, of course, but Reginald is distracted before he can finish the lesson. Perhaps he might have pointed out that singing opera (and rapping, for that matter) also demands a great deal of discipline and attention to technique.

lead_paragraph: “Banshee,” the latest action-and-attitude series from Cinemax, comes on strong — almost comically so. In the first few minutes the show’s unnamed hero walks out of prison and down some mood-setting railroad tracks, has sex with a waitress and steals a muscle car. Having checked those items off the hard-boiled mystery man’s to-do list, he branches out, tracking down an Asian hairdresser-drag queen from his past, getting shot at and chased through the streets of Lower Manhattan and narrowly avoiding death by a sliding double-decker bus.

headline: Washington’s Economic Boom, Financed by You
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Government Procurement', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Gentrification', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: Over the last decade, the nation’s capital has been the great American boomtown, courtesy of the U.S. taxpayer. What happens when the government money dries up?
lead_paragraph: One damp morning this winter, Jim Abdo was looking through architectural renderings at his office in Logan Circle, one of the many leafy Washington neighborhoods anchored by a statue of a long-dead guy riding a horse. Abdo got his start as a property developer by buying decrepit buildings and modernizing them, and his headquarters shows off the trick. The adjoining storefronts had been stripped bare and rebuilt, all warm wood and cold glass with exposed brick and beams. It looked like a Brooklyn design studio or a Silicon Valley start-up, or at least how those offices might look in a Nancy Meyers movie. But Abdo has built his business in the unstylish land of think tanks and tepid salmon lunches and boxy women’s suits.

headline: A Judaica Collection Heads to Auction
abstract: A Judaica collection will go to auction; Ballets Russes art is coming to the National Gallery of Art; and James Turrell creates art for Kayne Griffin Corcoran’s new gallery space in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Michael Steinhardt, the New York hedge fund manager, and Judy, his wife, have long supported Jewish causes. They are also known as passionate collectors, particularly of antiquities, though their holdings are far broader than most people realize. For decades the couple have quietly collected Judaica: illuminated manuscripts, elaborate silver vessels, candelabra and menorahs, as well as simple boxes used to collect money for charity.

headline: Citizen Foment That Fed Egypt’s Arab Spring
abstract: “Uprising,” directed by Fredrik Stanton, is a concise account of the revolution in Egypt.
lead_paragraph: It has been almost two years since Egypt’s astonishing revolution began at Tahrir Square in Cairo, the Arab Spring’s biggest moment. As Fredrik Stanton’s documentary “Uprising” makes clear, though, what may have seemed a spontaneous protest by millions against the oppressive 30-year rule of President Hosni Mubarak actually capped years of growing unrest.

abstract: A 16-year-old boy with a shotgun at a Central California high school shot a fellow student on Thursday; he was taken into custody after staff members talked him into putting down the gun.
lead_paragraph: A 16-year-old boy with a shotgun shot a fellow student on Thursday and was taken into custody after staff members talked him into putting down the gun, law enforcement officials said. The teenager walked into a classroom at Taft Union High School just before 9 a.m. and shot a male student in the chest, then fired at another student and missed, said Ray Pruitt, a spokesman for the Kern County Sheriff’s Office. A teacher who began to evacuate students through a rear door in the room and a campus supervisor persuaded the teenager to put down the gun. The victim was in critical condition in a hospital.

headline: Massachusetts: Archdiocese Is Guarding Against Flu
abstract: The Archdiocese of Boston told priests that they could make changes to church services to prevent the spread of flu, one day after Mayor Thomas M. Menino declared a public health emergency.
lead_paragraph: The Archdiocese of Boston told priests on Thursday that they could suspend distributing communion wine from a shared chalice and suggested that they ask parishioners to bow instead of shaking hands to wish one another peace to curb the spread of flu. Auxiliary Bishop Robert P. Deeley also said communion ministers should sanitize their hands before and after giving communion and try not to touch parishioners’ hands or tongues when distributing communion.

headline: Back From the Fiscal Abyss, California Balances Its Budget
abstract: Gov. Jerry Brown declared that “the deficit is gone,” and he projected that his state would post surpluses beginning next year.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — California has been Exhibit A for the fiscal upheaval that has rocked states throughout the recession. Year after year, California officials reported bigger and bigger deficits and sought to respond with spending cuts that left the state reeling.

headline: Fumbler? Hold On, Ravens’ Rice Says

lead_paragraph: If you want to deter crime, it seems that you’d want to lengthen prison sentences so that criminals would face steeper costs for breaking the law. In fact, a mountain of research shows that increases in prison terms have done nothing to deter crime. Criminals, like the rest of us, aren’t much influenced by things they might have to experience far in the future.

lead_paragraph: JUBILAT PROVISIONS is just a few blocks south of Park Slope, in an area that is gentrifying rapidly, but the Polish market’s low-slung stretch of Fifth Avenue cornered by expressways still feels like the Brooklyn noir of Pete Hamill and Tim McLoughlin, a place where, not too long ago, one could stumble upon a body.

abstract: The United States shockingly ranks at or near the bottom compared with other advanced nations.
lead_paragraph: It is no secret that the United States spends a lot more on health care than any other country yet ranks far behind other advanced nations in keeping its citizens healthy. This has been well documented in studies of older people and of newborn infants. It is now shockingly clear that poor health is a much broader and deeper problem than past studies have suggested.

headline: The Longest Nights

At the calendar’s gloaming, while the landscape is inert, and all is dark, sluggish, bleak and cold, writers and cooks and artists and tinkerers of all sorts are at their most productive.

lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — They have been derided and disrespected to such an extent that no one would have blinked if the Houston Texans had pushed back by now, letting fly a venomous tirade of trash talk at the doubters and defending their reputation.

headline: A Celebration That Accentuated an Absence
abstract: President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela, recovering in Cuba from cancer surgery, had no presence on Thursday at an inaugural event tailored for him.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — President Hugo Chávez is famous for speeches that last for hours, and Thursday should have been a special day for the loquacious socialist to let loose. But even with a parade of foreign dignitaries in town to laud him and a large, boisterous crowd on the day he was to be sworn in for a triumphal new term, Mr. Chávez’s silence spoke loudest of all.

headline: Day After Crash, Focus Is on Ferry’s Control System

lead_paragraph: One day after a New Jersey commuter ferry slammed into a Lower Manhattan dock, injuring scores of passengers, the vessel’s captain trained investigators’ attention on problems with the control system, which he said did not respond as he tried to put the boat in reverse near shore.

headline: Shutout in Cooperstown
abstract: In a stunning rejection of the steroid era, no players were elected into the Baseball Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens were not voted into the Baseball Hall of Fame on Wednesday. The rejection was hardly surprising but is still a stunning thing. Two of baseball’s all-time best — Bonds, the home-run king, and Clemens, the pitcher with the most Cy Young awards — were shunned by baseball writers in what Tyler Kepner of The Times called “the most resounding referendum yet on the legacy of steroids in baseball.”

headline: A Boyhood Friendship Fractured by War
abstract: “My Best Enemy,” a World War II drama, follows the closely linked fortunes of two childhood friends: the heir of a Jewish gallery owner and a newly minted Nazi.
lead_paragraph: An awkward blend of anti-Semitic atrocities and identity-swapping absurdity, the World War II drama “My Best Enemy” struggles to find a convincing tone. Sidling around the violence with a plot that juggles class resentment, counterfeit art and a limp love triangle, the film wobbles between high-stakes adventure and high-tone caper.

headline: Heat, Flood or Icy Cold, Extreme Weather Rages Worldwide
abstract: The growing incidence and intensity of extreme weather events is a sign that climate change is not just about rising temperatures.
lead_paragraph: WORCESTER, England — Britons may remember 2012 as the year the weather spun off its rails in a chaotic concoction of drought, deluge and flooding, but the unpredictability of it all turns out to have been all too predictable: Around the world, extreme has become the new commonplace.

headline: F.D.A. Advisory Panel Votes to Approve Diabetes Drug

lead_paragraph: A federal advisory panel voted 10 to 5 on Thursday to approve a diabetes drug that could be the first in a new class of drugs in the United States to treat the disease, although several members raised concerns about potential cardiovascular risks and its use in people whose kidneys are impaired.

headline: ‘Death of a Prisoner’
abstract: Four years after promising to do so, President Obama still has not closed the prison at Guantánamo.
lead_paragraph: When President Obama pledged to close the Guantánamo Bay prison on his first day in office as president in 2009, I believed the country had shifted direction. I was wrong. Four years later, President Obama has not only institutionalized Guantánamo and all the horrors it symbolizes, but he has initiated new extrajudicial programs, like the president’s secret kill list.

headline: Unpacking the Pandora’s Box of Technology
abstract: “Welcome to the Machine” ponders technology’s impact on humans.
lead_paragraph: Melding futurist theorizing and parental musings, Avi Zev Weider’s overambitious, misshapen documentary “Welcome to the Machine” is a strange beast. Experts at describing our collective tomorrow share screen time in the film with the admonitory writings of Theodore Kaczynski, the Unabomber. Mr. Weider, meanwhile, stays up nights worrying aloud about his prematurely born triplets, the products of in vitro fertilization.

Some are less so: the police have gotten angry with Mr. Zemedagegehu because they did not realize that he could not hear their instructions. He was born with no hearing in one ear and only a little in the other.

headline: Pakistan: A New Clash in Kashmir
abstract: In a sudden escalation of longstanding tensions this week, each side has bitterly accused the other of violating the de facto border in Kashmir, which both sides claim in its entirety.
lead_paragraph: The Pakistani Army said Thursday that Indian troops had killed another Pakistani soldier in the latest round of clashes in Kashmir, the disputed Himalayan region. In a sudden escalation of longstanding tensions this week, each side has bitterly accused the other of violating the de facto border in Kashmir, which both sides claim in its entirety. In recent days, India said two of its soldiers had been killed by the Pakistanis, and Pakistan had earlier accused India of killing one of its soldiers. The clashes have occurred amid tentative steps by the two nations to improve relations.

headline: Monks in California Breathe Life Into a Monastery From Spain

lead_paragraph: VINA, Calif. — The rebirth of a medieval Cistercian monastery building here on a patch of rural Northern California land was, of course, improbable. William Randolph Hearst, the newspaper tycoon, brought the dismantled Santa Maria de Óvila monastery from Spain but failed to restore it. The City of San Francisco, after some fitful starts at bringing the monastery back to life, left its stones languishing for decades in Golden Gate Park. The Great Depression, World War II and lethargy got in the way.

headline: Associate of Arms Dealer Arrested
abstract: Richard A. Chichakli, a dual United States and Syrian citizen who has been described as a close associate of a Russian arms trafficker, was arrested on Wednesday in Australia, American authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Richard A. Chichakli, a dual United States and Syrian citizen who has been described as a close associate of the Russian arms trafficker Viktor Bout, was arrested on Wednesday in Australia, American authorities said. He is expected to be extradited to the United States, where he faces charges in Manhattan of conspiring with Mr. Bout to violate international sanctions by attempting to buy two Boeing aircraft from companies based in the United States. Mr. Chichakli, who has previously denied being in business with Mr. Bout, faces a maximum 20-year sentence on each of nine counts if convicted, prosecutors said. Mr. Bout is serving a 25-year sentence for conspiring to sell weapons to people he believed were Colombian terrorists intent on using the arms to kill Americans. Michele M. Leonhart, the administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration, called Mr. Chichakli “a key criminal facilitator in Viktor Bout’s global weapons trafficking regime.”

headline: A Chainsaw-Free Mainstream
abstract: This year’s Oscar nominees, led by Steven Spielberg’s “Lincoln,” are an indication that mainstream movies for grown-ups may not be on the way out.
lead_paragraph: For the past few years, the Oscars have been haunted by the fear that the pictures, to paraphrase Norma Desmond, had gotten small. Or at least that the kind of pictures worthy of Academy Awards no longer operated at a scale demanded by a worldwide broadcast. The box office numbers of best picture nominees seemed to be shrinking as the movie business split in two. At one end was a specialized boutique outfit, at the other a franchise factory geared to the international mass market. Between those poles was a hole where the serious mainstream movies used to be.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Oscar Nods, Music by Beats, and a Space Age Ad Promotion
abstract: The 85th Academy Awards season got underway on Thursday with the annual Oscar nominations; Beats Electronics announced that Ian Rogers of Topspin Media would be the chief executive of its digital service, code-named Daisy; and Axe, the men’s grooming brand, is promoting a new line of products called Apollo by sending 22 consumers into space.
lead_paragraph: The 85th Academy Awards season got under way on Thursday as the heaviest number of Oscar nominations — including nods for best picture — went to “Lincoln,” about a president’s struggle with the Civil War; “Life of Pi,” about a shipwreck survivor and a tiger; “Silver Linings Playbook,” a comedy, of sorts, about a man with bipolar disorder; and “Les Misérables,” filled with songs of the oppressed. Close behind were “Argo,” about political captivity; “Amour,” a French-language film about aging and dying; and “Django Unchained,” a tale of slavery and retribution. “Beasts of the Southern Wild,” which chronicles a child’s encounters with rising floodwaters in the bayou, and “Zero Dark Thirty,” about the murky pursuit of a national enemy, also received best picture nominations. As Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes report, the shocker was a triple snub in the best director category: Kathryn Bigelow (“Zero Dark Thirty”), Ben Affleck (“Argo”) and Quentin Tarantino (“Django Unchained”) were passed over despite widespread expectations that one or all of them would be nominated. Instead, the nominations went to Steven Spielberg (“Lincoln”), Ang Lee (“Life of Pi”), Michael Haneke (“Amour”), David O. Russell (“Silver Linings Playbook”) and Benh Zeitlin (“Beasts of the Southern Wild,” his first film). In all, nine films received best picture nominations in a field that can include as many as 10 or as few as 5, depending on how voters from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences spread their hand.

headline: Girls
abstract: A writer considers the role of the women in her life.
lead_paragraph: This memoir of female friendships inspired a parlor game I suspect many readers will want to play — musing about the friends who shaped our own lives. The first best friend, the one to whom you clung and whispered all your secrets, and then outgrew. The big-sister friend, who married before you, had children before you and showed you her way of navigating those passages. The friend who let you down, who vanished during a crisis, and the one who stayed by your side. The friend you wronged without understanding how. The friend you simply had fun with, and the one you called when you were in despair.
