headline: Taylor Dance Company Offers a Bargain
abstract: The Paul Taylor Dance Company is to announce on Monday that it will commemorate the 25th anniversary of Mr. Taylor’s “Brandenburgs”and “Speaking in Tongues” by selling $5 tickets to the March 6 performance.
lead_paragraph: The Paul Taylor Dance Company is to announce on Monday that it will commemorate the 25th anniversary of Mr. Taylor’s “Brandenburgs” (above) and “Speaking in Tongues” by selling $5 tickets to the March 6 performance of the two dances in four separate pop-up shops across Manhattan. Every seat at the David H. Koch Theater in Lincoln Center will be sold at the discounted price, and tickets will be distributed equally among all pop-up locations. Tickets must be purchased in person, with a limit of two per buyer. More information including participating sites, on-sale times and dates can be obtained by calling (212) 431-5562.

It was right around that time that I heard the owner of the Zinc Bar, Alex Kay, use this-inbox-is-full tones to deliver the following sentence to a line of disappointed faces on West Third Street in Greenwich Village: “You will not get in to see Tigran tonight.”

lead_paragraph: In September, a group of nearly 40 journalists and bloggers, some from well-known news organizations like Forbes, Bloomberg, The Wall Street Journal and Reuters, boarded a bus in downtown Detroit and headed for one of the most run-down neighborhoods in the city. As they peered through the windows at block after block of dilapidated, abandoned homes, a young community organizer spoke eloquently about the area’s revitalization efforts.

headline: Japan Steps Out
abstract: Guess who’s breaking with economic orthodoxy.
lead_paragraph: For three years economic policy throughout the advanced world has been paralyzed, despite high unemployment, by a dismal orthodoxy. Every suggestion of action to create jobs has been shot down with warnings of dire consequences. If we spend more, the Very Serious People say, the bond markets will punish us. If we print more money, inflation will soar. Nothing should be done because nothing can be done, except ever harsher austerity, which will someday, somehow, be rewarded.

headline: What Is a ‘Hacktivist’?
abstract: The death of Aaron Swartz is sure to heat up the ‘lexical warfare’ over the meaning of the word ‘hacktivism.’
lead_paragraph: The untimely death of the young Internet activist Aaron Swartz, apparently by suicide, has prompted an outpouring of reaction in the digital world. Foremost among the debates being reheated — one which had already grown in the wake of larger and more daring data breaches in the past few years — is whether Swartz’s activities as a “hacktivist” were being unfairly defined as malicious or criminal. In particular, critics (as well as Swartz’s family in a formal statement) have focused on the federal government’s indictment of Swartz for downloading millions of documents from the scholarly database JSTOR, an action which JSTOR itself had declined to prosecute.

headline: An Incomplete Fix
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Income Tax', 'ALTERNATIVE MINIMUM TAX', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Editorials']
abstract: The fiscal cliff agreement did not fully reform the alternative minimum tax.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to the fiscal cliff deal, the alternative minimum tax will not ensnare tens of millions of middle-class Americans for whom it was never intended. The deal raised the income thresholds before the A.M.T. kicks in and indexes them for inflation going forward. As a practical matter, this means that 28 million filers who would have had to pay the tax on their 2012 returns have been spared and are much less likely to have to pay the tax in the future.

headline: Steppe by Steppe
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Mines and Mining', 'Nomadic People', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The Gobi Desert is losing its nomads, and a unique lifestyle, to the mining industry.
lead_paragraph: DALANZADGAD, Mongolia — The fire went out at 3 a.m. The cold on the floor of the ger woke me up. It was mid-December and minus-7 degrees Fahrenheit on our scrap of the Gobi Desert. As I lay awake, on the other side of the ger from a family of three, I thought that of all the people in the world, Gobi nomads must be the toughest. Drought and cold and sandstorms and isolation confound the gathering of the materials that perpetuate life, and yet these people survive.

lead_paragraph: I’m fascinated by wearable fitness trackers. By measuring your physical activity, and even comparing your efforts with your friends’, they make you constantly aware of your sad sedentary life, and always remind you to take the stairs or park farther away. The good ones also track your sleep, which is usually a completely invisible, undocumented part of your life. That window onto the invisible one-third of your existence can have a huge effect on your health, productivity and self-awareness.

headline: How To Lose At American Politics
abstract: The platinum coin, the debt ceiling, and how technical victories are swamped by political defeats.
lead_paragraph: No doubt thanks to my timely intervention in the great $1 trillion coin debate, the Treasury Department explicitly rejected the possibility that the White House would mint a platinum “solution” to the debt ceiling debate this weekend. I put the word “solution” in quotation marks because I’m confident that the coin gambit would have solved exactly none of the problems that its supporters claimed it was designed to address. No matter how many clever arguments exist to justify the maneuver, the politics of coin minting would have been just terrible for the White House — and because public opinion would have shaped how both the markets and the other branches of government would have responded to the move, those terrible politics would have ultimately produced exactly the kind of long-run outcomes (from swifter spending cuts to a stronger and more radicalized G.O.P.) that most of the coin-minters wanted to avoid.

headline: At Gucci, Italian With an English Accent
abstract: During a particular spate of Anglophilia, certain image obsessed upper-class Neapolitan gents of the early 20th century sent their tailors to London to learn English style. A fine example was Frida Giannini’s fall 2013 show this afternoon for Gucci.
lead_paragraph: During a particular spate of Anglophilia, certain image-obsessed upper-class Neapolitan gents of the early 20th century sent their tailors to London to learn English style. Having analyzed Englishmen’s tastes for suits with high armholes, a squared-off shoulder, a suppressed waist and armoring woolens, they came home and completely Italianized what they had learned. The results were slouchy and unconstructed renditions of a classic Savile Row suit. By the 1980s, this adaptation came to seem inherently Italian and thus gave the world the career of Giorgio Armani.

headline: ‘Gladiators in Suits': The Fashion of ‘Scandal’
abstract: Lyn Elizabeth Paolo, the costume designer of ABC’s television show starring Kerry Washington, tells T about creating a realistic but stylized version of Washington, D.C.
lead_paragraph: The costume designer Lyn Elizabeth Paolo’s work on ABC’s Washington, D.C., drama “Scandal” has garnered a lot of buzz of late, particularly regarding the way she outfits the show’s lead character Olivia Pope, a high-power “fixer,” or crisis-management professional (played by Kerry Washington). Though viewers may not have guessed, the show is shot entirely in Los Angeles, where Paolo also creates the wardrobe for TNT’s “Southland” and Showtime’s dark comedy “Shameless.” But Paolo has worked in Washington before, editing the looks for “The West Wing,” which, along with extensive research, informs her portrayal of the political characters on “Scandal,” from the president and his cabinet to the politicians whose dilemmas Pope and Associates is charged with resolving. Here, Paolo tells T about creating a realistic but stylized version of the nation’s capital.

headline: Deep Under Antarctica, Looking for Signs of Life
abstract: A $10 million American expedition is close to beginning work to drill through to a subglacial lake in Antarctica, looking for signs of microbial life and insight on glaciers.

But only one of the projects, a $10 million expedition from the United States, has a chance of identifying long-hidden microbes before the weather on the frigid continent puts an end to drilling in about a month.

headline: The Law on Board, and Coyotes on the Runway
abstract: Ken Austin is the founder and chairman of Avión Tequila, a maker of the beverage. He has loved flying since he was a child growing up near Kennedy Airport, and named his company for it.
lead_paragraph: I GREW up near Kennedy Airport, right on the border of Queens. Sometimes the approaching planes were so loud that I thought they were landing in our yard. I used to get a flashlight and go to my bedroom window and turn the thing on and off. I thought I was signaling the pilots. That’s when I fell in love with aviation. I was president of a private jet company. Now, I’m in the tequila business, mostly flying to meet clients, find new clients and check on production. I even named the brand Avión, the Spanish word for plane.

headline: When a Performance Is a Workout, and Vice Versa
abstract: Seth Numrich, who stars as a fighter in “Golden Boy” on Broadway, starts his nights with boxing workouts.
lead_paragraph: Every evening in the alley next to the Belasco Theater on West 44th Street, Seth Numrich, the 25-year-old star of “Golden Boy,” goes through an hourlong boxing workout that would exhaust even Rocky. Often coached by Dion Mucciacito, a friend who also plays a boxer in the show, Mr. Numrich — wearing shorts, boxing boots and a hoodie, his hands taped in Everlast boxing wrap — starts by playing Jay-Z on a speaker and by jumping rope, crossing his arms and hopping on one foot and then the other, the way fighters do.

headline: Treasures at the Met Wafting Through the Air
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum Artists played new and old works — by Boccherini, Kurtag and Dvorak — in a 10th-anniverary concert at the museum.
lead_paragraph: If you are going to play at the Met, the cellist Edward Arron said from the stage before a performance by the Metropolitan Museum Artists in Concert on Friday evening, “you should put true treasures on display.” Mr. Arron and his colleagues have highlighted treasures old and new during his stint as artistic director of the group, now celebrating its 10th season as the museum’s resident ensemble.

The allure of the obscure is what made the Gallery at the MGM Casino a hot $500 ticket on Saturday evening. For a sixth consecutive year, about 500 attendees strolled among the 30 exotic vehicles on display in a private room at the casino as a precursor to the North American International Auto Show.

headline: Reflecting on War and Its Tentacles
abstract: David T. Little’s “Soldier Songs,” at the Schimmel Center for the Arts, depicts a protagonist’s lifetime involvement with military conflict.
lead_paragraph: “Shock and awe” entered the mainstream vocabulary in 2003, when the term denoted the military doctrine of an overwhelming display of force that would be used in the invasion of Iraq. That the designation can have a markedly different meaning to the men and women who serve in the armed forces is a central point of “Soldier Songs,” a musical theater piece by the composer David T. Little. When the work had its New York premiere on Friday night at Pace University’s Schimmel Center for the Arts, shock and awe took on a new meaning: that of staging aesthetic.

headline: Giant Squids Ready for Small-Screen Debut
abstract: An expedition off Japan was able to capture video of giant squids, a first, locating them by dangling glowing lures that mimicked the luminescence of deep-sea jellyfish.
lead_paragraph: For decades, scientists and sea explorers have sought to hunt down and photograph the giant squid — a legendary monster of the deep with eyes the size of soccer balls and long tentacles lined with sucker pads. Dead specimens had been caught in nets or washed up on shore, but they revealed few of the species’ behavioral secrets.

lead_paragraph: Those of us who don’t know the drag-ball world may not be aware that the word “realness” has specific implications: it’s about passing as something you’re not. The point arose at the end of last week, when I attended the opening events of American Realness 2013, the festival of experimental dance and category-defying performance that is now in its fourth annual season.

This year’s lineup included Mucca Pazza, a madcap marching band from Chicago; the Stooges, a New Orleans brass band; La Santa Cecilia, a Mexican-American band from Los Angeles; Martha Redbone, a singer born in Kentucky with American Indian roots; and A Tribe Called Red, an American Indian electronic dance music group from Canada.

headline: Equation of Time Solves Mystery of Gray Mornings
abstract: The Equation of Time accounts for the difference between clock time and solar time, and why after the winter solstice the sunrise keeps getting later even as days start to get longer.
lead_paragraph: As the parent of teenage boys who have to be dragged out of bed on school days, I had been looking forward to earlier sunrises once the winter solstice was past. But early January mornings seemed darker than ever while at the same time, the sky was clearly lighter around 5 p.m.

headline: Wow! (Whatever It Was Jodie Foster Said)
abstract: Twitter lights up over the actress’ rambling, riveting speech at the Golden Globe Awards.
lead_paragraph: THE Golden Globe Awards started out being all about Tina Fey and Amy Poehler — perhaps the best award-show hosts ever — but by evening’s end most of the talk was of Jodie Foster and the rambling, riveting speech (watched by her date, a stone-faced Mel Gibson) in which she seemed to simultaneously come out of the closet and announce her retirement from acting. On Twitter, Ms. Foster’s speech brought praise for its bravery as well as derision for not being brave enough.

headline: An Alarm in the Offing on Climate Change
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Drought', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Weather', 'Wildfires']
abstract: A draft report from a federal committee warns that if humanity fails to get a handle on emissions, climate change is likely to accelerate and threaten human welfare in many ways.
lead_paragraph: The natural conservatism of science has often led climatologists to be cautious in their pronouncements about global warming. More than once they have drawn criticism for burying their fundamental message – that society is running some huge risks — in caveats and cavils.

headline: Gaza: Farmer Killed at Border
abstract: Palestinian medical officials accused Israeli soldiers of killing the farmer, Mustafa Abu Jarad, 21, but a military spokeswoman denied any Israeli involvement.
lead_paragraph: A Palestinian farmer died Monday hours after he was shot in the northern Gaza Strip. Palestinian medical officials accused Israeli soldiers of killing the farmer, Mustafa Abu Jarad, 21, but a military spokeswoman denied any Israeli involvement. Since November, when a cease-fire between Hamas, the militant group that runs Gaza, and Israel was brokered by Egypt, Israeli troops have killed three Palestinians near the restricted border area. Also on Monday, rescue workers recovered the body of a Palestinian who had been trapped in a smuggling tunnel under Gaza’s border with Egypt. The man, Ali al-Qadi, was in the tunnel with two other people on Saturday when it collapsed after a period of heavy rain.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8:30 P.M. (Sundance) CAREER GIRLS (1997) Two former college roommates — Hannah (Katrin Cartlidge) and Annie (Lynda Steadman, above left, with Ms. Cartlidge) — once locked in constant battle try to re-establish their relationship over a weekend in this Mike Leigh drama. Joe Tucker plays Adrian, a smug real estate agent selling a flat who barely remembers the time he once lounged around their druggy lair and broke their hearts. “With his usual deep, engrossing attention to behavioral detail, Mr. Leigh uses ‘Career Girls’ to visit and fuse these contrasting chapters into a continuum of the women’s lives,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “Over the course of their brief reunion, Hannah and Annie reveal the present while they talk about the past, and the film explodes with jittery, hand-held flashbacks to match their buried emotions.” The movie, she added, “doesn’t impose any false closure on its wistful portraits, nor does it contrive more than a few strained coincidences (like Adrian’s reappearance) to create a conventional story.”

If you listened closely, you might have heard President Obama try to do just that in his news conference on Monday, when he suggested that Washington will have tamed the government’s debt problems if the two parties can agree on another $1.5 trillion or so in spending cuts and tax increases.

abstract: Hollywood studios negotiate their way through China’s censorship process, Gigi Pritzker opens her own film production company, and Lance Armstrong confides in Oprah Winfrey.
lead_paragraph: As Hollywood studios look to tap into the fast-growing Chinese film market, they are increasingly having to navigate their way through that country’s sometimes inscrutable censorship process, Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes write in The New York Times. As they do so, they are discovering some details and themes that won’t pass muster, and that other things can be negotiated so that both the filmmakers and the Chinese censorship board are satisfied. Billions of dollars are riding on the outcome, because international box office revenue is such a crucial element in the success or failure of a picture.

headline: Awaiting the Great Confession
abstract: Journalists had their own questions for Lance Armstrong, who taped an interview with Oprah Winfrey that will be broadcast over two nights.
lead_paragraph: You do have to hand it to Lance Armstrong and Oprah Winfrey, two icons — one disgraced, the other faded — who have found a way to milk several days’ worth of attention out of awaiting the Great Confession. The good news is, we have been dripped on by the leak that Armstrong did indeed admit he used performance-enhancing drugs. (In other news: the world is round.) That gives us two more days to figure out where the Oprah Winfrey Network is in our cable lineup before Thursday’s broadcast, which is now being dragged out into a "two-night event," so a few people might remember it exists for another day. The bad news is, the interview has been taped, so all of our great suggestions for what Winfrey should ask Armstrong are going to go for naught. Had she only called first.

headline: Chinese Vase Said to Sell for Less Than Half Its Record-Setting Price
abstract: An 18th-century Chinese vase that sold for a record-setting $83 million at auction in 2010 but never paid for has now been sold for less than half that amount, according to Bloomberg.
lead_paragraph: When an 18th-century Chinese vase made for the Qianlong emperor sold for a record $83 million at a West London auction more than two years ago, it seemed like one of those rag-to-riches stories that was almost too good to be true. The price was more than 50 times the auction estimate and a record for any Asian work of art ever sold at auction. The bid was made by an agent on behalf of the Beijing-based collector Wang Yaohui, according to a Bloomberg report  posted on Monday.

headline: Lens: Ricky Flores’s Portraits of the South Bronx
abstract: A photographer captured images of the South Bronx in the 1980s that belie the grim stereotype of a crime-ridden, burning borough. Read more on the Lens blog.
lead_paragraph: Ricky Flores’s photos of the South Bronx in the 1980s belie the grim stereotype of a crime-ridden, burning borough. The stripped cars, hip-hop culture and the buildings aflame are there, but so is the full range of human experience and emotion. The photographer’s images from that era, along with those of five others, will be displayed in a new exhibition opening this weekend at the Bronx Documentary Center.

headline: Dozens Killed as Explosions Hit Syrian University
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: Each side in Syria’s conflict blamed the other Tuesday after multiple blasts rocked Aleppo University, leaving 82 people dead, according to a Syrian official.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — At least two deadly explosions, possibly caused by airstrikes or bombs, devastated the campus of Aleppo University in Syria on Tuesday as students were taking exams, a major escalation of the violent struggle for control of the country’s largest city. headline: Coming Soon to North America: Penalty Shot Fever

lead_paragraph: What with that soul-smothering N.H.L. lockout lasting so long, it might take a little something to get hockey fans back into the swing, or nudge casual sports fans toward remembering hockey is a sport. (Hint: Played on ice, very entertaining until ambulances are required.) To help, we bring you the best of a wacky penalty shot contest at the K.H.L. All-Star game in Chelyabinsk on Sunday, courtesy of Jori Lehtera, an East team all-star who plays for Sibir Novosibirsk. Lehtera was a 2008 draft pick by the St. Louis Blues, who could use this kind of inventiveness.

headline: The Birds and Birders of Central Park
abstract: A documentary featuring the birds and bird watchers of Central Park makes its theatrical debut this Friday in New York.
lead_paragraph: Like many visitors to Central Park, the author Jonathan Franzen thought for years that only gray pigeons and brown sparrows could be seen in the man-made space at the center of Manhattan. It wasn’t until the day he went deeper into the Ramble with birder friends that he saw feathers with bright yellows, blues and blacks flitting from branch to branch.

headline: Mass Grave Found in Aleppo Amid Fierce Fighting
abstract: Jari Lindholm, a reporter in Syria, describes the scene at a mass grave in Aleppo on Jan.9
lead_paragraph: The bodies lay pell-mell under sticky, red earth at Al Islamiah, a sprawling cemetery in Aleppo. Here and there, a limb or a strip of clothing was visible: the tip of a rubber sandal, a clump of curled-up toes, shoeless feet in blue socks. And then there was the face: a prominent nose, a half-open mouth framed by gray stubble, eyes covered with a blindfold. Whatever had happened to the others, there seemed little doubt as to how this man had met his end.

headline: Warm Millet, Carrot and Kale Salad With Curry-Scented Dressing
abstract: Millet can be tricky to cook, but if you are careful, you will be rewarded with a fluffy and delicious salad.
lead_paragraph: I love millet but it is tricky to cook; it can easily turn to mush. I have found that cooking more than 2/3 cup at a time can be problematic because the millet at the bottom of the pot becomes gummy by the time all of the millet is cooked. But the tiny, nutritious seeds of grain expand so much during cooking that you don’t need more than 2/3 of a cup for this recipe, and if you toast the seeds in a little oil first and take care not to stir the millet once you’ve added the water you will get a fluffy result.

headline: Juniper Jumps Into Software Networks
abstract: The second-biggest computer networking company announced its strategy for software defined networks. The specifics aren’t all there, but Juniper is hoping to become something like an enterprise software company, without disturbing its original business of selling high-margin hardware. The industry is changing quickly, but if it doesn’t change too fast, the plan might work.
lead_paragraph: Juniper Networks is in a tough place. It has long been a distant second to Cisco Systems in the business of computer networking. It now faces the same industry shifts bedeviling Cisco, primarily a change from running networks with high-margin hardware to deploying cheap commodity computers and fancy software.

headline: Skillet Brown Rice, Barley or Triticale Salad With Mushrooms and Endive
abstract: Triticale is a hybrid grain made from wheat and rye, but any hearty grain would work in this salad.
lead_paragraph: Triticale is a hybrid grain made from wheat and rye, which farmers and health food stores alike had high hopes for in the 1970s. It is a good source of phosphorus and a very good source of magnesium, but apparently the yields were disappointing to farmers and it never really caught on among consumers. I had sort of forgotten about it until I came across it again recently at Bob’s Red Mill. I like its chewy texture and earthy flavor, both very similar to farro or wheatberries. Any hearty, toothsome grain works well in this salad, so I’ve given you a choice.

headline: Learn How Calipash Differs From Calipee
abstract: A new book traces the history of words having to do with food and drink.
lead_paragraph: The excuse for buying a dictionary of culinary terms, even if you already have one, is that the vocabulary keeps growing. “Umami,” for example, which “The Diner’s Dictionary: Word Origins of Food & Drink” says was coined in 1908, is still relatively new to the English-speaking world. And “dulce de leche,” the Argentine milk caramel, first appeared in English in 1923 but was not more commonly used until a good 80 years later. These are just two of more than 2,000 words or terms crammed into this compact volume. There are some surprising gaps, like “acai,” the popular Amazonian berry; or “vadouvan,” a kind of curry that’s showing up on menus more often; or “guanciale,” the Italian cured pork cheeks. The perspective is more British than American, but what is offered is useful and fascinating. For example, who knew that there were not one but two terms for turtle meat: calipash and calipee, which refer to different parts of the animal? And that lamb’s wool was a warmed spiced beer with apple that Samuel Pepys mentioned as a nightcap in 1666?

headline: From Japan, a New Approach to Fine Chocolates
abstract: The signature of Royce’ is a small flavored square, vaguely truffle-like and alluringly creamy.
lead_paragraph: Steps from the Belgian chocolate giants Neuhaus and Leonidas on Madison Avenue is a new Japanese rival, Royce’, with a very different approach to chocolate-making. Instead of filled bonbons, its signature is a small flavored square, the Nama, vaguely truffle-like and alluringly creamy. Green tea, bitter dark, mild milk and white are some of the options, all made with fresh cream from farms near the factory in Hokkaido, Japan’s northernmost region. The sliver of a boutique sells less than half of the varieties Royce’ makes, but they include novelties like potato chips covered with fromage blanc, cocoa-dipped marshmallows and flat chocolate squares called Prafeuille with gooey fillings of honey, berries and caramel. Ken Romaniszyn, the company’s American partner and an owner of Lady M Cake Boutique uptown, said Royce’, which was founded in 1983 and has stores all over Asia, is poised to add two more shops in New York in the spring, on 40th Street opposite Bryant Park and on Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village.

headline: Italian Tomatoes Ripe for the Picking
abstract: Mutti Tomato Ketchup is sweet, tart, a bit spicy and more robustly tomatoey than the familiar brand and is made without high-fructose corn syrup.
lead_paragraph: The race to one-up Heinz continues. And the latest contender, from Italy, should at least get a silver medal. Mutti Tomato Ketchup is properly sweet, tart and a trifle spicy, and if anything, more robustly tomatoey than the iconic brand. It’s also made without the high-fructose corn syrup that is in most Heinz ketchup. Mutti, with headquarters in the Parma area, is an Italian giant that makes only canned tomato products. Its line has just been introduced in the United States and includes tins of juicy baby plum tomatoes, cherry tomatoes, tomato purée and rich, crushed tomato pulp — all worth having in the pantry, especially in winter. Tomato vinegar could easily replace commercial balsamic. There are also several sauces. The ingredient lists on these items are mercifully brief.

headline: An Herbed Cheese With Roots in Corsica
abstract: Wheels of sheep’s milk cheese are coated with herbs, including rosemary, lemon thyme, marjoram, elderberries and hop flowers, then aged.
lead_paragraph: Fleur du Maquis, better known as Brin d’Amour, is a popular Corsican sheep milk cheese with great character, thanks to its generous coating of brambly dried herbs, notably rosemary. Now, Murray’s Cheese is taking young, fat wheels of sheep’s milk cheese from Old Chatham Sheepherding in the Hudson Valley and giving them a Corsican accent, with a coating of rosemary, lemon thyme, marjoram, elderberries and hop flowers. The cheeses, called Hudson Flower, then age for about a month in Murray’s caves. The smooth, tangy interior acquires a mellow, satiny rim, which is flattered by the edible, fragrantly piney herb-dusted rind. And just as the Hudson Valley is a gentler place than volcanic Corsica, the herbs are not quite as aggressive as on the original.

headline: My Dark Materials: The Music of Depression
abstract: My music had always been deeply informed by my depression. Listen to what happened when it finally began to lift.
lead_paragraph: “A grief without a pang, void, dark, and drear,” wrote Coleridge in “Dejection: An Ode,” a poem about the paralyzing melancholy he suffered most of his life, which might be diagnosed today as depression. “A stifled, drowsy, unimpassioned grief,/Which finds no natural outlet, no relief,/In word, or sigh, or tear….” The irony of these lines about a poet who is too unhappy to write is, of course, that we find them in a long, sustained poem. A friend shared these lines with me because a similar paradox is at play in many of my compositions, distant as they are from the work of the Romantics.

No, not to drown out the squabbling children or the incessant drone of the several hours of Disney “sitcoms” they subject us to every weekend, but for my blender. I like making smoothies; the blender is old and horribly loud, and after months of blending with my hands over my ears, I indulged myself in $7 worth of noise reduction. They’re red. They even go with my kitchen. Blending is now a joy.

They also hope for bragging rights as the pioneers of a 60-block district that will be transformed by new infrastructure, commercial buildings and public spaces.

It came when he was in college at the University of Florida, playing in Kentucky’s Rupp Arena. During a timeout late in the game, with his Gators handily beating the Wildcats, Noah looked into the crowd, which was a sea of blue, and screamed at the top of his lungs, “It’s quiet in here!”

headline: Obama’s 1-2 Punch?
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Inaugurations']
abstract: Here’s hoping the president goes big in his plans for his second term.
lead_paragraph: If election campaigns are supposed to be an exercise in coming to grips with our biggest problems, then the one we just went through was a dismal failure. Our only real solution — a strategy to reignite consistent growth so we can narrow our income gaps and lift the middle class — never got a serious airing. Instead, each side was focused on how to secure a bigger slice of a shrinking pie for its own base. This lousy campaign produced the worst of all outcomes: President Obama won on a platform that had little to do with our core problems and is only a small part of the solution — raising taxes on the wealthy — so he has little incentive to rethink his strategy. And the Republicans did not lose badly enough — they held the House — to have to fully rethink their strategy. It does not bode well.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Sundance) MONSOON WEDDING (2002) An extended Punjabi family works through its issues as it prepares to celebrate the arranged marriage of a daughter (Vasundhara Das, above left, with Shefali Shetty) — who has been carrying on an affair with a television host — and her betrothed (Parvin Dabas), who lives in Houston, in this film directed by Mira Nair. Naseeruddin Shah plays the father determined to pull off a wedding he cannot afford. Vijay Raaz is the wedding planner, who nervously eats marigolds. “ ‘Wedding’ often has the energy of a Bollywood spectacle, with its ingratiatingly incongruous shuffles of genres; we even get a handful of musical numbers, including a warm, offhanded song on the pleasures of married life performed by a group of women,” Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times. “The agile handling of the soap opera elements — conventional plotting at best — finally makes ‘Wedding’ a pop, facile take on Capulet versus Montague stuff, likable but square.” He added: “Like the monsoon rains that temper Delhi’s summer heat, this movie offers subtle surprises. When ‘Wedding’ captures the small, hilarious skirmishes of a culture at war with itself, and the families trying to hold their ground against change, it is enchanting.”

lead_paragraph: My last three posts have focused on Holly Hunter and her business sale that went bad. I want to thank Ms. Hunter for allowing her story to be told. Although she made some mistakes, she was willing to talk about them in the hope that others might learn from her experience.

headline: Art Basel Enters Hong Kong
abstract: Art Basel, the Switzerland-based grandfather of international art fairs, announces the lineup of its first Asian fair. How will the presence of a big-name European art fair affect the local art scene?
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The dessert served at the Art Basel Hong Kong media luncheon was a large, hollow chocolate globe that self-destructed when hot fudge was poured over it. As expected, in a room filled with art types, everyone had to discuss it instead of just eating it. Did it symbolize the breakdown of global boundaries as Art Basel prepared its first fair in Asia? Or the melting away of a beloved and quirky local event? (Or maybe the Mandarin Oriental’s pastry chefs were just in overdrive).

headline: A Hospital Network With a Vision
abstract: Blending the humanist principles of an Indian mystic and the management style of McDonald’s, Aravind Eye Care System has become a global success.
lead_paragraph: As the United States struggles to find new business models for health care, some innovators are looking to other industries, ones that provide high-quality services for low prices. In a recent article in The New Yorker, for example, Atul Gawande suggests that the Cheesecake Factory restaurant chain — with its size, central control and accountability for the customer experience — could be a model of sorts for health care. That’s not as outlandish as it seems. The world’s largest provider of eye care has found success by directly adapting the management practices of another big-box food brand, one that is not often associated with good health: McDonald’s.

headline: Stone Links: Dating Made Easy (All Too Easy)
abstract: In this week’s links: how online-dating sites tear us apart; what free will does not require; and more.
lead_paragraph: Taking off from Dan Slater’s essay in The Atlantic, the philosopher and Stone contributor Peter Ludlow pinpoints the source of the trouble with online dating. In the language of economics (which is probably apt), the most basic cost, of which the ones Slater identifies are just consequences, is that it creates a near frictionless market where transaction costs are all but eliminated. But it is friction, the complications it introduces, Ludlow thinks, that is exactly what we need in love–even if it’s not what we want.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Gun Data Under Wraps, and Mixing and Matching Disney Characters
abstract: Also, The Atlantic apologizes for an ad on its Web site that looked like a real article, and Facebook makes a stab at the Web search business ruled by its chief rival, Google.
lead_paragraph: New York’s new gun law has a provision that restricts access to data about gun owners in the state, Christine Haughney writes in The Times. That component was included in the legislation in response to the publication of names and addresses of gun permit holders in two suburban New York counties by The Journal News, a newspaper based in White Plains, N.Y. The decision to print that information with an accompanying map outraged gun owners across the nation and prompted a backlash against the paper’s employees. Now some journalists are lamenting the loss of data previously available as a reporting tool.

Now, the company is betting it has enough data so that people can find whatever they want on Facebook. And on Tuesday, it unveiled an ambitious new tool to help them dig for it.

headline: Sexual Myopia
abstract: If we’re the same age, why do you look so old?
lead_paragraph: Every once in a while a male friend in his 60s tells me that try as he might, he just cannot get turned on by women his own age and naturally I channel Cher in “Moonstruck” and let him have it: Snap out of it, I say! Look in the mirror! We all age! What’s more important to you, a woman 30 years younger whom you can show off on the beach or someone who doesn’t draw a blank when you talk about Bullwinkle and Boris Badenov? Not that I have that many conversations in which I need to reference Bullwinkle and Boris Badenov, but when I do I don’t want to have to get bogged down in the whole back story. This is why I know this whole cougar thing is a myth. I do not know any women in their 60s who want a 30-year-old boyfriend because what would they talk about?

headline: Lumière | The French Fifty Shades
abstract: The French version of the “Fifty Shades of Grey” trilogy should have flopped. But it hasn’t. Why?
lead_paragraph: When it comes to erotica and pornography, whether hard, soft, sadomasochistic or merely steamy, the French believe they have done it first, done it better and done it all. So the French version of the “Fifty Shades of Grey” trilogy should have flopped.

headline: Trinkets and Doodads for Those Who Are Just Looking
abstract: The leader in handing out nifty stuff at the Detroit auto show is usually Scion, which in the past has offered hats, sunglasses and key chains. This year it had cloth sleeves for your gadgets and a Scion-branded baseball cap.
lead_paragraph: Seeing all the new cars may be the reason automotive journalists from all over the world gather at the Detroit auto show during press days at the Cobo Center, but part of the fun is also seeing what tchotchkes the automakers hand out on the show floor. The new Corvette Stingray is important and all, but wasn’t that a really cool paperweight Chevy handed out along with the press materials about the car? They went fast.

headline: Channeling Armstrong
abstract: Sportswriters ponder the possibilities of Lance Armstrong’s confessional interview with Oprah Winfrey.
lead_paragraph: O.K., so you find yourself with another day to kill while frantically searching your on-screen cable TV guide looking for the Oprah Winfrey Network — Honey, you sure it isn’t the Alerta TV network? I found that in the 400s. Halogen TV, maybe? — and you’ve decided to wonder whether you will be sick of Lance Armstrong’s big staged confession before it even starts. This is a distinct possibility. After all, Winfrey has already done interviews about the interview (sigh), let people know Armstrong will not come off as contrite (eye roll) and will quite likely try to paint cycling’s leadership as the truly bad guys (stomach churn). Winfrey’s network helped exactly nothing by deciding to drag the thing over two nights, so you can be doubly preannoyed at the whole sideshow.

The big bus had dropped off part of its cargo earlier, at another school, but in all, 10 children had ridden on a bus fit for about 60.

In a “highly preliminary, wildly speculative thematic guide” — as they put it — they argue that it’s possible to view recent American films as reflections of different aspects of the nation and especially its leader since 2008.

headline: Movies in the Age of Obama
abstract: It may be too soon to identify an Obama Cinema, but the president’s second inauguration seems an appropriate time to try.
lead_paragraph: FOUR years ago, on the historic occasion of Barack Obama’s first inauguration, we took a look at the good, bad and outrageous movie characters who helped make his election possible. The road to the White House, we wrote, hadn’t just been paved by Mr. Obama’s speeches, innovative campaign strategies and the hopefulness of a majority of voters, but also by decades of African-American men in movies. From the class striving of Sidney Poitier’s everyman in the classic film “A Raisin in the Sun” to Will Smith’s messianic loners in recent titles like “I Am Legend,” the movies have ennobled, consecrated, glorified, immortalized and, most important, normalized the figure of the black man.

headline: Social Search and the Difficulties of Discovery
abstract: Facebook is the latest technology company to offer a social search engine. In this new era of search, robots take over discovery, threatening to narrow our worlds.
lead_paragraph: In literature and philosophy, in both West and East, the notion of search refers to expansive, ambitious human pursuits. We have, alternately, searched for the Promised Land and the holy grail. Astronomers have searched for life in outer space. The Buddha searched for truth.

headline: Obama Unveils Plan for Gun Laws
abstract: President Obama outlined his proposals to reduce gun violence in the United States, urging Congress to approve expanded background checks, a ban on assault weapons and other restrictions.
lead_paragraph: President Obama outlined his proposals to reduce gun violence in the United States, urging Congress to approve expanded background checks, a ban on assault weapons and other restrictions.

headline: Has Snowboarding Lost Its Edge?
abstract: Once the hottest thing on the slopes, snowboarding is showing signs of cooling. Here’s why.
lead_paragraph: LATE last summer when Shaun White, the two-time Olympic gold medal snowboarder and X-Games superstar, was charged with public intoxication and vandalism, he became at age 26 an accidental metaphor for his sport: a young phenom all grown up, and in a spot of trouble.

headline: Only for Those Who Aren’t Photosensitive
abstract: If the four North American premieres that made up this year’s Contemporary Dance Showcase at Japan Society had anything in common, it was highly active lighting design.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend Japan Society presented its 15th annual contemporary dance showcase and once again opened a window onto the East Asian scene. The series’s artistic director, Yoko Shioya, remarked that the Internet has made that scene more easily accessible. She also said that her focus has shifted from new companies to new works, since so many dancers and choreographers are now freelancers and eager to collaborate with artists outside dance. Sounds like New York.

headline: Pushing France Onto the Digital Stage
abstract: In trying to put a French imprint on the digital economy, Fleur Pellerin has found herself clashing with American technology companies.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When the most prominent new face in France’s effort to oversee the new economy speaks, her pronouncements may be followed almost as closely in Silicon Valley and Seoul as in Paris.

headline: Forecast: More Sunshine at Sundance (at Least on Screen)
abstract: This year’s Sundance Film Festival has more comedies and an overall lighter tone than in years past.
lead_paragraph: The Sundance Film Festival has long had a dual personality. The atmosphere is typically fun and fizzy — Stars! Swag! Hot tub hopping! — while the films are dark and depressing, sometimes to the point of self-parody.

headline: Milan Top 5
abstract: Call it the “Downton Abbey” effect: an unmistakably English vibe was evident at the men’s collections in Milan.

headline: Below the Line: Designing ‘Moonrise Kingdom’
abstract: Adam Stockhausen, the production designer for “Moonrise Kingdom,” discusses his work.
lead_paragraph: While “Moonrise Kingdom,” Wes Anderson’s whimsical feature about young romantics in a small island community, didn’t make the cut for best picture at last week’s Oscar nominations, it did receive a nod for its screenplay and was recognized by the Producers Guild of America, while also making several critics’ top 10 lists.

headline: Introducing Building the Team: Flower Power
abstract: I wanted the chance to build something great, something with a product that people loved and that had a chance to be a really big business. But I’m not Mark Zuckerberg.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, I knew nothing about flowers.

headline: Rossignol Rentals Introduce Its Technology
abstract: Rental staff members and ski instructors offer quick tips on how to get the best performance from easy-to-turn skis.
lead_paragraph: Memories of ill-performing rental gear — skis with the turning ability of a two-by-four, boots that pinch — are a big deterrent to occasional skiers, especially those who haven’t visited the slopes recently enough to realize that today’s equipment has vastly improved, making it easier to become a better skier.

headline: Knicks Practice in London With Anthony Backing Dolan
abstract: Forward Carmelo Anthony said Wednesday that he appreciated James L. Dolan’s efforts to record trash-talking at Madison Square Garden as a way to protect him.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After a trans-Atlantic flight, the Knicks returned to work Wednesday, adjusting to their temporary surroundings with a practice session at O2 Arena and a clinic for children who might have been only vaguely familiar with N.B.A. players.

headline: The Latest in Anti-Politics
abstract: Brooks and Collins wonder what good can come out this week’s House Republican retreat.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: David, the House Republicans are going off for their annual retreat this week. As a sign of my good intentions, I am not going to make any jokes involving Custer and Little Bighorn.

headline: What Is Driving Growth in Government Spending?
abstract: A closer look at social insurance and entitlement programs reveals some surprises about where government spending is — and isn’t — increasing.
lead_paragraph: It’s one of the most fundamental political questions of our time: What’s driving the growth in government spending? And it has a relatively straightforward answer: first and foremost, spending on health care through Medicare and Medicaid, and other major social insurance and entitlement programs.

headline: Have an N.B.A. Question? Howard Beck Has Answers
abstract: Howard Beck, the N.B.A. reporter for The Times, will answer questions from readers.
lead_paragraph: 3:56 p.m. | Updated What has happened to the Mavericks? Are the Nets good enough to go beyond the first round of the playoffs? Can the Lakers be repaired? Howard Beck, the N.B.A. reporter for The Times, will answer questions from readers about the season. Use the comment field below for your questions. Answers will appear next week on Off the Dribble.

headline: Still Flying Beyond Gravity’s Pull
abstract: Idina Menzel performed at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, accompanied by the Orchestra of St. Lukes under the direction of Rod Mounsey.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a decade has passed since Idina Menzel introduced her signature song, the Stephen Schwartz anthem “Defying Gravity” in the 2003 Broadway smash “Wicked.”

headline: Study Discovers DNA That Tells Mice How to Construct Their Homes
abstract: Scientists have identified four regions of DNA that play a major role in controlling animal behavior: telling a mouse how long a burrow to dig and whether to add an escape tunnel.
lead_paragraph: The architectural feats of animals — from beaver dams to birds’ nests — not only make for great nature television, but, since the plans for such constructions seem largely inherited, they also offer an opportunity for scientists to tackle the profoundly difficult question of how genes control complicated behavior in animals and humans.

headline: Sandy and the Hastert Rule
abstract: John Boehner let the federal aid package pass without majority support from the Republican caucus.
lead_paragraph: A quick look at the House vote on $50.7 billion in federal aid to repair the damage from Hurricane Sandy suggests that it passed pretty easily on Tuesday night, 241 to 180. The real news is in how the two parties split: Republicans voted overwhelmingly against it, while all but one Democrat supported it.

headline: Will Gridlock Last?
abstract: Why the current balance of power in Washington might be upset in the next few election cycles.
lead_paragraph: Lately I’ve been arguing that both political parties should probably lower their expectations for what they’re likely to achieve in a divided Washington D.C. This would mean focusing on consolidation (for liberals) and rebuilding (for conservatives), making small-ball deals instead of seeking grand bargains and comprehensive reforms, giving up on the idea that some brilliant legislative gambit will suddenly “break” the House Republicans or “force” the White House to accede to G.O.P. demands, and accepting that the next wave of significant legislating will probably have to await a shift in the balance of power come 2014 or 2016.

headline: Reversing Course, Kelly Leaves Oregon to Become Coach of the Eagles
abstract: After initially saying no, Chip Kelly, who has no pro football experience as a player or an assistant coach, changed his mind and became the new coach of the Eagles.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday evening, the Philadelphia Eagles sent out a curious statement. They explained that they had no regrets about how much time they had spent interviewing the best college coaches for their vacant head coaching spot, despite knowing there was only a remote chance one of them would leave for the N.F.L. The statement was an indication the Eagles were moving on, having failed to land their top choice.

headline: Comparing Wall St. Bonuses? There’s an App for That
abstract: An iPhone app, “Banker’s Bonus 2013,” allows a banker (or really anyone) to enter a bonus amount and see how it ranks among others around the world.
lead_paragraph: It’s a ritual as old as Wall Street. Come bonus time, employees furtively compare their pay to see how they measure up.

headline: Oxygen Drops Plans for ‘All My Babies’ Mamas’
abstract: The cable channel scrapped the show, which was in development, after the promotion of an online petition that condemned Oxygen, accusing it of exploiting and stereotyping black children and families.
lead_paragraph: The cable channel Oxygen has scrapped a show in development called “All My Babies’ Mamas” after the promotion of an online petition that condemned the channel, accusing it of exploiting and stereotyping black children and families.

headline: Incoming Members of Congress Not Exactly Average Joes
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An analysis of the incoming freshman class of the 113th Congress belies the Little Guy image. The 94 new lawmakers boast a median net worth of $1,066,515 — almost exactly $1 million more than the wealth of a typical American household.
lead_paragraph: With the rise of the Tea Party movement, the image of Average Joe Citizen taking over Congress has captured the media’s imagination, from rural northern Florida, which sent a large-animal veterinarian, Ted Yoho, to the House, to eastern Michigan, which elected a reindeer farmer and Santa Claus impersonator, Kerry Bentivolio.

headline: Inaugural Committee Previews Weekend’s Festivities
abstract: The Presidential Inaugural Committee held a news conference at the National Press Club Wednesday to preview this weekend’s festivities.
lead_paragraph: “I love the idea of any show that begins with Chuck Schumer and ends with Beyoncé.” — Brent Colburn, communications director for President Obama’s inaugural committee, describing Monday’s swearing in ceremony on the west front of the Capitol. Senator Charles E. Schumer, the New York Democrat, will make remarks opening the ceremony and Beyoncé will sing the national anthem at the end.

headline: Houston Symphony Chooses New Maestro
abstract: The Colombian-born Andrés Orozco-Estrada, 35, will become music director of the Houston Symphony in 2014.
lead_paragraph: The Houston Symphony on Wednesday named the Colombian-born Andrés Orozco-Estrada as its next music director. Mr. Orozco-Estrada, 35, will begin conducting the orchestra regularly next season and take over officially with a five-year contract in the 2014-15 season.

headline: A Breath of Florida, Alligators Included
abstract: Parsons Dance presented works by David Parsons, the company’s artistic director, and Katarzyna Skarpetowska at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: Parsons Dance returned to the Joyce Theater on Tuesday with works by the choreographer David Parsons, including his new “Dawn to Dusk,” as well as a commission by a former company member, Katarzyna Skarpetowska. Each serve watered-down versions of dances by master choreographers: Mr. Parsons, as usual, draws from Paul Taylor, with whom he danced. Ms. Skarpetowska, at least in her new “Black Flowers,” channels Martha Graham.

headline: Anti-Auto Show Focusing on Alternative Transportation
abstract: “It’s not necessarily about one person and four wheels being bad,” said the show’s curator, Christina de Roos of Spread Art. “It’s about the environmental consequences of the automobile and the things that come from a heavy car culture.”
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The North American International Anti-Auto Show, an art exhibition timed around the show at the Cobo Center, opens Friday night with a black-tie preview at the Contemporary Art Institute of Detroit. Admission is $1 to the green carpet event, where anti-auto show girls will unveil some of the artwork from 14 artists highlighting alternative transportation-based themes.

headline: Family Art
abstract: Dieter Roth’s works live on as a family business.
lead_paragraph: Dieter Roth’s works live on as a family business.

headline: Into Antarctica’s Dark Depths
abstract: Lake Untersee is one of the most remote and isolated dive sites in the world. And polar researchers can’t wait to drop into its miles of darkness.
lead_paragraph: Michael Becker, a doctoral student at McGill University, was a scientific diver on an expedition to Lake Untersee, Antarctica.

headline: Could Responsibilities Help Prevent Teenage Suicide?
abstract: A friend’s suicide made me look more closely at what drives, and prevents, suicide in teenagers — like mine.
lead_paragraph: One recent Saturday, a friend of mine drove across town to a gun store. She bought a pistol, went back to her car in the parking lot, and ended her life.

headline: Gun Reform for a Generation
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Series']
abstract: After years of sorrowful declarations and inaction from American presidents, President Obama steps up.
lead_paragraph: We usually cringe when politicians drag ordinary people onstage for their events. But the four children who appeared with their parents and President Obama in the White House on Wednesday at his announcement on gun control proposals drove home the nature of the crisis facing the country. While guns and gun control have been a subject of debate among politicians and lawyers and lobbyists and pollsters and political groups in the center and on the fringes, our children have been living in a free-fire zone for sociopaths with virtually unfettered access to instruments of mass murder.

headline: Producer Says James Brown Biopic Is Finally a Go
abstract: The producers says he’s gotten the rights from the singer’s estate to proceed.
lead_paragraph: The movie producer Brian Grazer says that  he has obtained the rights to James Brown’s music from the singer’s estate and that he is moving ahead with a long-delayed film about Mr. Brown’s life. In an interview with Rolling Stone, Mr. Grazer said that he had brought in Mick Jagger as a producer and that they intended to begin casting the movie soon, using a revised version of a script Mr. Grazer commissioned years ago from the British screenwriters Jez and John-Henry Butterworth.

headline: Owning a Home, Mortgage Free
abstract: Nearly a third of homeowners do not have a mortgage, an analysis by Zillow finds.
lead_paragraph: With all the painful foreclosures during the recent economic downturn, it’s easy to forget that some homeowners don’t even have mortgages. Nearly a third of homeowners — 29.3 percent of them — do not, according to a recent analysis by the real estate site Zillow.

headline: Europe Weighs Requiring Firms to Disclose Data Breaches
abstract: To combat a rise in cybercrime, the European Commission is considering a plan to require some of the biggest Web businesses to report the loss or theft of personal data, or risk sanctions and fines.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — To combat a rise in cybercrime, the European Commission is considering a plan to require companies that store data on the Internet — like Microsoft, Apple, Google and I.B.M. — to report the loss or theft of personal information in the 27-nation bloc or risk sanctions and fines.

headline: An Actor’s Evolution, by Way of Some Famous Scenes
abstract: James DeVita charts his career during “In Acting Shakespeare” at the Pearl Theater, a play adapted from Ian McKellen’s “Acting Shakespeare.”
lead_paragraph: Right from the start of his career James DeVita could perform Shakespeare with his hands tied behind his back.

headline: Seven Features Announced for New Directors/New Films Series
abstract: “Stories We Tell,” Sarah Polley’s documentary exploration of her own family, and “Upstream Color,” Shane Carruth’s follow-up to “Primer,” are among the seven films announced for the program presented by the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Polley’s documentary exploration into her own family and Shane Carruth’s followup to his 2004 debut, “Primer,” are among the features that will be presented at this year’s New Directors/New Films series, the annual program presented by the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center, the organizations said on Wednesday.

headline: Students’ Letters to Obama
abstract: Read three student letters, released by the White House to The Associated Press, asking President Obama to change gun laws.
lead_paragraph: Read three student letters, released by the White House to The Associated Press, asking President Obama to change gun laws.

headline: Spicing Up a Ho-Hum Tech Show
abstract: This year’s Consumer Electronics Show didn’t have a lot to write home about, but there was some action courtesy of Daxton Blackthorne.
lead_paragraph: Hi boss! I’m back from the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. You assigned me to report on what’s new and exciting, but I have some bad news. The answer is: almost nothing.

headline: Winehouse Foundation Gift to Help Brooklyn Conservatory Students
abstract: The $25,000 being donated will go to defray the expenses of needy children accepted into the academy’s Teen Jazz Program.
lead_paragraph: The Amy Winehouse Foundation has awarded $25,000 to the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music to finance scholarships for teenage jazz musicians. The parents of Amy Winehouse, Janis and Mitch Winehouse, attended a short ceremony at the nonprofit conservatory in Park Slope on Wednesday morning to hand over a giant facsimile of a check to Karen Geer, the executive director.

headline: Growing Up With Hinsch’s
abstract: Recalling lunches in vinyl booths served by waitresses sporting beehive hairdos at a mainstay of Bay Ridge’s 86th Street.
lead_paragraph: One of the last vestiges of my childhood in Brooklyn will be gone when Hinsch’s, the luncheonette-cum-ice cream parlor in Bay Ridge, closes down as planned in March.

headline: Germany to Move 674 Tons of Gold
abstract: Two-thirds of Germany’s gold reserves is stored in Paris, London and New York. The German central bank, responding to a public outcry over accountability, is going to repatriate some of the gold.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Nearly half of Germany’s gold reserves are held in a vault at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York — billions of dollars worth of postwar geopolitical history squirreled away for safe keeping below the streets of Lower Manhattan.

headline: What’s in Obama’s Gun Control Proposal
abstract: The initiative to reduce gun violence announced by President Obama includes both legislative proposals that would need to be acted on by Congress and executive actions he can do on his own.
lead_paragraph: The initiative to reduce gun violence announced by President Obama includes both legislative proposals that would need to be acted on by Congress and executive actions he can do on his own.

headline: If You Like the Moody Blues, Try Alt-J
abstract: The Moody Blues were an experimental band from Britain that didn’t neatly fit one genre. The same can be said for Alt-J.
lead_paragraph: Each week, Val Haller, the founder of the music Web site Valslist.com, matches music from her baby boom generation to that of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Lance Armstrong Opens Up to Oprah
abstract: On the eve of Lance Armstrong's interview with Oprah Winfrey, The Times's Brian Stelter talks about the fallen athlete as he faces the media.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of Lance Armstrong's interview with Oprah Winfrey, The Times's Brian Stelter talks about the fallen athlete as he faces the media.

abstract: The prototype hints at the looks of the coming, third-generation seven-passenger MDX. And for the first time it could be available in front-wheel drive.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 15: 2014 Acura MDX Prototype

headline: Video Shows Flaming Wreckage After Helicopter Crash in London
abstract: Video and photographs posted online by witnesses showed smoke and fire on a street in central London after a helicopter crash on Wednesday left two people dead and at least nine injured.
lead_paragraph: Video and photographs posted online by witnesses showed smoke and fire on a street in central London after a helicopter crash on Wednesday. The police said the aircraft hit a crane atop a residential tower, exploding into flames and hurtling to the ground during the morning rush, my colleagues Lark Turner and Alan Cowell reported.

headline: Alfa Romeo Returns to America, via China
abstract: The 2013 Guangzhou Trumpchi is based on the Alfa Romeo 166.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 15: 2007 Alfa Romeo 166 … check that, it’s now a 2013 Guangzhou Trumpchi

headline: When Scots Cut Loose, They Go All the Way
abstract: “Midsummer,” written and directed by David Greig, is a rom-com in theatrical form centering on a long, wild weekend in Edinburgh complete with theft, bondage and drinking.
lead_paragraph: New York seems to be lacking in proper date plays — you know, lively love stories that might lead to dinners in dark places and public make-out sessions. Of course there’s “Once,” the Tony-winning, boy-almost-gets-girl musical on Broadway. But if you’re looking for a less obvious, more affordable show to see with that special someone you slipped your number to last week at Citarella, you could do worse than “Midsummer,” written and directed by David Greig.

headline: Kathryn Bigelow Steps Up Defense of “Zero Dark Thirty”
abstract: A naturally reserved woman who dislikes public speaking, she has taken more opportunities to defend her film and its portrayal of torture as a tactic used by the C.I.A. in its manhunt.
lead_paragraph: As the political and film industry tensions around “Zero Dark Thirty” rise, Kathryn Bigelow, a naturally reserved woman who dislikes public speaking, has taken more opportunities to defend her film, about the hunt for Osama bin Laden, and its portrayal of torture as a tactic used by the C.I.A. in its manhunt.

headline: Pot Goes to Florida, and Vice Versa
abstract: New comic novels by Dave Barry and Tim Dorsey feature hapless tourists and overlapping humor.
lead_paragraph: Dave Barry has written a comic novel that features lost luggage, beaches, hapless tourists from Michigan, exotic animal life, drugs, wild mix-ups, laughable oldsters and the trademarked zaniness of Florida. Not at all coincidentally Tim Dorsey’s new comic novel features these same ingredients, although Mr. Dorsey’s hapless tourists come from Wisconsin.

headline: H.P. Said to Have Suitors for Two Units
abstract: Hewlett-Packard has received a number of inquiries from would-be buyers for its Autonomy and Electronic Data Systems units in recent weeks, though the technology company isn’t interested in selling at the moment, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Hewlett-Packard has received a number of inquiries from would-be buyers for its Autonomy and Electronic Data Systems units in recent weeks, though the technology company is not interested in selling at the moment, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: By the Fadduh of ’60s Parodies
abstract: Allan Sherman’s 1969 musical “The Fig Leaves Are Falling” is given a new treatment by UnsungMusicalsCo. at the Connelly Theater in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: Broadway history is punctuated with failures, but some are more spectacular than others. Surely hopes were high in 1969 when Allan Sherman, he of “Hello Muddah, Hello Fadduh” and the best-selling song-parody album “My Son, the Folk Singer,” delivered a musical about the strains of infidelity then sweeping across suburbia. Despite Dorothy Loudon as its star and George Abbott as its director “The Fig Leaves Are Falling” closed after four performances, leaving behind a memorable pan from Clive Barnes of The New York Times. “There is nothing much wrong” with the show, he wrote, “that a new book, new music, new lyrics, new settings, new direction, new choreography and a partially new cast would not quite possibly put right.”

headline: Counting the Vanishing Bees
abstract: No census exists so far, but a new monitoring method involving pan traps is remarkably cheap and efficient.
lead_paragraph: A new method for monitoring the decline in bee populations may prove a useful tool in much-needed conservation efforts. It requires only a few hundred pan traps: bright shallow bowls partly filled with soapy water or propylene glycol.

headline: Segregation Linked in Study With Lung Cancer Deaths
abstract: The study was the first to look at segregation as a factor in lung cancer mortality, and its authors said they could not fully explain why it worsens the odds of survival for African-Americans.
lead_paragraph: African-Americans who live in highly segregated counties are considerably more likely to die from lung cancer than those in counties that are less segregated, a new study has found.

headline: China Arrests 7 in New Effort to Stop Tibetan Self-Immolations
abstract: The arrests suggest that the government is embracing a new strategy against politically motivated suicides: punishing friends and relatives of those who self-immolate.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The authorities in northwest China have detained seven people they say organized the fatal self-immolation of a Tibetan villager in October, photographed his burning body and then sent the images abroad.

headline: A First Look at Saint Laurent in the Stores
abstract: Hedi Slimane’s first designs for Saint Laurent, including his spring men’s wear and a women’s resort collection that had not previously been shown to the news media, began appearing in stores this week.
lead_paragraph: Hedi Slimane’s first designs for Saint Laurent, including his spring men’s wear and a women’s resort collection that had not previously been shown to the news media, began appearing in stores this week, giving customers their first opportunity to see the clothes up close. Barneys New York has a small selection of the men’s designs, including a cotton hoodie that costs nearly $1,000, and some women’s pieces like a minidress in an animal print ($4,490) are now available online.

But in anticipation of its reopening next year, the Smithsonian announced on Wednesday that it is starting a programming and exhibition series this summer at the Patent and Trademark Office’s headquarters in Alexandria, Va.

headline: Rodriguez Has Hip Surgery; Yankees Expect Six-Month Recovery
abstract: If all goes well, Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez should be back in major league games in July, his surgeon said.
lead_paragraph: The last time Alex Rodriguez had hip surgery was 2009. He did not return until May 8 that season, but managed to hit 30 home runs and knock in 100 runs, then went on a remarkable tear in the postseason to lead the Yankees to a World Series title. Four years later, Rodriguez is hoping for a taste of the same formula, although the recovery time could be three times as long.

headline: Audi’s Trackside Diversion in Detroit
abstract: Fueled with a mix of pizza and the acrid exhaust of small chattering engines, journalists and Audi executives fought it out on a go-kart track.

Perhaps to drive the point home, the German automaker invited journalists to a night of go-karting, following the first media preview day on Monday.

headline: In Thoreau’s Flower Journal, Clues for Climatologists
abstract: Relying on notes taken by the naturalists Henry David Thoreau and Aldo Leopold, researchers track over a century of warming spring temperatures and earlier first blooms.
lead_paragraph: Henry David Thoreau was a peculiar fellow. After his secluded stint at Walden Pond, his fixation with the natural world only grew. Starting in 1852, his journal turned into a two million-word project documenting seasonal observations around his small Massachusetts township, Concord. Over the next six springs he could be seen racing about town like a madman in an effort to spot and record that year’s first elusive blooms, all the while taking notes.

headline: Letting Dance Carry Music: Balanchine Put Tchaikovsky in Perspective
abstract: The New York City Ballet opened its winter season on Tuesday night with a Balanchine-Tchaikovsky triple bill.
lead_paragraph: Peter Martins will soon reach his 30th anniversary as ballet master in chief of New York City Ballet. The company’s schedule for the whole 2012-13 season reads as a statement of what Mr. Martins believes matters most to its identity. The fall season concentrated on the series of Stravinsky ballets that was the most celebrated and radical part of the founder and choreographer George Balanchine’s work; the current season, through Feb. 24, celebrates Balanchine’s no less important Tchaikovsky ballets (following the six-week season of “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker,” a core ballet for reasons apart from its popularity). And the spring season will focus on Mr. Martins’s own ballets. Premieres by both Justin Peck and Christopher Wheeldon are spaced over months.

Born in the north of England to a coal miner father and a mother who worked in a cotton mill, he lives in London.

headline: Illumination, Inspired by Catastrophe
abstract: Cappellini introduces the Meltdown lamp.
lead_paragraph: Giulio Cappellini, the Italian design entrepreneur who helped start the careers of such luminaries as Jasper Morrison, Tom Dixon and Marcel Wanders, has made another find: a young Swedish designer, Johan Lindsten, whom Mr. Cappellini discovered at the Salone Satellite, a showplace of young talents that is part of the International Furniture Fair in Milan. Their first collaboration is a lamp by Mr. Lindsten made of thin-walled, handblown colored glass. Called Meltdown, the lamp is Mr. Lindsten’s comment on the nuclear catastrophe at Fukushima, Japan. Instead of being suspended within the fixture, the light bulb rests against the bottom of the glass and looks ready to dissolve.

headline: Art Imitates Indianapolis
abstract: An installation throughout the new Alexander Hotel reflects the city’s history.
lead_paragraph: Indianapolis Museum of Art curators have filled a nearby hotel with contemporary art that resonates with and sometimes mocks the region. At the Alexander Hotel, designed by Gensler, which opens Monday, windows here and there are covered with the artist Kim Beck’s vinyl silhouettes of local weeds (above). The sculptor Sonya Clark built a portrait of the Indianapolis hair-care tycoon Madam C. J. Walker out of 3,840 combs (top right). Paul Villinski’s wall-mounted installation is made from vinyl records by musicians including the Gary, Ind., native Michael Jackson (top left). And Mark Fox’s stream-of-consciousness text, cut from reflective stainless steel, notes that John Dillinger is buried about seven and a half miles from the Alexander, and that hotel rooms are zones of “mirrors and copulation.”

headline: Tips From a Backyard on a Dirt Road
abstract: Margaret Roach publishes her second memoir about rural life and gardening.
lead_paragraph: Margaret Roach, the garden writer and blogger who lived out the fantasy of not only making it to the top (editorial director of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia), but also chucking it for an old house in upstate New York, wrote about her first adventures with snakes and solitude in “And I Shall Have Some Peace There: Trading in the Fast Lane for My Own Dirt Road.” Now, in “The Backyard Parables: Lessons on Gardening, and Life” (Grand Central Publishing, $26), she really digs in. Along with observations of wind, caterpillars and bacteria — Mycobacterium vaccae can elevate the mood and stimulate immune cells — she offers details like shoveling alone, through thigh-high snow, in the dark of night, to hammer a hole in the ice of a frog pond so the frogs didn’t suffocate. For fans who crave her gardening advice, don’t worry. She tells how to protect banana plants in winter, and put up a deer fence, too.

headline: Which Way Did the Taliban Go?
abstract: Digging out roadside bombs, running into ambushes and dancing with deranged informants — a week in the life of an Afghan National Army battalion, on its own in the wilderness.
lead_paragraph: The village was abandoned. Streets deserted. Houses empty. Behind the central mosque rose a steep escarpment. Behind the escarpment mountains upon mountains. Up there — above the timberline, among the peaks — a white Taliban flag whipped in the wind. Several Afghan soldiers were admiring it when a stunted and contorted person emerged from an alley. Dressed in rags, he waved a hennaed fist at them and wailed. Tears streamed down his face. Most of the soldiers ignored him. Some laughed uncomfortably. A few jabbed their rifles at his chest and simulated shooting. The man carried on undeterred — reproaching them in strange tongues.

headline: How Good Does Karaoke Have to Be to Qualify as Art?
abstract: Portland’s karaoke scene includes strippers, muppets and every song you can dream of. Can a city be having a pop-music moment if all everyone’s doing is singing along?
lead_paragraph: John Brophy, the mastermind of America’s greatest karaoke night, lives in a well-kept bungalow in a neighborhood of small homes in southeast Portland, Ore. When I visited on a weekday afternoon last spring, Brophy, then 36, wore a ringer T-shirt and dark jeans. His wrist was encircled by a half-dozen bracelets, and his dark hair swooped in front of his face. Like many Portlanders, he’s in a band, called Gingerbread Patriots, although currently the band is on hiatus — the “Shows” section of the Gingerbread Patriots Web site is empty but for the words “2009 will bring shows shows and more shows!”

headline: What I Sang on My Epic Karaoke Odyssey
abstract: In Portland, I visited karaoke nights at tiki bars, strip clubs, comedy clubs, honky-tonks and pizza places. These are the songs I sang.
lead_paragraph: For this weekend’s magazine, I wrote about my epic six-day karaoke odyssey in Portland, Ore., hoping to figure out why this city’s karaoke scene is so ridiculously vibrant. I visited karaoke nights at tiki bars, strip clubs, comedy clubs, honky-tonks and pizza places, interviewing K.J.s (karaoke jocks), fans, strippers and Portland’s mayor. But I also, of course, sang. A lot.

headline: Maybe There Is Such a Thing as Bad Publicity
abstract: A commercial on ABC would have cost TerraCycle hundreds of thousands of dollars and only given it 30 seconds of exposure. Instead, the company got more than three minutes, twice in one month. But at what cost?
lead_paragraph: In part because we are a social enterprise with a mission that most people support — keeping waste out of landfills and incinerators — TerraCycle has been blessed with a lot of good publicity. In fact, we talk about having what we call a “negative-cost” media department that in 2012 generated more than 4,500 articles around the world. That’s more than 12 articles per day! (You can see an example of this coverage here.) We call the department negative-cost because we have been able to produce marketing — books, TV shows — that earns us money while also promoting the company.

headline: Louisville Slugger
abstract: A tender, rosy roast beef — a good excuse for more Henry Bain sauce.
lead_paragraph: The Pendennis Club in Louisville, Ky., is a big Georgian pile that might have appeared in the Thackeray novel it was named for, full of wealthy afternoon nappers and drawling black-tie gentry. In the early part of the last century, the club’s headwaiter was a black man named Henry Bain. His contribution to the world was at least as important as the newspapers and racehorses, banks and bridges sired by the white club members he served. Bain invented a sauce.

headline: On the Non-equivalence of Greenhouse Gases and Entitlement Spending
abstract: Current gases versus future spending: not the same.
lead_paragraph: One fairly common trope in budget discussions – I’m pretty sure I’ve done it myself, somewhere along the line – is to compare attitudes toward fiscal issues and those toward environmental issues. The usual version, which I must have used, is to compare attitudes toward the long run: pointing out how strange it is that many people profess to be deeply concerned about the state of the Social Security trust fund in the year 2037, while being apparently indifferent to the state of the climate around the same time, which is all too likely to involve things like a permanent drought in the southwest and so on.
