lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — If Harry Swayne could choose, he would appoint Lenny Moore as the Baltimore Ravens’ honorary captain for the pregame coin toss at Super Bowl XLVII.

headline: The Great Migration
abstract: As the winners of our meritocracy hold the reins of progressive power, they may struggle to mitigate the inequality their own ascendance has helped produce.
lead_paragraph: One of the features of the Obama years is that we get to witness an enormous race, which you might call the race between meritocracy and government. On the one side, there is the meritocracy, which widens inequality. On the other side, there is President Obama’s team of progressives, who are trying to mitigate inequality. The big question is: Which side is winning?

headline: Aurora’s Suffering Beyond the Spotlight
abstract: The movie theater in Aurora, Colo., where a gunman went on a rampage, reopened last week, but life for surviving families is far from being back to normal.
lead_paragraph: The cinema complex in Aurora, Colo., reopened last week, six months after a gunman killed 12 patrons, wounded 58 and left deep scars on a community still struggling to recover. “Everyone heals, some slower, some in different ways,” contended Gov. John Hickenlooper of Colorado in the face of angry complaints from some of the victims’ families that the reopening, with prayers, a “night of remembrance” and a screening of “The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey,” was insensitive and crass.

headline: Hubris in the Commonwealth
abstract: No sooner had a Democratic state senator left for the inauguration than Republicans, in a power grab, passed a partisan redistricting map.
lead_paragraph: The dark art of statehouse gerrymandering reached a new low in Virginia this week. Senate Republicans in Richmond used the absence of a Democratic member, who traveled to the presidential inauguration, to ram through a surprise redistricting map patently designed to aid the G.O.P.’s grab for majority power in the next election.

headline: Mr. Cuomo’s Low-Buzz Budget
abstract: By Albany standards, Governor Cuomo’s budget is mostly low trauma, but it does need a few fixes.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York presented an extra-lean state budget this week, his third conservative spending plan since taking office in 2011. The total outlays for fiscal year 2013-14, including federal funds to rebuild after Hurricane Sandy, will be almost $143 billion. The budget contains some real bonuses, including a plan to raise the minimum wage and a proposal for a workable database for gun ownership. But it could also raise the debt load, especially in struggling upstate areas.

headline: Women in the Battlefield
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: Ending the ban on women in combat means greater opportunity and a stronger military.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon’s decision to end its ban on women in combat is a triumph for equality and common sense. By opening infantry, artillery and other battlefield jobs to all qualified service members regardless of sex, the military is showing that categorical discrimination has no place in a society that honors fairness and equal opportunity.

headline: American Adoptions From Abroad at Their Lowest Level in Years
abstract: Moves to limit adoptions by some countries and tougher standards intended to protect children may be making it harder to put them in new homes, officials say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The number of foreign children adopted by Americans has plunged to its lowest level in more than a decade as some countries have cut back on adoptions to the United States and others have struggled to meet stricter standards intended to combat corruption and child trafficking, government officials said Thursday.

headline: Gay Marriage Bill Approved in Rhode Island House Vote
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures', 'Marriages']
abstract: After an easy 51-to-19 vote by representatives, the same-sex marriage measure faces a tougher fight in the State Senate.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — The Rhode Island House of Representatives on Thursday handily passed a bill to legalize same-sex marriage, paving the way for a showdown in the State Senate in the only New England state where it is not allowed.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Jan. 25, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, January 25, 2013.
lead_paragraph: It’s not enough to change the law. We also need cops on the beat to enforce the law.

headline: Health Chief Defends Decision Not to Evacuate Hospitals
abstract: Dr. Thomas A. Farley told the City Council it was “a judgment call,” and said moving patients in advance of Hurricane Sandy would have been even more risky, perhaps leading to deaths.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s health commissioner ardently defended the city’s decision not to evacuate hospitals and nursing homes before Hurricane Sandy, facing down withering questions Thursday from City Council members who contended that some old people may have died as a result.

headline: Adoptive Parents vs. Tribal Rights
abstract: Should the adoption of American Indian children receive special consideration, or is it too much focused on race?

Pay $162 Million to
Foundation

lead_paragraph: HCA, the nation’s largest profit-making hospital chain, was ordered on Thursday to pay $162 million after a judge in Missouri ruled that it had failed to abide by an agreement to make improvements to dilapidated hospitals that it bought in the Kansas City area several years ago.

headline: 3 Black Men Are Offered Committees in Senate
abstract: The move came as lawmakers seek to address concerns about a lack of racial diversity in the ranks of its leadership.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Seeking to address concerns about a lack of racial diversity in its ranks, a coalition of Republicans and breakaway Democrats that controls the State Senate offered committee chairmanships on Thursday to two black Democrats who are not part of the coalition.

headline: A Timeout Jeered Round the World
abstract: A 10-minute break by Victoria Azarenka during her match with Sloane Stephens at the Australian Open shifted momentum and added fuel to a debate over the legitimacy of medical timeouts.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — When the world’s top-ranked female tennis player was examined on the court and then granted a medical timeout Thursday during her semifinal match at the Australian Open, the howling commenced immediately. Skeptical fans at Rod Laver Arena and those watching on television worldwide were convinced that the player, Victoria Azarenka of Belarus, was suffering from nothing more than an attack of nerves and perhaps faked an injury to collect herself after losing several crucial points.

headline: Picture Him in a Mohawk: A Czech Prince Seeks Young Voters
abstract: Karel Schwarzenberg, a 75-year-old prince, is running for president of the Czech Republic with an advertising campaign that has him wearing a pink mohawk.
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — His face stares out from campaign posters in music clubs and hip cafes, a 75-year-old prince retooled as a punk rocker with a hot pink mohawk and lofty presidential ambitions.

headline: Number of Tears
abstract: Why so glum, Joe DiPietro?
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — I solved this one in a clockwise pattern, and I suspect that Joe DiPietro needs some cheering up. Oh, he tries to put on a brave front: it’s all RAINBOW ROOM in the northwest, but then he hears a SAD SONG and a SOB, witnesses someone STEALing BASES, ponders how it all STRUCK A NOTE, and decried the MORTAL SIN in the center of the grid.

headline: Chinese Graduates Say No Thanks to Factory Jobs
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Youth', 'Series']
abstract: Millions of Chinese graduate from college every year, but they struggle to find jobs in an economy that is still dominated by blue-collar industries.
lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China — This city of 15 million on the Pearl River is the hub of a manufacturing region where factories make everything from T-shirts and shoes to auto parts, tablet computers and solar panels. Many factories are desperate for workers, despite offering double-digit annual pay increases and improved benefits.

headline: Jets’ General Manager Lands in Crisis Mode
abstract: The Jets introduced their new general manager, John Idzik, who is aware of all the challenges that await him, including reports about trading the injured cornerback Darrelle Revis.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — At 11 a.m. Thursday, the Jets’ owner Woody Johnson introduced John Idzik, the team’s new general manager, at a news conference. It was Idzik’s first official day at the training center. He met employees at an organizational welcome breakfast in the cafeteria. He also had Rex Ryan show him where his office was. It was unclear if Idzik was kidding.

headline: Governors Push Bigger Reliance on Sales Taxes
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Governors (US)', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Corporate Taxes', 'States (US)']

headline: U.N. Panel to Investigate Rise in Drone Strikes

lead_paragraph: LONDON — A prominent British human rights lawyer said on Thursday that a United Nations panel he leads would investigate what he called the “exponential rise” in drone strikes used in counterterrorist operations, “with a view to determining whether there is a plausible allegation of unlawful killing.”

headline: Richard G. Stern, Writers’ Writer, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Stern’s classroom at the University of Chicago became a showcase for visiting literary eminences like Philip Roth.
lead_paragraph: Richard G. Stern, whose novels, short stories and essays were almost universally admired in the literary world but whose name remained stubbornly unrecognized in the wider world of readers, earning him a reputation for being, as one reviewer put it, “the best American author of whom you have never heard,” died on Thursday at his home on Tybee Island, Ga. He was 84.

headline: Weighing Political Risk Against Mercy for Prisoners

lead_paragraph: A little more than a year ago, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s staff reported that it was taking a careful look at applications from people in prison for official mercy. His spokesman promised: “It is a power that the governor will use practically and methodically to help ensure everyone is treated fairly under the law.”

headline: A Night Later, the Rangers’ Struggles Resume
abstract: The Rangers’ record fell to 1-3 as they lost to the Flyers for the first time after eight wins going back to May 2011.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — After one night’s respite, the Rangers are back in a funk. They lost here Thursday to the Flyers, a team that was winless in three games this season and that entered the evening missing three of its key players.

headline: North Course Is Shortest Route to Top of Leader Board at Torrey Pines
abstract: The leader board at Torrey Pines was top heavy with players who teed off on the North Course, which at last year’s event played to an average that was 2.8 strokes easier than the South layout.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — The Farmers Insurance Open is the golfing equivalent of a 400-meter race, an onerous aerobic test with a staggered start that makes it hard to pick out the pacesetter at Torrey Pines. The Thursday leader board was top-heavy with players who teed off on the North Course, which at last year’s event played to an average that was 2.8 strokes easier than the South layout.

headline: Armed Forces in Canada Resolved Issue Long Ago
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: More than two decades later, the debate in Canada over the suitability of women as combat troops has all but faded from the nation’s collective memory.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — When Sheila A. Hellstrom first joined the Royal Canadian Air Force in 1954, she was limited to one of three roles: nurse, dietitian or administrator. As the decades passed, she would become the first Canadian woman to reach the rank of general and the Canadian military would integrate women into combat roles.

lead_paragraph: Dulce Vida Cafe has helped fill a culinary void on the Upper East Side.

keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: Prime Minister Raja Pervez Ashraf has outraged many by urging that murder charges be dropped in a deadly garment factory fire last year.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Prime Minister Raja Pervez Ashraf, already targeted by the country’s interventionist Supreme Court, has become embroiled in a new judicial controversy, this time over the investigation into a garment factory fire that killed at least 259 people in Karachi last year.

headline: G.O.P. Mulls a Strategy From Obama’s Playbook
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Republican National Committee is reviewing the party’s deficiencies, particularly in technology and grass-roots organizing, that contributed to Mitt Romney’s defeat.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — As Republican leaders gathered here on Thursday to consider how to rebuild their party, President Obama was at the center of the conversation. But the sharp criticism directed at him was replaced by something new: envy over his campaign.

headline: Loyalists to Dominate Jordan’s New Parliament
abstract: The vote was intended by King Abdullah II to quell the discontent that has posed a challenge to his rule, but the results make it unlikely that the protest movement will be appeased.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — The new 150-seat Parliament here will include members arrested just days before the elections on charges of vote-buying, and a cast of government loyalists will dominate a body long seen by Jordanians as being as corrupt as it is inept.

headline: No. 2 Leader of Al Qaeda in Yemen Is Killed
abstract: Said Ali al-Shihri died recently from wounds he received during a “counterterrorism operation” late last year, Yemen’s government announced Thursday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Said Ali al-Shihri, the second-ranking operative in Al Qaeda’s branch in Yemen, died recently from wounds he received during a “counterterrorism operation” late last year, Yemen’s government announced Thursday.

headline: Savoring Culinary Secrets From Colombia
abstract: Dulce Vida Cafe, whose menu is filled with recipes from the owner’s mother, attracts expatriates from across the city.
lead_paragraph: “Adiós, Queens!” said the squat, burly man to Maria Marquez-Hass, the owner of Dulce Vida Cafe on Lexington Avenue and 82nd Street, on a recent Saturday. He wasn’t talking about an impending move. He meant that her Colombian food was so good that he would no longer have to traipse from his home in the Bronx out to Jackson Heights, where many of the city’s Colombian restaurants are found, to get his fix.

headline: Police Search Offices of Fruit Importer in Russia
abstract: Officials said that they had uncovered evidence that leaders of the Joint Fruit Company had used falsified contracts with fictitious businesses to obtain large loans from major banks.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officials on Thursday searched the offices of Vladimir Kekhman, the general director of the Mikhailovsky Theater in St. Petersburg, as part of a widening fraud investigation into the Joint Fruit Company, of which Mr. Kekhman is a major owner. Known as “the Banana King,” because of the wealth he earned as a fruit importer, Mr. Kekhman in recent years has seemed to focus more on the arts than on business. Officials with the Interior Ministry told the news agency Interfax that it had uncovered evidence that between 2010 and 2012 leaders of the Joint Fruit Company had used falsified contracts with fictitious businesses to obtain large loans from major banks. Investigators said Mr. Kekhman was not a target of the investigation. The Joint Fruit Company filed for bankruptcy last year after creditors sought repayment of the loans. Mr. Kekhman issued a statement saying that he was “outraged” by the fraud allegations against company officials and that he was cooperating with law enforcement.

headline: Protesters Clash With Police in Cairo
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police']
abstract: A coalition of opposition groups has called for a major rally in Tahrir Square to voice opposition to the new Islamist-backed Constitution and President Mohamed Morsi.
lead_paragraph: Protesters clashed with the police on Thursday in Cairo near Tahrir Square on the eve of the second anniversary of the uprising that toppled President Hosni Mubarak. Three police officers and dozens of protesters were injured in skirmishes after protesters tried to dismantle concrete barriers that had been set up around the Interior Ministry after previous demonstrations. A coalition of opposition groups has called for a major rally in Tahrir Square, the center of the 2011 uprising, to voice opposition to the new Islamist-backed Constitution and President Mohamed Morsi. The Muslim Brotherhood, the Islamist group allied with Mr. Morsi, has asked its supporters to observe the anniversary by taking part in community service projects far from the square, a plea aimed at preventing renewed fighting between the factions.

headline: The Perils of DVR’ing the Australian Open
abstract: For a tennis fanatic in the United States, managing the time difference between the U.S. and Australia is one of the most difficult tasks of the year.
lead_paragraph: How does one fit eight hours of tennis viewing into a workday without getting fired or divorced? That’s the question I face four times every year when my life revolves around tennis’s major tournaments to the detriment of work and family life. Twice in the past five years, I made the mistake of booking trips to Latin America during the Australian Open and found myself up in the middle of the night, watching grainy images of barely recognizable figures on dodgy Web sites that infected my laptop with viruses. Never again.

headline: Towns’ Next Hit From Hurricane Is to Tax Revenue
abstract: As a result of property damage, localities across the New York region that are reeling from Hurricane Sandy cannot expect to reap the same property taxes from homeowners.
lead_paragraph: Localities across the New York region, already reeling from the cost of cleaning up from Hurricane Sandy, are confronting the prospect of an even bigger blow to their finances: a precipitous decline in property tax revenues.

headline: Two Children Who Need All of Mother’s Energy
abstract: Every day brings a new and exhausting challenge for Colleen Tam-Diaz who cares for her children, while dealing with health problems of her own.
lead_paragraph: Nine steps lead to the front door of the Tam-Diaz household. Thirteen more lead from the first floor to the second. And Colleen Tam-Diaz feels the strain of every one.

headline: Even in Sickness, a Promise to a Son to Fulfill
abstract: After a difficult pregnancy, a diagnosis of breast cancer and the loss of her work, a Lower East Side woman received help.
lead_paragraph: It has been more years than she can remember since Dolores Lora tried to solve a math problem or was tested on her spelling. She could not believe how much she had forgotten as she watched one of her sons tackle his homework with ease.

While the sellout crowd at TD Garden was generally restrained (by Boston standards) in its treatment of Carmelo Anthony, he would enjoy the last laugh.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 1:30 P.M. (IFC) ABOUT A BOY (2002) In Paul and Chris Weitz’s adaptation of Nick Hornby’s novel Hugh Grant plays Will, a London Lothario with a Peter Pan complex who must face up to his irresponsible ways when Marcus (Nicholas Hoult), the socially inept 12-year-old son of a hippie-dippy single mother (Toni Collette, above, with Mr. Grant, right, and Mr. Hoult), begins to stalk him. Rachel Weisz is the artist on whom Will fixes his sights; he uses Marcus to help seduce her. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that “Mr. Grant, leaning on his mumbling charm until it turns into its opposite, is an ideal cad.” Like “High Fidelity,” another of Mr. Hornby’s works, “ ‘About a Boy’ finds redemption in a stale, gooey pop song, in this case Roberta Flack’s ‘Killing Me Softly,’ ” Mr. Scott added. “It’s a cheap trick, but one that’s guaranteed to work every time. You succumb to the movie’s warmth and bonhomie because the alternative is to remain in the isolating, self-protective cynicism from which Will has been lucky to escape.”

headline: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 25
abstract: North Korea issues more threats, a prince runs for president of the Czech Republic, and sumo wrestling is dominated by non-Japanese competitors.
lead_paragraph: NEWS  A blunt and explicit threat on Thursday from North Korea that its weapons programs would “target” the United States, and that it would proceed with a third and “higher-level” nuclear test, poses a stark challenge to the Obama administration at a time when it hoped to focus its major diplomatic effort on restraining Iran’s less-advanced nuclear program. David E. Sanger reports from Washington and Choe Sang-Hun from Seoul.

headline: Familiar Rooms, Hidden Faces
abstract: Alison Brady’s images — of contorted bodies, hidden faces and oddly familiar rooms — are unsettling, an effort to explore the fear that is triggered when our reality is uncomfortably distorted.
lead_paragraph: If looking at Alison Brady’s photographs makes you inexplicably uncomfortable, then she has accomplished her goal. Her images are carefully structured to blend the familiar with the unknown — antique furniture and vintage fabrics juxtaposed with unnaturally twisted body forms — with the hope of getting viewers to ask one question: “I know these objects, but why does this all feel so foreign?”

lead_paragraph: The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, published and periodically updated by the American Psychiatric Association, is one of those documents few laypeople ever read, but many of us are affected by.

headline: Chinese Leader Takes Conciliatory Tone in Meeting With Japanese Lawmaker
abstract: Xi Jinping, the Chinese leader, met with the lawmaker in an effort to cool tensions with Japan over islands in the East China Sea claimed by both nations.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s new leader, Xi Jinping, offered Japan a conciliatory tone during a meeting with a senior Japanese politician on Friday in what appeared to be an effort to reduce the escalating tensions between the countries over islands in the East China Sea.

headline: France Is Sweet on ‘Sugar Man’
abstract: The French have a tradition of adopting American artists that they consider underappreciated in the United States. The 70-year-old musician Rodriguez is the latest.

headline: Italy's Oil Leader Is Pursuing Its East African Bet
abstract: Beginning in 2010, the Italian oil company and a rival, Anadarko Petroleum, made a series of finds in Mozambique that add up to the largest natural gas trove of recent years.

There, geologists working for the Italian oil company Eni don 3-D glasses to contemplate fluorescent images of underground geological formations and try to divine which might be worth tens of millions of dollars in exploratory drilling.

headline: Getting Sales Representatives to Sell
abstract: How long do you stick with a sales representative who is not performing?
lead_paragraph: During a previous She Owns It business group meeting, Beth Shaw, who owns YogaFit, said she realized she had to ramp up her sales efforts. Toward that end, she brought on a sales manager with a 60-day contract that is up in February. So far, results have been lackluster, leaving Ms. Shaw to wonder whether her expectations are realistic and whether she is offering the contractor the proper incentives to sell sponsorships of YogaFit’s conferences and its branded merchandise. She asked the group how quickly they expected new sales representatives to sell and what type of learning curve they expected.

headline: Five Questions for: Prajwal Parajuly

headline: A Hip-Hop Aesthetic With a Careful Grasp on History

headline: Consumer Spending and Inequality Denial
abstract: Summarizing the latest bait and switch.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been debating rising inequality with the usual suspects for a couple of decades (despite what it says on this piece, it was actually published in 1992). And what you always encounter from the right is a sort of defense in depth: claims, based on tortured statistics, that it isn’t happening; claims, based on similarly tortured statistics, that it doesn’t matter; and claims that anyway it’s a good thing. You might think that people would have to choose one of these lines: you can’t simultaneously say that inequality isn’t rising and that the rise is a good thing, can you? Well, yes you can; we’re engaged in a political defense of the 1% here, not research.

headline: The Accidental Writer
abstract: A path to a career is paved with the sometimes-painful experiences we make our own.
lead_paragraph: I became a writer when I was hit on the head with a rock. It was 1969, I was 6 years old and my mother had dropped me off at a friend’s birthday party. It was June, and I remember the backyard of that house, in Mandeville Canyon, the hot California sun on my hair, the screams of the children as they ran around the yard. The partygoers had assembled into a big and rowdy gang, chasing the birthday boy, trying to get him to crawl through the spanking machine (a joyful and sadistic enterprise in which the children stood in a row and the birthday boy crawled through their legs, getting whacked along the way). The adults gathered inside, trying to ignore us. Then the birthday boy picked up a big rock. And he threw it.

The Italians bombed Libyans on the eve of World War I, but that was just the beginning. From 1919 onward, the fledgling Royal Air Force was busy dropping bombs on Afghan, Somali and Iraqi tribesmen. In 1926, French artillery shelled the center of Damascus. It was in this context that Elbridge Colby, an American Army captain, wrote an article, “How to Fight Savage Tribes,” in order to educate his countrymen and challenge what he saw as their naïve faith in international law.

headline: What Does It Mean to Be Comfortable?
abstract: As the world’s cultures become more homogeneous, so has the definition of comfort.
lead_paragraph: In 1999, government workers in Mexico took their last officially sanctioned siesta. Until then, it was normal for clerks and bureaucrats to take two- or three-hour breaks in the middle of the workday. Many of them went home for lunch, took a nap, then returned to their offices, working into the evening to make up for lost time. The siesta used to be commonplace in Spanish-speaking countries, but the tradition was already waning as Latin America’s economies developed throughout the ’80s and ’90s. As companies and governments modernized, they adopted the same schedules as their counterparts in other countries. Mexico failed to properly anticipate the effect this would have on energy consumption.

headline: We Were Joy Division
abstract: Everything came easily for the new-wave band. Only later did they see how lucky they were.
lead_paragraph: It all started with the Sex Pistols. I saw them twice in 1976 — two gigs weeks apart at the Lesser Free Trade Hall in Manchester — Bernard Sumner (our guitarist) and I went together with a couple of friends to the first gig, and at the second gig I bumped into Ian Curtis, who would become our lead singer. They were only on for half an hour, but when they finished, we filed out quietly with our minds blown, absolutely utterly speechless, and it just sort of dawned on me then — that was it. On the way home that night we decided to form a band — Joy Division. The name was Ian’s idea.

headline: Who Made That Military Dog Tag?
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Design', 'Inventions and Patents', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Identification Devices']
abstract: An answer to the problem of unknown fallen soldiers.
lead_paragraph: During the Civil War, more than a quarter of dead soldiers remained unidentified. “I saw two human skull-bones, one pelvis and two jaw bones lying on a stump with no trace of a grave,” a newspaper correspondent wrote in 1866 about his tour of Southern battlefields. Even mothers could not recognize the weathered corpses of their sons. In order to increase the chances that they would receive proper burials, soldiers bought customized name tags made of metal or wood. When pinned on the lapel or worn around the neck, a tag could help bring the dead soldier home. “Soldiers did a lot to try to be identified,” says Luther Hanson, curator at the U.S. Army Quartermaster Museum. “Some soldiers even wrote their names on the bottom of their shoes.”

abstract: A fraught issue — illegal immigration — divides an Oklahoma family and their town in Rilla Askew’s novel.
lead_paragraph: What might have been a political polemic or a partisan pitch in the hands of a lesser writer, Rilla Askew’s fourth novel is a study in the categories and contradictions that dissolve families, dissect communities, and split nations. With a topic as incendiary as immigration at the story’s core, Askew could have trod heavily over her subject matter and garnered passionate responses from both sides of the political divide. Instead she personalizes the issue, exploring with a deft hand and an unflinching moral vision the gray areas of an argument so often presented in black and white.

headline: Ends of the Earth
abstract: Melanie Challenger travels in search of the species, cultures and industries touched by extinction.
lead_paragraph: This past summer I found myself traveling with a strange man straight out of Melanie Challenger’s book “On Extinction.” He was an Alaska homesteader, firefighter and fishing guide, and for a week he led me down a remote rivulet in Alaska’s interior. The ostensible purpose of our trip was to fish the biggest remaining sockeye salmon run in the world and at the same time to make a case for opposing what would be the continent’s largest open-pit mine to be built atop said salmon run. But the more I tried to establish a narrative about this man, the more he broke up my effort with a kind of wilderness attention deficit disorder. No sooner had he hunched over to differentiate the identities of the shades of sage and white in the blooming tundra than he would hear the call of a ptarmigan. This in turn would lead to a discourse on the connection between migrations and snow melt and the desperation of grizzly bears in particularly snowy years. He was so profoundly knowledgeable, and everything he said felt incredibly nuanced and relevant. But at the same time his accounts were often tedious and circular and without any “point” that an impatient New Yorker could discern.

headline: Exiting the Stage
abstract: In Ros Barber’s verse-novel, Christopher Marlowe fakes his own death in order to keep writing.
lead_paragraph: The pre-eminent fictional Marlowe is still the hard-boiled detective created by Raymond Chandler, but novelistic treatments of the real-life Elizabethan playwright Christopher Marlowe are running him a close second. The earliest, now seldom read, was a book called “It Was Marlowe,” published in 1895. Its author was an Ohio lawyer, Wilbur Gleason Zeigler. More recently there have been Anthony Burgess’s “Dead Man in Deptford” and Robin Chapman’s “Christoferus,” both published in 1993, the 400th anniversary of Marlowe’s death, as well as “Tamburlaine Must Die” (2004) by the Scottish thriller writer Louise Welsh. The list goes on.

headline: Sunken Treasure
abstract: A history of Venice, from the city’s origins as a lagoon refuge to its apex as a maritime empire to its rebirth as a modern tourist hub.
lead_paragraph: Some visitors to Venice, dazzled by its beauty, are struck speechless; a great many more, to judge from the ceaseless flood of books about it, have the opposite reaction. The library of literature inspired by the city and its wealth of masterpieces was already vast 131 years ago, when Henry James wrote his essay entitled “Venice.” “It is a great pleasure to write the word,” James began, “but I am not sure there is not a certain impudence in pretending to add anything to it.”

headline: Stairway to Hell

headline: Floating Ideas
abstract: Marie Tharp mapped the seafloor and hit the glass ceiling.
lead_paragraph: The only thing mid-20th-century scientists disliked more than being wrong was being told they were wrong by a woman. Marie Tharp, barely acknowledged in her life and nearly forgotten since her death in 2006, frustrated her male colleagues on both fronts. Working at a time when female scientists set off reflex skepticism, Tharp drafted the first comprehensive map of the ocean floor, which led to the acceptance of the once-mocked, now fundamental theory of continental drift. Not bad for someone whose discoveries were initially dismissed as “girl talk.”

headline: How to Make an Ironman Whimper (and Cough)

lead_paragraph: When you watch the video from the start of last February’s Empire State Building Run-Up, an 86-story stair race, one man stands out. Thomas Dold, a 28-year-old German wearing Bib No. 1, is already a few inches ahead when the starting horn blasts. His shins are canting into a run, and with his left arm he’s pushing at the chest of a runner to that side of him. A split second later, his right arm juts up to block more runners.

headline: In Quebec, a Celebration on Skis

lead_paragraph: Snow squeaked under my boots as I turned up the Rue Ste.-Anne and into the tangerine glow flowing from the streetlamps overhead. The storm that had blown in that afternoon had eased up for the moment, and in the distance I could just make out the sandstone spires of the  St.-Michel church still shrouded in fog.

headline: A Monsoon, Then Underwater Magic in Malaysia
abstract: The weather forces a family to make a vacation detour to one of the top diving destinations in the world.
lead_paragraph: We were in fins and snorkel masks, navigating the thicket of wooden posts that lift the Sipadan-Kapalai Dive Resort above the limpid waters of the Sulu Sea off Sabah, Malaysia. Around us were enough tropical fish to make not a school, but a university and all its departments: a score of yellow-and-black-striped tigerfish, stock-still under the stairs; a massive grouper, presiding over an artificial reef; banner fish, angelfish, starfish, parrotfish, needlefish, you name it, lounging amid corals and darting between rocks.

Beside me, our pilot, Thomas, was riding the yoke as if it was a mechanical bull, trying to keep the single-engine Cessna steady as gusts roared in from the Southern Ocean.

headline: Helicopter Parents Make Children Miss Milestones

lead_paragraph: Yet another account of educators describing wild instances of helicopter parenting is making the rounds, this time from Australia. lead_paragraph: HOPE: A Tragedy,  by Shalom Auslander. (Riverhead, $16.) Auslander’s previous books — the story collection “Beware of God” and the memoir “Foreskin’s Lament” — are propelled by the author’s struggle with the constraints of his Orthodox Jewish background. In “Hope: A Tragedy,” his first novel, hilarity alternates with pain as a doleful family man in upstate New York finds a prickly geriatric squatter in his attic: she claims to be Anne Frank and is working on a novel to eclipse her girlhood diary.

This week, two United Nations agencies opened a global campaign to address that conundrum, calling for changes in the way that food is harvested, transported, processed, sold and consumed.

So when Kotb and Gifford swore off alcohol for all of January, it was an eventful pledge — and an ill-conceived one, as it turned out, since it coincided with the publication of Kotb’s new book and the parties to celebrate its release. According to The New York Post, Gifford was spotted drinking chardonnay at a luncheon she organized for Kotb, just nine days after the announcement on the air of their alcohol sabbatical. “You caught me,” Gifford said through a representative. “You can’t celebrate a book launch without it.”

headline: Greek Opposition Leader Seeks Conference on Debt
abstract: Alexis Tsipras, the leftist opposition leader who could become the next prime minister, called for a European summit to ease the crushing debts that threaten not only his country but all of Europe.
lead_paragraph: The 38-year-old leftist opposition leader in Greece who could become its next prime minister on a wave of simmering popular fury over the government’s austerity measures, called on Friday for a European summit meeting to ease the crushing debts that threaten not only his country but all of Europe.

headline: Priebus Re-elected to Lead Republican National Committee
abstract: Reince Priebus pledged to remake and restore the Republican brand before the Congressional elections next year and the 2016 presidential race.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Reince Priebus was re-elected chairman of the Republican National Committee on Friday, overcoming divisions and tensions in the party as he pledged to remake and restore the Republican brand before the Congressional elections next year and the 2016 presidential race.

headline: A Courtship Marked by Longitudes and Latitudes
abstract: David Muehlke and Patricia Choi found their love in a shared wanderlust, and a desire to serve both globally and religiously.
lead_paragraph: Africa, Asia and the Middle East are not exotic or abstract destinations for David Muehlke and Patricia Choi. They are, in fact, places where Mr. Muehlke, a foreign service officer at the State Department, and Ms. Choi, a public health adviser at the Department of Health and Human Services, have staked their futures and that of the family that they hope to have one day.

headline: Test Run: Vine, Twitter’s New Video Sharing App
abstract: Vine, a new video capture tool introduced by Twitter, lends a quirky, stop-motion feel to its creations, which could have both entertaining and odd implications for the microblogging service.
lead_paragraph: Applications designed to let you record and post short videos to the Web almost always disappoint. The final products tend to be too grainy, too noisy and too shaky to be worth watching.

headline: A De Niro Campaign That Takes a Page From the Streep Playbook
abstract: The Weinsteins are trying to position Robert De Niro as this year’s Meryl Streep: a living legend who hasn’t won an Oscar in years.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – With less than a month to go before the Oscars, studios are putting their muscle into campaigns on all platforms. The Weinstein Company, a master of the form, has made a TV spot to show viewers – and Oscar voters – the many facets of Robert De Niro’s best supporting actor-nominated performance in “Silver Linings Playbook.”

headline: Living in His Own Tiny Home, Before He Was a Billionaire Mayor
abstract: Discussing the city’s contest to pick a developer for a new “micro-apartment” building on his Friday radio show, the mayor fondly recalled his own humble start in New York.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg may now be one of the wealthiest men in the world, with gracious estates scattered across the globe from Bermuda to London, but it was not always so.

headline: Who Should the Nationals’ New Racing President Be?
abstract: The Washington Nationals are picking a fifth president to join the Presidents’ Race. Who should it be?
lead_paragraph: You  have to give the Washington Nationals credit. They have turned a piece of game-day entertainment silliness — the Presidents’ Race — into a pop culture phenomenon, so much so that Teddy Roosevelt’s first victory in the last game of last season took on a life of its own.

headline: In Surprise, Educator Tied to Cheating Rejects Deal
keywords: ['Cheating', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Education (K-12)', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Clarence Mumford Sr., who is accused of soliciting teachers to take certification exams for others, said the proposed 9- to 11-year sentence was “too severe for what I am charged with.”
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — In an 11th-hour reversal, an educator accused of running a large test-cheating ring in three Southern states rejected a plea deal on Friday and elected to go to trial.

headline: Trouble on Tuesday Nights
abstract: ABC’s Tuesday-night comedy block has run into ratings difficulties.
lead_paragraph: Every broadcast television network has a slate with shows that do not perform to expectations. Take Tuesdays on ABC. This week, the series premiere of “The Taste,” a cooking competition show in the mold of “The Voice” on NBC, drew 5.8 million total viewers, according to Nielsen data. That is a decent audience sampling, but ultimately unimpressive considering its time slot competitor, the very popular “NCIS” on CBS, was a repeat.

headline: Lakers’ Glass Appears Empty at Halfway Mark
abstract: The star-laden Lakers entered Friday’s game 17-25, with conditions worsening by the day.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As Kobe Bryant tries to make sense of this train wreck of a season, he may want to note that Lakers stars of the past sometimes felt miserable, too.

headline: Celery, Center Plate
abstract: Take celery off your snack tray and move it to center plate with these five new Recipes for Health.
lead_paragraph: For many people, celery is best used as a garnish, part of a snack tray or perhaps to stir a Bloody Mary. But to Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist, celery can be a main course. She writes:

headline: F.D.A. Likely to Add Limits on Painkillers
abstract: An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration voted 19 to 10 to recommend increased restrictions on hydrocodone products, the country’s most widely used narcotic painkillers.
lead_paragraph: Trying to stem the scourge of prescription drug abuse, an advisory panel of experts to the Food and Drug Administration voted on Friday to toughen the restrictions on painkillers like Vicodin that contain hydrocodone, the most widely prescribed drugs in the country.

headline: Yuji Ramen Opens Campaign to Start a Restaurant
abstract: The campaign will use Kickstarter to raise money.
lead_paragraph: Yuji Haraguchi, whose Smorgasburg stand, Yuji Ramen, is popular for its “mazemen” or “dry ramen,” which is more of a stir-fry than soup, has announced a series of five-course omakase (chef’s choice) ramen dinners, to be held upstairs at Whole Foods, 95 East Houston Street (Bowery) from mid-March through May.

headline: On Our Radar: A Spinning Solar Cell
abstract: A solar start-up says its technology could generate electricity that was even cheaper than the coal-fired variety.
lead_paragraph: A solar venture says it has developed a “spin cell” technology using specialized lensing and a rotating conical shape that could generate five times more electricity from a given amount of land than conventional solar methods. It says the electricity would cost only 8 cents per kilowatt-hour, compared with 10 to 15 cents for electricity generated by conventional photovoltaic panels. [Clean Technica]

headline: Book Review Podcast: Joe Queenan on a Lifetime of Reading
abstract: Mr. Queenan discusses his new memoir, “One for the Books.”
lead_paragraph: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Ligaya Mishan reviews Joe Queenan’s “One for the Books,” a memoir about life as a voracious reader. Ms. Mishan says that Mr. Queenan, a “famously dyspeptic humorist,” is in this book “mostly in celebratory mode, writing of his love of literature.” Ms. Mishan writes:

headline: Feeling For | Atelier Nunu’s Uno Tote
abstract: This French tote strikes the balance between beauty and function.
lead_paragraph: One rarely needs another tote bag. That is, until a tote as beautifully proportioned, functional and smart as Atelier Nunu’s leather Uno comes along, and then needing gives way to wanting, which leads to asking how many colors it comes in (the answer is two: burgundy and tan) and next up, considering buying both.

keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Privacy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: A dispute has brought into the open how much Europe and the United States differ on privacy rights and their role in the digital economy.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley technology companies and the United States government are pushing hard against Europe’s effort to enact sweeping privacy protection for digital data.

headline: India Needs to ‘Reset Its Moral Compass,’ President Says
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Sex Crimes', 'Constitutions', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: President Pranab Mukherjee of India made a blunt call for gender equity and said the Dec. 16 gang rape and murder of a young woman in New Delhi had “shattered complacency.”
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — President Pranab Mukherjee on Friday warned about the danger of corruption corroding Indian public life and called on the country to “reset its moral compass” in light of a grisly gang rape and murder of a young woman that have stirred outrage and protests in India and around the world.

headline: Married to the Plan. Still Looking for a Possible Groom.
abstract: The lack of a prospective husband is a detail that can be addressed later.
lead_paragraph: Kate Owens, a 34-year-old project manager for I.B.M. who lives in Clifton Park, N.Y., had planned her wedding for more than a decade before marrying last June.

headline: Not Selling Gray Hair Short
abstract: For some older women, letting their hair go gray and long allows hem to defy attitudes about femininity and sexuality.
lead_paragraph: Cindy Joseph, a model, knew she was being subversive when she stopped tinting her long, loose waves more than a decade ago.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 25
abstract: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.
lead_paragraph: More photographs.

headline: Does Your Child Like Your Baby Sitter Best?
abstract: When parents feel like the baby sitter ranks higher than they do on a child’s list of “my favorite people.”
lead_paragraph: This week’s quandary comes via Michelle Cove and Facebook. Michelle (the author of “I Love Mondays, and Other Confessions From Devoted Working Moms”) was speaking at a “Parent Talk” event when a parent put up a hand and asked, “What do you do when you truly believe your kid likes the nanny/baby sitter better?”

headline: The Right Tone for a Sensitive Zombie
abstract: It was a challenge to develop makeup for Nicholas Hoult’s sensitive zombie in “Warm Bodies,” which opens on Friday.
lead_paragraph: How many scars should line the faces of the undead? How blue (or purple or pale) should their lips and skin be? How much blood is too much blood? These and many other questions can plague filmmakers who tackle the zombie movie genre, and when that zombie movie is also a romantic comedy, the questions get all the more complicated.

headline: How Bright Horizons Took Care of Bain Capital Over the Years
keywords: ['Child Care', 'Day Care Centers', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Private Equity']
abstract: Bright Horizons’ successful initial public offering on Friday was the latest chapter in the day care center chain’s long and lucrative relationship with Bain Capital.
lead_paragraph: For nearly three decades, the day care center chain Bright Horizons Family Solutions has taken care of children. It has also taken very good care of Bain Capital.

headline: Disputing a Charge on Your Credit Card
abstract: The cat and mouse game that goes on behind the scenes can be tilted more, or less, in your favor, depending on how you go about it.
lead_paragraph: If you have ever disputed a charge with your debit or credit card company, you know what a potent weapon this type of complaint can be.

headline: Li vs. Azarenka: A Study in Contrasts in Australian Open Final
abstract: Victoria Azarenka and Li Na are very different players heading into the Australian Open final, and the crowd is expected to treat them very unequally.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Each woman in the Australian Open final Saturday has already reached the finals in Melbourne this decade, has won one Grand Slam title and will be playing in her third Grand Slam final.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: ‘Persepolis’ Tops the Paperback List
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Graphic Novels']
abstract: Marjane Satrapi’s memoir is No. 1 on the paperback list.
lead_paragraph: There is activity on each of our graphic books best-seller lists this week. At No. 1 on the manga list is Vol. 2 of “Missions of Love,” a romance series. On the hardcover list, at No. 3, is “Dark Tower: The Gunslinger — The Man in Black,” the latest adaption of Stephen King’s epic, published by Marvel Entertainment. At No. 4 is Vol. 2 of “Wonder Woman,” part of the “New 52” initiative by DC Comics that reintroduced all the company’s heroes. Wonder Woman has always been tied to Greek mythology and this version is making great use of those mischievous gods and goddesses.

headline: The Card of My Dreams, Always Elusive
abstract: A look back at the allure of a Ken Griffey Jr. rookie card and an 11-year-old on a mission.
lead_paragraph: It was a spring day in 1998, and my best friend’s mother was on the other end of the phone. The news wasn’t good: her nephew wanted his baseball card back, despite the deal his younger brother had made to sell it to me for $2.

headline: Reports From Your Own Credit Card Disputes
abstract: Consumers and merchants share war stories from their own attempts to dispute debit or credit card purchases or defend against these complaints.
lead_paragraph: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I tried to give people a user’s guide to disputing credit and debit card purchases. The ability to turn problems over to your card issuer is one of the most powerful weapons in a consumer’s arsenal, but you don’t want to be wielding it constantly. Merchants are people, too, and disputing a charge causes them real hassle and expense.

headline: A Dead Date: That’ll Kill a Romance
abstract: “The Future Is Not What It Was,” by Michael Rabe, playing at Walkerspace, refers to the future but is set “in a world not unlike our own, where society’s moral compasses have been broken.”
lead_paragraph: “Everybody’s last night on earth is a sick joke,” Sean, a single young New Yorker, says defensively.

headline: Pentagon Reverses Some of Its Censoring of a War Book
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Bagram Air Base (Afghanistan)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: In an illustration of the government’s changeable ideas of what should be secret, Pentagon censors have decided that nearly 200 passages deleted from “Operation Dark Heart” can be printed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an illustration of the government’s changeable ideas of what should be secret, Pentagon censors have decided that nearly half of more than 400 passages deleted from an Afghan war memoir can be printed without damaging national security.

headline: Wielding Influence, Even if You’re Small
abstract: Bucks readers who own small businesses discuss their experiences in lobbying state and local government officials.
lead_paragraph: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, writes about one of small businesses’ disadvantages — they do not have the resources that the big companies do to wield political influence. But, as Paul points out, that does not mean they can’t wield any influence.

headline: A Hedge Fund Dogfight, Live, Mesmerizes Wall Street
abstract: Years of bad blood between the two hedge fund magnates spilled publicly onto CNBC’s airwaves on Friday, as Mr. Icahn derided his younger counterpart as a “crybaby,” and Mr. Ackman declared the veteran investor a “bully.”
lead_paragraph: For a half-hour on Friday afternoon, the eyes of Wall Street were not on the usual fixations, like the fiscal talks in Washington, or Apple’s earnings or a potential takeover of Dell.

headline: Jim Courier Wins Australian Open Again
abstract: Fans who woke up at 3:30 this morning to watch Andy Murray play Roger Federer got an extra treat.
lead_paragraph: As if the gutty, four-hour, five-set Australian Open semifinal today between Andy Murray and Roger Federer weren’t enough to make East Coast tennis fans glad they woke up at 3:30 a.m. to watch it live, viewers who hung on to see Jim Courier’s interview with Murray (scroll toward end of video) after his victory got an extra treat. Courier, who won the last of his four Grand Slam titles in Australia exactly 20 years ago, was a power baseliner as a player. As an interviewer, though, he’s a crisp serve-and-volley man. His questions are brief and informed, and they encourage his subjects to actually say something, as opposed to the all-too-common inane sportscaster queries like “How big was that . . . ?” and “What does it mean to have . . . ?” Courier was overshadowed during his fine playing career by contemporaries like Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi, but as an on-court interviewer, he’s almost unbeatable.

headline: On Lookout in Davos for Next Growth Story in Emerging Markets
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: An economic renaissance in Mexico, Chile, Colombia, Panama and Peru has become the focus in Latin America, and sub-Saharan Africa has also flashed signs of promise.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — With Europe in a sharp slowdown and the United States forging only a slow recovery, the business and academic elites gathering here are scouring the global landscape for any new economic success story. And a number of countries are stepping forward here at the World Economic Forum to peddle their tales — even if the smart money knows that betting on emerging markets continues to be risky.

headline: Pure Dance, Pure Finale
abstract: Trisha Brown, a leading choreographer for more than 50 years, will present her last two dances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this week.
lead_paragraph: THE CHOREOGRAPHER TRISHA BROWN has made dances worth arguing about for more than 50 years, and for at least 30 years her dances have been loved across the world. Many of today’s best-known choreographers — including David Gordon, Mark Morris and Stephen Petronio — have cited her influence, whether for the poetic fluidity of her movement or for the steely, analytical methods of her choreographic structures. A pioneer of the pure-dance experimentalists of the 1960s and ’70s, she challenged and changed the way we define dance performance.

headline: January Is the Cruelest Month
abstract: Written inside of us is the birth of the solar system and workings of the planet itself.
lead_paragraph: BY late January many of us residing in northern latitudes aren’t sleeping well, overeat and are looking forward to the long sunlit days of July. Some people even get clinically depressed: a recent study revealed that some 10 percent of New Hampshire residents suffer from seasonal affective disorder. For too many people, this might seem like just a quirk of their personalities, or worse, a shortcoming. But the cause for our malaise lies in the working of our genes, organs — and, ultimately, in the chemical structure of moon rocks, like the ones returned by the Apollo space program.

headline: From Note Pads to Shoulder Pads
abstract: The British soul singer Jessie Ware, recently nominated for the prestigious Mercury Prize, is advancing on the United States after her recent full-length album, “Devotion,” and a new EP.
lead_paragraph: ON A RECENT EVENING the British soul singer Jessie Ware was in her South London flat, staring helplessly at a suitcase. “I’m just kind of packing for tour as we speak, really,” she said. “I’m one of those people who gets her suitcase out a week before they’re going on holiday, just because you’re afraid you’re going to miss something. And then of course you miss something anyway.”

abstract: The annual financial report released this week by Germany’s Bundesliga shows a league that is the most secure and prosperous in Europe and the world.

Like the tectonic shifts of one continental plate against another, the goliath European leagues have been rubbing shoulders and stepping over each other for some time now, carving out the modern world of soccer one television deal or coefficient at a time.

headline: 2 Outlets Find Prized Sources in Algeria Siege: The Fighters

headline: For Mazda, It’s Diesels at Daytona
abstract: Three Mazda 6s that competed in the Rolex 24 endurance race last week used diesel engines, a technology the company says has never competed at Daytona.
lead_paragraph: When three Mazda 6 sedans roll onto the starting grid for the Rolex 24 endurance race on Saturday, they’ll be packing a technology the company says has never before competed at the Daytona International Speedway: diesel engines.

headline: Racing Fuel From the Fat of the Land
abstract: In its diesel racecars, Mazda is using a new synthetic clean-diesel fuel that is refined from fats left over from chicken, pork and beef processing.
lead_paragraph: When the Grand-Am racing organization created the GX class of competition for alternative-fuel cars, its official supplier, Sunoco, was not ready with a suitable diesel blend. So Mazda’s motor sports managers, mindful that the 2013 season kickoff was quickly approaching, decided to try a synthetic clean-diesel fuel that has powered naval vessels, aircraft, heavy trucks — and has been tested in rental fleets in the United States.

headline: Human Sounds, Painful or Haunting

lead_paragraph: Within the contemporary-music scene of New York, the vocal ensemble Ekmeles inhabits its own neighborhood on the border between music and linguistics. The name of this ensemble, which is dedicated to music by living composers, refers to the Greek term for notes of indefinite pitch and intervals with complex ratios that destabilize the perfect proportions of harmony theory, elements that in ancient Greece were considered inappropriate for music.

headline: Looking to Israel for Clues on Women in Combat
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Although on paper the Israeli military is one of the most gender-neutral in the world, the reality is more complicated.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — One of her fellow soldiers lay dead, and her Humvee was being fired upon. She saw one of the attackers — three armed men who had penetrated Israel’s border with Egypt — reach toward his waist. Fearing he was about to detonate a suicide belt, she fired two shots at his head.

lead_paragraph: “Down on its luck” was how John M. Weiss, the deputy counsel for the Landmarks Preservation Commission, described the derelict hulk of 502 Canal Street in Lower Manhattan in November after flooding from Hurricane Sandy prompted the Buildings Department to bar entry.

headline: Fox Says Its 3-Year Relationship With Palin Is Over
abstract: A Fox spokeswoman confirmed Friday that Fox had parted ways with the former Alaska governor and Republican vice presidential nominee, effectively reducing her exposure to the channel’s millions of viewers.
lead_paragraph: “Sarah, where are you?” one of Sarah Palin’s 3.4 million Facebook fans wrote on her wall last week. “Has your contract with Fox ended?” another fan asked the day before.

headline: A 17th-Century Masterpiece Discovered at the Ritz in Paris
abstract: A painting by Charles Le Brun, one of the masters of 17th-century French art, hung for decades at the Hôtel Ritz Paris before art experts recently recognized it for what it was, the auction house Christie’s announced.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – The Hôtel Ritz Paris, famous for its bar, its swimming pool and its assignations, had a treasure hiding in plain sight, an exceptional painting that had been hanging on a wall for decades without anyone paying it the least attention.

headline: ‘Most Israelis Are Not Listening’
abstract: “The Gatekeepers,” an Israeli documentary about the occupation of the Palestinian territories, has captured the attention of the world, but not that of its most relevant audience.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Oscar-nominated documentary “The Gatekeepers” braids the recollections and reflections of six former chiefs of the Shin Bet, Israel’s internal security service, into a disturbing narrative of their country’s occupation of the Palestinian territories since 1967. In the United States the confessions of these tough terrorist hunters have startled and provoked audiences, fueling the criticism among Jewish liberals of the right-leaning Israeli government’s expansion of settlements in the West Bank.

headline: Officials in Azerbaijan Claim to Restore Order to Rioting City
abstract: Despite the claim, residents of the city of Ismayilli said it remained on the brink of martial law after two days of protests, a rare explosion of uncontrolled frustration in the country.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Officials of the ruling party in Azerbaijan said on Friday that the police had restored order in the city of Ismayilli after two days of rioting and calls for the local governor to resign. Local residents, however, said the police were still making arrests and the city remained on the brink of martial law.

headline: Amid a Shake-Up, JPMorgan’s Risk Officer Takes a Leave
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: JPMorgan Chase’s chief risk officer is taking a temporary sabbatical, the latest move in an extensive reshuffling of JPMorgan’s executive suite after a botched credit bet that has cost the bank more than $6 billion.

lead_paragraph: Think it’s expensive to buy a home in New York? Try moving to China.

headline: Jan. 27 — Feb. 2
abstract: A selection of cultural events this week.
lead_paragraph: “The rain in Spain stays mainly in the plain” has been replaced by “pahk yah cah in Hahvahd Yahd.” And a gender switch has rendered Henry Higgins a Hannah and Eliza Doolittle an Elliot. But “The Makeover,” a “Hallmark Hall of Fame” production on Sunday at 9 p.m. on ABC, retains the bone structure of George Bernard Shaw’s “Pygmalion,” in which a professor of phonetics wagers that he can train a Cockney flower girl to pass as a duchess by way of proper speech and manners. Set in contemporary Boston, “The Makeover” updates the tale, with Higgins (played by Julia Stiles) as an educational consultant and grammar stickler who decides, after a failed run for Congress, to transform an unkempt beer salesman (David Walton) into the perfect candidate. But she has to subdue that South Side accent before Washington can be conquered — or love pursued. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

headline: Madison Avenue Reveals More of Its Super Bowl Playbook
abstract: Nine marketers that are buying commercial time unveiled their plans for the game, which will be broadcast by CBS on Feb. 3.
lead_paragraph: Super Bowl XLVII is now only IX — er, um, make that nine — days away, and the closer the game draws, the more information Super Bowl sponsors are sharing about their plans.

abstract: Mr. Korab, a leading architectural photographer, died Jan. 15 in Royal Oak, Mich. He was 86.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Korab, a leading architectural photographer, died Jan. 15 in Royal Oak, Mich. He was 86.

headline: For Sotomayor, Bronx School’s Closing Prompts Heartache — and Memories
abstract: Justice Sonia Sotomayor recalled a lesson that she learned, painfully, at Blessed Sacrament School on the obligation to think about people in need.
lead_paragraph: The planned closing of Blessed Sacrament School in the Bronx – a haven amid the housing projects in the Soundview neighborhood – has left many parents and graduates upset. That includes the valedictorian of the Class of 1968, who grew up in the projects that now bear her name: Sonia Sotomayor, associate justice of the United States Supreme Court.

headline: Any Engine You Like, but Only if It’s a Hybrid
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)']
abstract: For the C-Max, Ford Motor looked to Europe, where small cars are accepted realities of life. Then the company went “all California,” making the car only a hybrid model.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, CALIF. — For many Americans, the basic compact car stands as a matter of sacrifice — to financial constraints, to fuel economy demands, to the exigencies of urban crowding. But what if the design of small cars could be reformulated to transcend their size?

headline: Merry Old Efficiency
abstract: The candy dish of details on each tower of Tudor City, on the far East Side of Manhattan, proves that a master-planned complex doesn’t have to be bland — and can even live up to its English name.
lead_paragraph: Free-associate on “older middle-class housing” and “New York City,” and an image most likely comes to mind of a cluster of redbrick buildings indistinguishable from one another.

headline: A New U.S. Racing Season Opens With the Rolex 24
abstract: The Rolex 24 endurance race roars off the grid at Daytona International Speedway in Florida at 3:30 p.m. Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The off-season hibernation of racing fans is about to end. At 3:30 p.m. Saturday, the Rolex 24 endurance race roars off the grid at Daytona International Speedway in Florida. This weekend’s race will be the event’s 51st year since the founder of Nascar, Bill France, decided to give the Sebring 12-hour race some competition in 1962.

abstract: Some new places mimic New York style.
lead_paragraph: Some new places mimic New York style.

headline: Big Ticket |  $13.575 Million in a Glass Tower
abstract: The sale of a three-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath apartment with a 750-square-foot terrace and a wall of windows directed toward Central Park was the most expensive transaction of the week.
lead_paragraph: The turnover at One Beacon Court, the glassy spike of condominiums anchored by the Bloomberg L.P. headquarters on the site of the former Alexander’s department store, has continued unabated, and so has the escalation of prices, making the $13.575 million sale of a three-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath unit on the 32nd floor the most expensive transaction of the week, according to city records.

headline: Miami’s Design District Looks for an Upgrade
abstract: Those who have recently set up shop on Northeast 40th Street, the neighborhood’s chief commercial thoroughfare, include Prada, Hermès, Cartier, Céline, Agnona, and Louis Vuitton.
lead_paragraph: Those who have recently set up shop on Northeast 40th Street, the neighborhood’s chief commercial thoroughfare, include Prada, Hermès, Cartier, Céline, Agnona, and Louis Vuitton.

headline: Street-Level Views of Protests in Cairo to Commemorate 2 Years of Revolution
abstract: During demonstrations in Cairo to commemorate the second anniversary of the Egyptian revolution, activists, bloggers and journalists shared street-level views of protests as they unfolded.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of protesters remained in Cairo’s Tahrir Square late Friday despite thick clouds of tear gas, after a day of nationwide demonstrations on the second anniversary of the revolution that toppled President Hosni Mubarak.

keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Foreign Investments', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Luxury Goods', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: A proposed $312 million renovation is expected to transform the Design District into an ultra-high-end retail destination within a year or two.
lead_paragraph: As parties go, it was pure spectacle. The celebrity-heavy crowd at the Moore Building, a landmark in Miami’s Design District, was celebrating the opening of Dior Homme nearby, swaying to electro-pop, rubbing shoulders with the likes of Pharrell Williams, Martha Stewart and Calvin Klein, and oozing like a lava spill into the street.

headline: South Beach Without the Beach
abstract: A local crowd not interested in velvet ropes now has restaurants and bars to call its own in South Beach, a neighborhood better known for its weekend warriors.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH — The Freehand, a new designer hostel in South Beach, seems antithetical to its ZIP code. Bunk beds in shared rooms go for around $50 a night, the lobby is full of young visitors with laptops and the garden serves barbecued goat tacos on weekends.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Match.com  Lawsuit, and Berners-Lee in Davos
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Friday, selections include a woman’s lawsuit against an online dating service that matched her with a man who later assaulted her, Yahoo’s chief executive talking about feeding information from the Web to mobile devices, and an Internet pioneer discussing sharing more information online.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

lead_paragraph: The artist Julie Green paints the last meals of death row inmates on plates.

headline: Brooklyn Artisans and Police History
abstract: Books on a New York City borough where craftsmanship lives, the making of the subway map and vintage photos of the city’s police force.
lead_paragraph: “Brooklyn is not a place that lost touch with the art of making,” Eric Demby — a founder of the Brooklyn Flea — writes in “Brooklyn Makers” (Princeton Architectural Press, $24.95), in which Jennifer Causey, a photographer, goes on to invitingly redeem the book’s subtitle, “Food, Design, Craft and Other Scenes From the Tactile Life.”

headline: Dish by Dish, Art of Last Meals
abstract: Ice water, pickles, a cigarette and a soda — these are some of death row inmates’ final choices, documented on plates by Julie Green in her project “The Last Supper.”
lead_paragraph: CORVALLIS, Ore. — One man wanted only ice water as his last meal before execution. Another asked that his mother be allowed into the prison kitchen to make the chicken dumplings he loved. Another told the guards he had never had a birthday cake, so they bought him one, along with his formal last-meal request, a pizza. Some asked for nothing, or nothing special — a regular prison dinner, food from the vending machines, a cigarette and a soda.

headline: Leaving the Cage to Crash the Multiplex
abstract: Mixed martial arts champions are trying to breaking into cinema through low-budget fight films.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2006 Ken Chamitoff was traveling around the United States for his company, which takes photographs at martial arts studios. In Bellingham, Wash., about halfway through a three-and-a-half-month stint on the road, the unending days of being away from his family and living in hotel rooms got to him.

lead_paragraph: The Pentagon’s decision to allow women into combat has set off new debate on whether women can perform the same dangerous and physically demanding tasks as ground combat units do, day in and day out.

The Duke of Windsor had died in May, and Ms. Vreeland thought his wardrobe would make a superb focus for her debut as special consultant to the Met event.

headline: Let’s Get This Party Started
abstract: Party games are a tricky business, and it takes a sensitive host to determine when to introduce a game and what it should be.
lead_paragraph: Initiating party games is a delicate business. “I hate it when hosts say, ‘We’re going to play games now!’ ” the comedian Amy Sedaris said. “It takes you out of the circulation of the party. And most of the people know all the tricks to the games, so I’ll feel like a loser.”

headline: In Bronx, a Beach That Moses Built
abstract: Among the highlights of Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx are Orchard Beach and the Bartow-Pell Mansion.
lead_paragraph: The weather last week may have sent some New Yorkers scrambling for Florida. But if you’re more of a Yankee at heart, then a winter walk along Orchard Beach in Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx might just be your scene. On summer weekends, thousands of visitors flock here; in the cold weather, you would be lucky to see a few hardy souls enjoying the crescent beach and unpeopled views of City Island, Pelham Bay and Long Island Sound.

headline: Even Big Stars Like to Be Juvenile
abstract: “Movie 43” is a potpourri of off-color, politically incorrect and potentially offensive vignettes made by big-name stars and directors.
lead_paragraph: The kindest thing to be said of “Movie 43,” a star-saturated collection of crude one-joke vignettes made with big-time directors, is that most of the participants seem to relish being naughty. What binds these skits in a format that leads from one to the next with no connective tissue is the occasional presence of Dennis Quaid as a crazy, down-on-his-luck filmmaker who has wangled his way into the office of a timid midlevel studio executive (Greg Kinnear) to sell the project.

headline: A Right to Unlock Cellphones Fades Away
abstract: Your right to unlock your cellphone is about to expire. Cellphone carriers say this is for your own good — and theirs. Unlocking a cellphone enables it to work on a wireless carrier other than the one you bought it from.
lead_paragraph: Your right to unlock your cellphone is about to expire. Cellphone carriers say this is for your own good — and theirs.

headline: A ‘Black Bloc’ Emerges in Egypt
abstract: Some protesters dressed from head to toe in black, covered their faces with bandannas or kerchiefs and brandished black flags as they skirmished with security forces.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Saturday, 10:17 a.m. While using Twitter to narrate events in Tahrir Square on Friday, people in Egypt described tires burning in the street, protesters blocking traffic and hurling rocks, and police officers launching tear gas in an effort to break up crowds that had gathered to protest against the Muslim Brotherhood and the country’s new Islamist president.

headline: Could Rodriguez Miss Season? Yes. Is It Likely? No, Cashman Says
abstract: A minor furor erupted Friday after Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman said in a radio interview on WFAN that it was possible Alex Rodriguez could miss the entire season, which is true. But it is not the expected outcome, he said.
lead_paragraph: Brian Cashman, the Yankees’ general manager, said it was “not likely” that Alex Rodriguez would miss the 2013 season because of his hip surgery.

abstract: As Brazil and Argentina lose some of their luster, are sub-Saharan African nations on the rise? Billionaire dealmakers want to know.
lead_paragraph: Some of the global elite gathered at Davos this year are draping South African scarves on their shoulders and wrapping their iPads with cozies provided by businesses in Peru. It was hardly a new fashion trend, but it was a sign of the latest wave of up-and-coming, fast-growing countries determined to show the world that they have arrived — or badly want to.

abstract: Nancy and Steve Potter met on a commune and now live on their own farm, where they enjoy the hard work. And each other.
lead_paragraph: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Somalia: Twitter Shuts Rebels’ Account
abstract: The Twitter account of the Shabab militant group in Somalia, which used to trumpet the group’s battlefield prowess and once had thousands of followers, has been shut down.
lead_paragraph: The Twitter account of the Shabab militant group in Somalia, which used to trumpet the group’s battlefield prowess and once had thousands of followers, has been shut down. “Account suspended,” read a message on Twitter’s Web site on Friday. American officials had been looking closely at the Shabab’s use of Twitter, saying that it could be a potential recruiting tool. The Shabab recently sent out a Twitter message vowing to kill Kenyan hostages if the Kenyan government did not meet its demands. Shabab fighters, who used to control large areas of Somalia, have been routed in recent months by African Union peacekeepers.
