headline: Britain: A Bill for Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Marriages']
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron’s government on Friday published a bill to legalize same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister David Cameron’s government on Friday published a bill to legalize same-sex marriage. The bill will begin its passage through Parliament next month and is expected to become law by midsummer. “We feel that marriage is a good thing, and we should be supporting more couples to marry,” said Maria Miller, the Conservative Party’s culture minister. The bill will allow same-sex couples who have formed a civil partnership (legal since 2004, with legal rights equivalent to those of marriage) to convert the partnerships to marriage, and enable married people to change their legal gender without having to end their union. The Church of England has raised concerns that it could be forced to conduct same-sex marriages against its will, but Ms. Miller said the bill would exempt clergy who have a conscientious objection from having to carry out the ceremonies.

headline: An Opening Argument in DePuy Hip Case
abstract: An artificial hip being sold by Johnson & Johnson had such serious design flaws that even its consultants were urging the company to stop selling it, according to a lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: An artificial hip being sold by Johnson & Johnson had such serious design flaws that even its consultants were urging the company to stop selling it, according to a lawsuit.

headline: A Twist on Grimm: It’s the Witches Who are Hunted
abstract: Hansel and Gretel, all grown up and perhaps traumatized by their childhood, use their fury against their captor to help others.
lead_paragraph: Between the vampire fad and the zombie fad, we haven’t been giving nearly enough attention lately to this planet’s witch problem, so it’s good to see the Norwegian director Tommy Wirkola put the issue back in the public eye with “Hansel & Gretel: Witch Hunters.” It may not stay in the public eye long because this movie is probably not going to put up “Twilight”-like numbers, but, hey, you have to admire the against-the-grain effort.

headline: Obama Heaps Praise on Hillary Clinton in Joint Appearance
abstract: In a rare joint interview on “60 Minutes,” President Obama lavishly praised his departing secretary of state. Some saw it as a thumb on the scales of the 2016 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: President Obama said in an interview shown Friday night that Hillary Rodham Clinton, his bitter rival for the Democratic nomination five years ago, “will go down as one of the finest secretary of states we’ve had” and added that he would “miss her” once she steps down in the coming days.

headline: Ogling Two International Men of Mystery
abstract: The men in the Bollywood “Race 2” are toned, dressed-up blanks, pulled out of the drawer marked International Man of Mystery.
lead_paragraph: “Race 2,” a Bollywood thriller set mostly in Turkey, has so much plot that it takes time out at the beginning to sketch in some details. As a portentous voice-over intones, we watch images of the characters on their yachts and in their fancy cars, their beautifully tailored suits straining to contain their meaty gym bodies.

headline: Alfa Anticipation Once Again
abstract: Over the years, Alfa Romeo has said it was returning to the United States, but it never did. This time the company seems to mean it, with plans to sell the 4C sports coupe here in the fall.
lead_paragraph: Alfa Romeo’s ever-shifting plans for a return to the North American market, which it left in 1995 after decades of pitiful sales, poor reliability and strained dealer relations, form a boulevard of broken dreams. The latest blueprint for Alfa’s American resurrection calls for sales of the coming 4C sports coupe, a 2014 model, to begin here in the fall.

headline: Maker Hid Data About Design Flaw in Hip Implant, Records Show
abstract: Johnson & Johnson executives were aware that an artificial hip had a critical design flaw years before it was recalled, but concealed that information, according to documents disclosed at a trial.
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson executives knew years before they recalled a troubled artificial hip in 2010 that it had a critical design flaw, but the company concealed that information from physicians and patients, according to internal documents disclosed on Friday during a trial related to the device’s failure.

headline: ‘Propaganda’ by Gays Faces Russian Curbs Amid Unrest
abstract: Police arrested about 20 people as attackers hurled eggs and paint at gay rights advocates who gathered in Moscow to protest a bill that outlaws “homosexual propaganda.”
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — While Russian lawmakers debated a bill that would outlaw “homosexual propaganda,” nationalist and religious demonstrators on Friday attacked gay rights advocates who had gathered outside the lower house of Parliament to protest the legislation.

headline: A Steady Ascent
abstract: The S. & P. 500 has recently been approaching levels close to its 2007 peak.
lead_paragraph: The S. & P. 500 has recently been approaching levels close to its 2007 peak.

headline: A Living Presence, Not on Disc
abstract: The pianist Radu Lupu performed in a recital at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: Since the pianist Radu Lupu has not made a new album since the 1990s, his record label has been forced to peddle endless reissues and repackagings of his visionary takes on the German and Austrian masters. A movement from one of his Mozart piano concertos is included in a 2005 compilation called “For the Discriminating Man.”

headline: Harder to Run 50 Years Later
abstract: Yvonne Rainer, a founder of the experimental collective Judson Dance Theater, revives a 50-year-old piece from the Judson era, and two newer works that reflect on age.
lead_paragraph: Judson Now, Danspace Project’s series celebrating the 50th anniversary of the first concerts by the experimental collective Judson Dance Theater, ended in December. But on Thursday it got a coda, the rescheduling of a program that had been canceled because of Hurricane Sandy. The program was Yvonne Rainer’s, and Ms. Rainer cannot be skipped.

headline: A Long Line Marching to War, and Sometimes From It
abstract: “The Steadfast,” written by Mat Smart and directed by Wes Grantom, tells stories of soldiers from eight eras in American history.
lead_paragraph: In one of the longer, more ornate speeches in “The Steadfast” — Mat Smart’s snapshots of the American military, from the Revolutionary War to Afghanistan — a Union soldier (John Behlmann) explains why he deserted by acting out a fictional dialogue with Abraham Lincoln.

headline: Poetry, Puppets and Playgrounds
abstract: Tracy K. Smith, last year’s winner of the Pulitzer Prize for Poetry, spends Sundays with her husband and daughter, and devotes some time to writing.
lead_paragraph: For Tracy K. Smith, last year’s winner of the Pulitzer Prize for Poetry, Sunday is a family day. “I travel a lot during the week, teaching and doing readings,” said Ms. Smith, whose award-winning collection, “Life on Mars,” included a villanelle about geese being gassed at Kennedy Airport. “So it’s nice to keep Sundays fairly local.” An assistant professor of creative writing at Princeton University, Ms. Smith, 40, lives in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, with her husband, Raphael (or Raf) Allison, 42, an assistant professor of literature at Bard College; their 3-year-old daughter, Naomi; and their dog, Shaba, a Rhodesian Ridgeback and pit bull mix.

headline: Work With China, Don’t Contain It
abstract: Asia’s internal balance of power should be the key to our strategy.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

headline: Flights of Imagination That Soar Too Close to the Sun
abstract: Arturo Vidich considers the difficult birth of any creative work in “The Daedalus Effect and other dilemmas,” at the Invisible Dog Art Center in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: To understand “The Daedalus Effect and other dilemmas,” Arturo Vidich’s latest work — an opaque look at technology and the birth of any creation — it doesn’t hurt to brush up on a little Greek mythology. Daedalus, a master craftsman, created the labyrinth for the Minotaur. Icarus, Daedalus’s son, flew too close to the sun, wearing wings his father had fashioned from feathers and wax. The design was flawed; the wax melted. He fell into the sea.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
abstract: Questions about subway gratings in Brooklyn and the first motorized buses in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Q. I recently moved to Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, and started noticing concrete barriers surrounding subway gratings all over the neighborhood. There is no uniformity to them — some are ankle high, some are waist high. They’ve become great impromptu garbage dumps. What are they protecting? Why did the M.T.A. build them here but (presumably) nowhere else in the city?

headline: Grand Overtures, Dances and Romantic Concertos
abstract: Lola Astanova was the soloist on Wednesday in a program of concertos by Tchaikovsky and Rachmaninoff, and works by Suppé and Smetana.
lead_paragraph: Performing Tchaikovsky’s Piano Concerto No. 1 and Rachmaninoff’s Piano Concerto No. 2 on the same evening requires athletic stamina. But if a pianist lacks the muscle to complete the race, it becomes an endurance test for both soloist and listeners.

headline: At Gay Conference, Applause for Obama Is Spirited but Wary
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexual', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Leaders of the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force assured members that they would keep the pressure on the president to do more on gay rights.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Here at the nation’s largest gathering of politically minded gays and lesbians, President Obama’s historic inclusion of sexual orientation in his inauguration speech just days earlier would seem to be cause for celebration.

headline: France: Striking a Blow for the Mother Tongue
abstract: France has decreed that Twitter-using citizens should refrain from using the word “hashtag” in favor of the newly coined French term “mot-dièse.”
lead_paragraph: In its determined if quixotic mission to keep the French language French — that is, to keep out the English language, which creeps in more each day — France has decreed that Twitter-using citizens should refrain from using the word “hashtag” in favor of the newly coined French term “mot-dièse.” The new term, which effectively means “hashtag-word,” was developed by a government committee on vocabulary and published this week in the Journal Officiel, where laws and government rules are recorded. Linguistic purists have noted that “dièse” is, in fact, a musical term meaning “sharp symbol” and that the word “croisillon,” which means “hash symbol,” might have been a better choice. In any case, for the moment French Twitter users still “tweet” — “tweeter” in French (pronounced “twee-tay”) — when they post messages to the service. Many have been posting snarky notes about the new word under the hashtag “#motdièse.”

headline: It Has Been Frigid Outside, but Also a Lot Less Dangerous
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Temperature', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Weather', 'Crime Rates']
abstract: As of Friday morning, New York City had been murder-free for nine days.
lead_paragraph: It’s an old saw that murders spike during hot summers, when city dwellers flee their apartments for the streets and tempers soar along with the mercury. Less, however, has been said about the effect of extreme cold spells on mankind’s capacity for violent crimes.

headline: Norway: 3 Missing Gas Workers Confirmed Dead in Algeria
abstract: The energy giant Statoil on Friday confirmed the deaths of three of the company’s five employees who had been missing since Islamist militants attacked a gas installation in Algeria last week.
lead_paragraph: The energy giant Statoil on Friday confirmed the deaths of three of the company’s five employees who had been missing since Islamist militants attacked a gas installation in Algeria last week. Statoil’s chief executive officer, Helge Lund, said the three workers were Tore Bech, 58; Thomas Snekkevik, 35; and Hans M. Bjone, 55. Few hold out more than the slimmest hopes for the remaining two. The company offered no details about the circumstances of their deaths.

headline: Germany: Funds for Global Health Fund Reinstated
abstract: Germany announced on Thursday that it would reinstate the annual pledge of 200 million euros to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria.
lead_paragraph: Signaling that it was pleased with changes in the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, Germany announced Thursday that it would reinstate the annual pledge of 200 million euros (about $267 million) it had made since the fund’s early days. In 2011, Germany temporarily held back half its contribution and threatened to hold back future funds in protest against inefficiencies, thefts by some grantee countries and infighting among the fund’s top executives. Other contributions dried up, forcing the fund to cancel a planned round of grants. Since then, both the fund’s executive director and inspector general have departed, and it was run for one year by a Brazilian banker; he devised an overhaul of the grant-making process that is to take effect next month. In November, Dr. Mark Dybul, the Bush administration’s global AIDS czar, became the new executive director. The fund recently announced that it cut its operating expenses by 5 percent in 2012 while still making 26 percent more in grants than it did in 2011. Of the grants that had been audited, Dr. Dybul said, only 0.5 percent had been lost to fraud. The fund plans a new fund-raising round for later this year. The United States is the fund’s largest supporter, providing roughly a third of its budget.

headline: The Holmes Behind the Modern Sherlock
abstract: “The Seven-Per-Cent Solution” by Nicholas Meyer provided the template for the sensitive, neurotic Sherlock Holmeses of today’s films and television.
lead_paragraph: We’re lousy with Sherlock Holmeses right now: the Robert Downey Jr. version on the big screen, the competing television interpretations of Benedict Cumberbatch (“Sherlock”) and Jonny Lee Miller (“Elementary”) and all the Holmes-inspired geniuses in current and recent TV shows like “The Mentalist,” “Psych,” “House” and “Monk.” So “The Seven-Per-Cent Solution,” released this week in a new Blu-ray and DVD package, enters a crowded market.

headline: Skills Honed When the River Was Still the Highway
abstract: The Arts Exchange presents a multimedia exploration of the construction of watercraft along the Hudson River and the north and south shores of Long Island Sound.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — It is easy to imagine a brisk breeze blowing and lapping water buoying the wooden boats that fill the gallery of ArtsWestchester’s Arts Exchange as part of “From Shore to Shore: Boat Builders and Boatyards of Westchester and Long Island.” The exhibition presents a multimedia exploration of boat building in the region. It includes a 15-foot-long illustrated timeline, graphic panels, videos, models and half-models and a selection of well-worn tools. Interspersed are actual boats — a flat-bottom fishing skiff, a couple of rowing boats, six handcrafted kayaks and a 16-foot melonseed catboat, its single gaff-rigged sail unfurled.

headline: A Tenor With ‘Breath and Imagination’
abstract: A musical at Hartford Stage tells the story of the tenor Roland Hayes, the first African-American vocalist to receive international acclaim.
lead_paragraph: THE HEADLINE ON an unsigned music review from 1929 in The New York Times was unequivocal: “Roland Hayes, Tenor, Delights a Throng: Carnegie Hall Audience Hears Him in Meticulous Refinement of Style.” The critic praised the program of arias, art songs and spirituals and compared Hayes’s phrasing to “the delicacy of a cameo”; what’s more, the singer was so famous that the reviewer did not feel it necessary to mention the most extraordinary aspect of the concert: Roland Hayes, tenor, who had toured Europe and sung for royalty, was a black man, born in rural Georgia to a former slave.

headline: More Evidence of a Severe Flu Season
abstract: Death rates from flu and pneumonia have soared well above those of the last few years, confirming that this will be a fairly severe flu season.
lead_paragraph: Death rates from flu and pneumonia have soared well above those of the last few years, confirming that this will be a fairly severe flu season, figures released Friday by federal health officials show. At the same time, new infections with influenza continued to fall, suggesting that the season has peaked almost everywhere in the country except in the far West. Because so many of those hospitalized and dying from the flu are geriatric patients, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued guidelines to doctors who care for older patients, suggesting giving high-dose flu shots to the elderly and starting antiflu drugs as soon as an infection is suspected.

headline: As Her Old School Faces the End, a Justice Reminisces

lead_paragraph: The planned closing of Blessed Sacrament School in the Bronx — a haven amid the housing projects in the Soundview neighborhood — has left many parents and graduates upset. That includes the valedictorian of the class of 1968, who grew up in the projects that now bear her name: Sonia Sotomayor, associate justice of the United States Supreme Court.

headline: A Court Upholds Republican Chicanery
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Using phony Senate sessions, lawmakers tried to keep two federal agencies from operating.
lead_paragraph: For most of President Obama’s first term, Republicans used legislative trickery to try to prevent the functioning of two federal agencies they hate, the National Labor Relations Board and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. First they would filibuster the president’s nominees to the agencies, knowing that neither agency could operate without board members or a director. Then they would create fake legislative sessions for the Senate during its recess, intended solely to prevent Mr. Obama from making recess appointments as an end run.

headline: In Tennis, Gamesmanship Is the Norm
abstract: To some observers, Victoria Azarenka’s injury timeout at a pivotal point in her match against Sloane Stephens was an unusual and troubling tactic.
lead_paragraph: Gardnar Mulloy could hardly believe his eyes. Watching the Australian Open semifinal between Victoria Azarenka and Sloane Stephens on television, the 99-year-old Mulloy suddenly found himself screaming at what he described as “an atrocity, the worst thing I’ve ever seen” in a tennis match.

headline: When Police Violate the Constitution
abstract: A federal judge assails the New York City Police Department’s stop-and-frisk program for its flagrant indifference to the Fourth Amendment.
lead_paragraph: The federal courts are bearing down on the New York City Police Department’s constitutionally suspect stop-and-frisk program, under which hundreds of thousands of citizens are stopped on the streets each year, often illegally and for no discernible reason. Earlier this month, the federal judge who is presiding over three lawsuits that challenge different parts of the program issued her harshest ruling yet, putting the city on notice that some aspects of stop and frisk are clearly unconstitutional.

headline: Wisconsin: Sheriff Makes a Pitch for Gun Training
abstract: Sheriff David A. Clarke Jr. of Milwaukee County issued a radio message suggesting that residents consider how to protect themselves from crime, including firearm training.
lead_paragraph: Sheriff David A. Clarke Jr. of Milwaukee County has issued a radio message suggesting that residents consider how to protect themselves from crime, including, perhaps, firearm training. “With officers laid off and furloughed, simply calling 911 and waiting is no longer your best option,” the sheriff said in the recording, one installment in the periodic public service messages he issues. “You could beg for mercy from a violent criminal, hide under the bed, or you can fight back,” he said, later suggesting that residents consider taking a certified course in firearm safety. Sheriff Clarke said in an interview that his office has faced budget cuts in recent years and that he meant his message merely to encourage safety and personal responsibility. “I wouldn’t tell people to go get a gun,” Sheriff Clarke said. “I wouldn’t tell them not to go get a gun.”

headline: Texas: Lawsuit Permitted Over Immigration Policy
keywords: ['Deportation', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Suits and Litigation', 'Illegal Immigrants']
abstract: A federal judge in Dallas ruled that a group of federal immigration agents can proceed with a lawsuit that seeks to halt an Obama administration program.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Dallas has ruled that a group of federal immigration agents can proceed with a lawsuit that seeks to halt an Obama administration program granting reprieves from deportation to young illegal immigrants. In a suit filed in August, several Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents argued that the administration had exceeded its constitutional authority in granting the reprieves, and said they were being forced to violate the law by obeying instructions to refrain from deporting the young immigrants. Judge Reed O’Connor rejected a Justice Department request to dismiss the case.

headline: Fascination With a Medium, and the Lives of Women
abstract: “In the Company of Women: Prints by Mary Cassatt,” an exhibition at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum in New Brunswick, runs through March 3.
lead_paragraph: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — In an 1890 letter famous among scholars of the period, Mary Cassatt urged the painter Berthe Morisot, her friend, “You must see the Japanese — come as soon as you can.” The Japanese she was referring to was an exhibition of 725 woodblock prints and albums at the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris. But Cassatt was writing from a particular perspective: she was obsessed with prints and printmaking. “In the Company of Women: Prints by Mary Cassatt,” an exhibition of 23 prints at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum here, offers a snapshot of Cassatt’s engagement with the medium.

headline: Hope, and Lessons, in Somalia
abstract: The country’s positive evolution may offer some cautionary advice for the fight against militants in Mali.
lead_paragraph: Somalia has been the paradigm of failed states since before 1993, when militants shot down two Black Hawk helicopters and killed 18 American soldiers in Mogadishu. One of the world’s poorest, most violent countries, it has been pummeled by warring militias, famine and pirates. But the country recently has shown enough positive movement that the Obama administration last week hosted President Hassan Sheikh Mohamud in Washington and recognized Somalia’s government for the first time in more than two decades. The evolution is worth examining as the West tries to grapple with militants in Mali.

headline: A Spanish Theme That Seems to Fit Just Right

lead_paragraph: Bistro Latino is the third name for Rafael Palomino’s restaurant on the Post Road in Old Greenwich, and this time he seems to have gotten it right. It began as Palomino, became Greenwich Tavern and was recently transformed into this Spanish-South American place. Considering that Señor Palomino himself is from Colombia, the Latin American theme would seem to be a natural fit. When I asked Moe Gad, his partner, about the significance of the new name, he said: “Bistro Latino was the name of Chef Palomino’s first cookbook in 1996. It’s like returning to our roots.”

headline: A Cost Cut, on the Backs of Children
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Foster Care', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Juvenile Delinquency']
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo pulled financing for a group that gives a voice to New York minors caught in the court system.
lead_paragraph: In 1853, Charles Loring Brace, a patrician reformer, devised a plan to remediate the circumstances of New York City’s 30,000 homeless children, many of whom passed their days as desperate salesmen hawking rags and newspapers, and who had acquired the label, absent a world of ethnic sensitivities, of “street Arabs.” Founding the Children’s Aid Society, Brace controversially arranged for abandoned children to be sent, by rail, to farm families — “kind, Christian homes in the country” as he put it, typically where they would work. By 1929, approximately 100,000 city children had been relocated across the country, often with no sense of where they would be going, in what became known as the Orphan Train movement and was the precursor to the American foster care system.

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Sundance) SECRETARY (2002) Maggie Gyllenhaal, right, portrays Lee Holloway, a repressed young secretary with masochistic tendencies and a stint in a mental hospital who blossoms during spanking sessions with her boss, E. Edward Grey (James Spader), a grim lawyer who prefers the typewriter to the computer. Spelling mistakes result in corporal punishment, and soon Edward, like a cruel Pygmalion, is telling Lee how to dress, answer the telephone and even eat. But his instructions help shape and direct her life — and his advances set her aflame. “Secretary,” directed by Steven Shainberg and adapted by Erin Cressida Wilson from a novella by Mary Gaitskill, could be seen “as a slap in the face to orthodox feminist thinking, since the concept of sexual harassment doesn’t seem to occur to anybody.” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “I prefer to see ‘Secretary’ as a wacky new-wave romantic comedy in which two lonely people locked inside their private fantasies discover a miraculous erotic harmony. In today’s post-Freudian, do-your-own-thing era of free sexual expression, the movie stands to be a wholesome self-help fable about the unlocking of shame and its magical transformation into pleasure and personal liberation. So what if its vision is finally too good to be true?”

headline: Jihadists and Secular Activists Clash in Syria

A growing contingent of jihadist fighters from the ideologically extreme and militarily formidable Nusra Front was suspicious of the activists’ secular, nonviolent agenda.

headline: Enjoying Snow, While We Still Have It
abstract: Scientists warn that future winters may be less white.
lead_paragraph: SNOW was my first love. From November’s first flakes and the season’s first blizzard, to unexpected midnight dustings and late March blasts, snow fell frequently and happily on my childhood in western Massachusetts. I never complained about the unshoveled, post-blizzard darkness of my paper route, nor about scrambling over icy drifts en route to school. In the evenings I read in front of our wood stove, captivated by thoughts of Narnia’s endless winter.

headline: A Back-Seat Narrator by the Name of Ishmael
abstract: By Oklahoma, we felt as if we had approached some metaphysical border.
lead_paragraph: Is there a stranger figure in American literature than the narrator of “Moby-Dick”? He says, “Call me Ishmael” — the very first words of the book — but that isn’t exactly the same as saying “My name is Ishmael.” He could be anyone, of any name, but Ishmael is what the reader must agree to call him before the book can get under way. I recently drove with a friend from my farm in New York State to Southern California, and Ishmael was our companion. We picked him up, so to speak, on the dark, icy streets of New Bedford, round about 1851, and delivered him within sight of what he calls “your contemplative Pacific,” ageless as always.

abstract: The Mexico City government removed a large statue of a former president of Azerbaijan from a central boulevard early Saturday, giving in after months of complaints by critics.
lead_paragraph: The Mexico City government removed a large statue of a former president of Azerbaijan from a central boulevard early Saturday, giving in after months of complaints by critics who said that Mexico’s capital was no place for the likeness of a man accused of suppressing democracy and committing human rights abuses. City workers, accompanied by police officers, arrived shortly after midnight at the little park that Azerbaijan’s embassy had paid to renovate. They pried up the statue of Heydar Aliyev, who ruled Azerbaijan from 1993 until just before his death in 2003, and then loaded it onto a trailer and carted it off to a city warehouse. Talks are continuing with Azeri officials to find a new home for the statue. As to whether the embassy wants its money back for the park renovations, the city government’s legal director, José Ramón Amieva, told the local news media on Saturday that the city had not yet received a request for reimbursement.

lead_paragraph: Constance Elaine Howard Irons and James Kent Malernee Jr. were married Saturday on the beach at Kikaua Point in Kailua-Kona, Hawaii. The Rev. Rodney G. Aller, a minister of the United Church of Christ, led the ceremony.

headline: Deborah Williams and Matthew Dean
abstract: The bride is a doctoral candidate in the school-clinical child psychology program at Pace University; the groom is a director in the operations risk and control group at Morgan Stanley, both in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Deborah Anne Williams, the daughter of Angelina L. Williams and Randall S. Williams of Vernon, N.J., was married Saturday to Matthew Gregory Dean, the son of Kathleen McGettigan Dean and Gregory F. Dean of Potomac, Md. The Rev. Thomas J. Valenti, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

headline: Joanna Gang, Kent Sanderson
abstract: The bride works for a nonprofit organization; the groom for a film company.
lead_paragraph: Joanna Michelle Gang and Kent Edward Sanderson are to be married Sunday by Rabbi James M. Prosnit at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn.

headline: Jamie Krauss and George Hess
abstract: After a mutual friend suggested they meet, the bride took the bull by the horn.
lead_paragraph: Toasting Her ‘Yes’ With a Smoothie

headline: Ada Bryant and Robert Haire
abstract: The bride, 97, and the groom, 86, met at a retirement community in Wilmington, Del.
lead_paragraph: A Lifetime of Happiness, Part 2

headline: Emily Salas and Daniel Crowley III
abstract: The couple is married in New York.
lead_paragraph: Emily Gietl Salas, a daughter of Caroline Wilmerding Rupp of Muttontown, N.Y., and Peter E. Salas of Fernandina Beach, Fla., was married Saturday evening to Daniel Francis Crowley III, the son of Karen Williams Crowley and Mr. Crowley Jr. of Dana Point, Calif., at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. Thomas N. J. Synan, an Episcopal priest and the church’s associate rector, performed the ceremony.

headline: Erin Miller and Brent Rogol
abstract: The couple is married in New York.

headline: Emily Cooper, Adam Janvey
abstract: Dr. Emily Tamara Cooper and Adam Jonathan Janvey were married at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Emily Tamara Cooper and Adam Jonathan Janvey were married Saturday evening by Rabbi J. Rolando Matalon at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York.

headline: At Inferno Downhill, Growing Size of Event Hasn’t Spoiled Its Charm
abstract: The Inferno, one of the world’s oldest and longest downhill races, has grown from 12 competitors to 1,850 ski racers, but many of the rituals remain.
lead_paragraph: MÜRREN, Switzerland — On a sun-drenched hill overlooking the Eiger, Monch and Jungfrau peaks, 1,850 ski racers prepared Saturday to compete in the Inferno, one of the world’s oldest and longest downhill races. As they shuffled through the start house perched at 9,720 feet in the Bernese Oberland, a bottle of homemade schnapps hung in the entryway, a traditional elixir to quell prerace jitters.

headline: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
abstract: In an interview with The New Republic, President Obama expressed empathy for gun owners, and he acknowledged that it would be tough to get his proposals through Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – President Obama said that he and his guests go skeet shooting at Camp David “all the time” and that gun control advocates need “to do a little more listening” to understand why so many Americans are wary of government limits on firearms.

headline: Q. and A. With the WTA’s Stacey Allaster
abstract: On the eve of Saturday’s women’s final in Melbourne, Stacey Allaster, the chairwoman and chief executive of the Women’s Tennis Association, discussed the state of the game.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — It was a news-making Australian Open for women’s tennis with the emergence of young talent, a major upset of Serena Williams by the 19-year-old Sloane Stephens and a controversy over medical timeouts involving the eventual champion Victoria Azarenka.

headline: North Korean Leader Vows ‘High-Profile’ Retaliation Over New U.N. Sanctions
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Tests', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: North Korea did not clarify what those measures might be, but referred to earlier threats to launch more long-range rockets and conduct a third nuclear test.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, has ordered his top military and party officials to take “substantial and high-profile important state measures” to retaliate against American-led United Nations sanctions on the country, the North’s official media reported Sunday.

headline: ‘Real’ Life in North Korea
abstract: As North Korea threatens that its weapons programs will “target” the United States, a former British ambassador provides some insight into the lives of ordinary people in the North.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — With North Korea in the headlines again amid concerns it could explode a third, more powerful nuclear device, many people around the world may be wondering: What are they like?

headline: Scattered Protests in Delhi on Republic Day
abstract: Protests demanding better safety for women continue in India’s capital, but on a small scale.
lead_paragraph: Several groups of protesters marched and demonstrated in New Delhi on Saturday as India celebrated its 64th Republic Day, demanding better safety for women, a movement that started after the Dec. 16 gang rape of a young woman here.

headline: North Korea Spoils the Party
abstract: In the face of sanctions, North Korea has threatened “all-out” action on its “sworn enemy” the United States.
lead_paragraph: In the face of sanctions, North Korea has threatened “all-out” action on its “sworn enemy” the United States.

headline: The Clinton Doctrine of American Foreign Policy
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s time as secretary of state saw no major breakthroughs and few mistakes, but as she left she made the case for a new American foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: The partisan political theater, of course, was top-notch. Senator Rand Paul’s declaration that he would have fired Hillary Rodham Clinton; her angry rebuttal of Senator Ron Johnson’s insistence that the Obama administration misled the American people about the Benghazi attack; Senator John McCain’s continued outrage at the slapdash security the State Department provided its employees.

headline: In Myanmar, Sports Choices Raise Concerns
abstract: Myanmar, the host of the 2013 Southeast Asian Games, is being criticized for stacking the competition with obscure sports so that its athletes have a good chance of winning.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — It has been promoted as a showcase for the new Myanmar, a regional sporting event in December that will celebrate the country’s embrace of democracy and the end of a hermetic and oppressive era.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
abstract: Long-form articles on a leadership crisis in India and Indo-Pak relations.
lead_paragraph: As India’s rival national parties, the incumbent Congress and the principal opposition, the Bharatiya Janata Party, begin preparing for the general elections scheduled for 2014, Open Magazine’s Jatin Gandhi analyzes the country’s potential choices for prime minister: Narendra Modi, the controversial chief minister of Gujarat, who was welcomed amid feverish chants of “P.M.! P.M.!” at his party’s New Delhi office last month, and Rahul Gandhi, the 42-year-old heir apparent of the Gandhi dynasty, who took charge last week as vice president of the Congress party.

headline: App Smart Extra: On the Slopes
abstract: It’s cold outside. Here are more apps for skiers and snowboarders.
lead_paragraph: Apps that add a technological edge to your skiing or snowboarding vacation were the subject of a recent App Smart column. But the column could barely make a dent in discussing all the apps available to help winter sports enthusiasts. Here are some more suggestions.

headline: Djokovic Wears Murray Down for Australian Open Title
abstract: Novak Djokovic won a grueling final 6-7, 7-6, 6-3, 6-2 match over Andy Murray to win his third consecutive Australian Open title.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — His legs are stronger than in the past. So are his résumé, his nerves and his coaching staff. But Andy Murray still cannot solve the tennis riddle that Novak Djokovic represents at the Australian Open.

headline: Obama on Football, and Contemplating a Death on the Field
abstract: President Obama predicted that the game would gradually change to “reduce some of the violence,” and he expressed more concern about college players than those in the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: The last time President Obama weighed in on a hot topic in football, in 2008, he was stumping for a college playoff:  “If you’ve got a bunch of teams who play throughout the season, and many of them have one loss or two losses, there’s no clear decisive winner. We should be creating a playoff system.”

headline: Frenzied Scene as Toll Tops 200 in Brazil Blaze
abstract: A fire ignited by a band’s pyrotechnic spectacle swept through a nightclub full of university students early Sunday morning in Brazil, leaving at least 233 people dead.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A fire ignited by a flare from a band’s pyrotechnics spectacle swept through a nightclub filled with hundreds of university students early on Sunday morning in Santa Maria, a city in southern Brazil, killing at least 233 people, officials said.

headline: Slamdance Dispatch: Outside the Gifting Suite
abstract: The screenwriter and actress Halley Feiffer reports on her success — and lapse — at Slamdance.
lead_paragraph: All eyes were on Sundance for the last week, and the long shadow it casts can make it difficult for filmmakers at the “other” Park City, Utah, festival, Slamdance, to get their projects seen. The Carpetbagger blog asked Halley Feiffer, co-writer and star of “He’s Way More Famous Than You,” directed by Michael Urie, to share her experiences at Slamdance:

headline: ‘Argo’ Leads Producers Guild Awards
abstract: “Argo,” on a roll since the Golden Globes, won at the Producers Guild Awards as well.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — “Argo” continued its upward momentum through awards season, as Ben Affleck’s film took the top prize at the Producers Guild Awards.

headline: Foster Parenting Creates a Future, Without Erasing the Past
abstract: Adoption is not a rescue and a happy ending. My children are safer and loved now, but their losses cannot be undone.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I adopted our three children, now ages 11, 10 and 7, in October 2010 (we had to wait another nine months for our oldest daughter, the eldest of three biological siblings). We hadn’t intended to adopt this many, but we did not know how to answer the questions of desired age, sex, race and quantity on our paperwork so we left it blank, which the social workers took to mean, “We have a blank, load them up!” During our last training, we got a call that the current foster parents wanted to hand them over A.S.A.P., and we had to leave early to pick them up.

headline: With Fighters Gone, Malians Welcome Normal Days
abstract: Residents of Gao, who had been under occupation for nearly a year by Islamist fighters, celebrated the arrival of Malian and French troops.
lead_paragraph: SÉVARÉ, Mali — Residents of northern Mali’s largest city poured out of their homes to celebrate the expulsion of Islamist fighters who had held their town for months, playing the music that had been forbidden under the militants’ harsh interpretation of Islamic rule and dancing in the streets.

headline: From Welfare Queens to Disabled Deadbeats
abstract: The right loses its resonance.
lead_paragraph: If you want to understand the trouble Republicans are in, one good place to start is with the obsession the right has lately developed with the rising disability rolls. The growing number of Americans receiving disability payments has, for many on the right, become a symbol of our economic and moral decay; we’re becoming a nation of malingerers.

headline: An Ecolabel for McDonald’s Fish Fare
keywords: ['ACCREDITATION', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Fish Farming', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Pollock (Fish)']
abstract: The company’s offerings have been certified by the Marine Stewardship Council as responsibly harvested.
lead_paragraph: McDonald’s has signed on with the Marine Stewardship Council to show that the fish it serves is caught in an environmentally responsible manner. While the fish is not changing, the deal will make the council’s distinctive blue logo familiar to tens of millions of Americans for the first time.

headline: Fire at a Nightclub in Southern Brazil
abstract: Scenes from an intense fire that ripped through a nightclub crowded with university students in southern Brazil early on Sunday morning.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Monday, 3:36 p.m. An intense fire ripped through a nightclub crowded with university students in southern Brazil early on Sunday morning, leaving behind a scene of horror, with bodies piled in the club’s bathrooms and on the street. At least 233 people were killed, many of them students in the agronomy and veterinary medicine programs at a local university, police officials said. By Sunday evening, the authorities had released a preliminary list of the dead.

headline: At Last, a New Lincoln Square Synagogue
abstract: A journey of just a couple of hundred feet took many more years than expected for a Jewish congregation on the West Side.
lead_paragraph: The Torah scrolls had only 250 feet to travel from the old Lincoln Square Synagogue to the new Lincoln Square Synagogue.

headline: Disruptions: A Fuzzy and Shifting Line Between Hacker and Criminal
abstract: To many people who understand computers and the law, there is a danger in lumping people who have not sought financial gain with armed robbers. Where people should receive slaps on the wrist, they face decades in jail.
lead_paragraph: In January 2011, I was assigned to cover a hearing in Newark, where Daniel Spitler, then 26, stood accused of breaching AT&T’s servers and stealing 114,000 e-mail addresses.

headline: Trade Official Says U.S. Wants Deal With Europe
abstract: Ron Kirk, the United States trade representative, says President Obama is committed to an agreement to smooth trade with the European Union, but only if it can overcome objections from farm groups and win Congressional approval.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — America’s top trade negotiator said late on Saturday that President Obama was committed to reaching an agreement to smooth trade with the European Union, but only if it was written in a way that would overcome objections from farm groups and that could win Congressional approval.

headline: ‘Hansel and Gretel: Witch Hunters’ Leads at the Box Office
abstract: The film, starring Jeremy Renner and Gemma Arterton as the title characters, took in an estimated $19 million at North American movie theaters over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Armed with machine guns and other over-the-top weaponry, Hansel and Gretel took in an estimated $19 million at North American movie theaters over the weekend — a total that, while strong enough for No. 1, represented far from a fairy-tale finish. Based on prerelease audience surveys, some analysts had predicted that “Hansel and Gretel: Witch Hunters” (featuring Jeremy Renner and Gemma Arterton as the title characters) could take in as much as $30 million.

headline: De Blasio, Announcing Mayoral Bid, Pledges to Help People City Hall Forgot
abstract: Bill de Blasio, the city’s public advocate, promised to focus on education as well as neighborhood and pocketbook issues that he said had not been addressed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
lead_paragraph: Pledging to “leave no New Yorker behind” by focusing on public education and neighborhood and pocketbook issues, Bill de Blasio, the city’s public advocate, announced on Sunday that he was entering the race to become the city’s next mayor.

headline: Israel Girds for Attacks as Syria Falls Apart
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: At least one Iron Dome missile defense battery was deployed in northern Israel amid reports that Syria’s chemical weapons could possibly fall into Hezbollah’s hands.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — At least one Iron Dome missile defense battery was deployed Sunday in northern Israel amid reports of intense security consultations with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu regarding Syria and the possibility of chemical weapons falling into the hands of Islamist rebels or being transferred to the militant group Hezbollah.

headline: Aging in Brain Found to Hurt Sleep Needed for Memory
abstract: A report in Nature Neuroscience suggests that natural physical changes interfere with quality slumber, blunting the ability to remember new information for the long term.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have known for decades that the ability to remember newly learned information declines with age, but it was not clear why. A new study may provide part of the answer.

headline: Fuse Channel’s Music News Show, ‘Fuse News,’ to Start in February
abstract: “Fuse News,” a daily show reporting on the music world and its personalities, will make its debut on Feb. 6. Fuse will also broadcast a live special at the red carpet of the Grammy Awards on Feb. 10.
lead_paragraph: As the recording industry prepares for next month’s Grammys and all the developments that come with that awards show, Fuse, the music-themed cable channel, will use the days leading up to the ceremony to introduce its own dedicated news program.

headline: Thousands Rally in Paris for Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Law and Legislation', 'Homosexuality', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: About 125,000 people in Paris marched to support a same-sex marriage bill that lawmakers will begin to debate on Tuesday and that stands a good chance of becoming law this year.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Thousands of people marched in Paris on Sunday to show their support for a same-sex marriage bill that lawmakers will begin to debate on Tuesday.

headline: Obama Seeking ‘Political Conquest’ of G.O.P., Ryan Says
abstract: The former vice-presidential candidate said that President Obama was ignoring the nation’s problems, choosing instead to wage a “political conquest” of the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin, the former vice-presidential candidate, said Sunday that President Obama was ignoring the nation’s problems, choosing instead to focus on the “political conquest” of the Republican Party.

headline: In Men’s Final, a Surprising Lack of Return Success
abstract: Novak Djokovic and Andy Murray, who in the 2012 season ranked second and third on the ATP World Tour in terms of percentage of return games won, opened the Australian Open men’s final with 31 consecutive holds of serve.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — In the 2012 season, Novak Djokovic and Andy Murray ranked second and third on the ATP World Tour in terms of percentage of return games won. Djokovic won 35 percent of his return games, while Murray claimed 32 percent (Rafael Nadal led the tour with 38 percent).

headline: At Fed, Nascent Debate on When to Slow Asset Buying
abstract: The Federal Reserve has left little doubt about its immediate plans, but inside the central bank, debate is moving from whether the Fed should do more to boost the economy to when it should start doing less.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve has left little doubt about its plans for the next few months, and thus little mystery about the statement it will release Wednesday after the latest meeting of its policy-making committee. The economy remains weak. The Fed will keep buying bonds to hold down borrowing costs.

headline: No Defect Is Found in Another 787 Battery
abstract: The National Transportation Safety Board said an examination of an undamaged battery with the same design as one that caught fire in a parked plane in Boston found nothing out of the ordinary.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Although a fire destroyed one of two big batteries on a Boeing 787 parked at Logan Airport in Boston three weeks ago, a quick examination of the second battery found “no obvious anomalies,” the National Transportation Safety Board said on Sunday.

headline: Living, and Dying, on His Own Terms
abstract: Clark Lambros, a successful businessman and philanthropist who at 39 found a life partner in a woman a generation his junior,  lived with intention and by his own rules until the end.
lead_paragraph: Clark Lambros knew how to live, and he knew how to die.

headline: The Embers of a Fading Coal Town
abstract: “News From Heaven” is Jennifer Haigh’s collection of stories about the lives and secrets of people in Bakerton, Pa.
lead_paragraph: The essential reference for Jennifer Haigh’s new book of short stories, “News From Heaven,” is her 2005 novel, “Baker Towers.” Both books are about the life and times of Bakerton, Pa., a coal-mining company town that went from booming prosperity to sharp decline.

headline: Solace in a Sea of Insanity
abstract: Based on a true story, “Airswimming” chronicles the lives to two women institutionalized for giving birth out of wedlock in 1920s England.
lead_paragraph: Clearly they have movie nights at St. Dymphna Hospital for the Criminally Insane.

headline: Contemporary Composers Bring Britain Into the Musical Spotlight
abstract: The New Juilliard Ensemble focuses on contemporary British composers in the school’s Focus! 2013 Festival of free concerts this week.
lead_paragraph: The often-heard put-down of Britain as “the land without music,” mostly voiced by smug Germans of earlier times, is a bit unfair. Britain had a minisurge of major composers during the 15th and 16th centuries, Dunstable and Dowland among them. Had Purcell not died at 36, he might have changed the face of music history. By the late 19th century, performing institutions in Britain were prospering, and significant composers like Elgar and Vaughan Williams had emerged.

headline: You Can Choose Your Friends, and Maybe Your Family, Too
abstract: In “The Truth Quotient” a billionaire hires a company to create pleasant doppelgänger robots of dead relatives with whom he had not always had good relations.
lead_paragraph: Don’t you just hate it when the robot that replaced your mother hasn’t read Schopenhauer? Time to upload a new app.

headline: Still on Strike, a Bus Union Sees a Threat to Its Culture
abstract: Decades of job protections are threatened as New York City moves to end some seniority-based job guarantees, which has led to a strike.
lead_paragraph: Each August, just before the start of school, more than 1,000 drivers for the Atlantic Express school bus company gather in a lot in the shadow of Citi Field in Flushing, Queens. For the drivers, it is the event of the year, one repeated at lots all over the city, and is known simply as “the pick.”

headline: Cambridge, Cabs and Copenhagen: My Route to Existential Risk
keywords: ['Artificial Intelligence', 'Biotechnology', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Philosophy', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: The fear that technology might threaten our survival is is often dismissed as outlandish. But it is cause for concern.
lead_paragraph: In Copenhagen the summer before last, I shared a taxi with a man who thought his chance of dying in an artificial intelligence-related accident was as high as that of heart disease or cancer. No surprise if he’d been the driver, perhaps (never tell a taxi driver that you’re a philosopher!), but this was a man who has spent his career with computers.

headline: The Harbaugh Who Did Not Last in Baltimore
abstract: Jim Harbaugh’s quarterbacking stint in Baltimore, brief and unproductive, was the opposite of his older brother John’s experience while coaching the Ravens to three A.F.C. title games in five years.
lead_paragraph: Until Joe Flacco came along in 2008, being the starting quarterback of the Baltimore Ravens featured all the job security of a department store Santa. Preceding him were the likes of Scott Mitchell, Jeff Blake and Steve McNair. And Elvis Grbac, Anthony Wright and Stoney Case.

headline: Australian Open Notebook: Top Seeds Rule Play
abstract: Seven closing notebook items from the first Grand Slam event of the 2013 season, which ran both hot and cold — though thankfully rarely wet.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Here are seven closing notebook items from the first Grand Slam event of the 2013 season, which ran both hot and cold — though thankfully rarely wet.

headline: District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y.
abstract: Alison Wilson, Chris Willenken, Bjorn Fallenius and Andrew Rosenthal of New York City won the Open Swiss Teams on Jan. 17 at the District 3 Winter Regional.
lead_paragraph: Alison Wilson, Chris Willenken, Bjorn Fallenius and Andrew Rosenthal of New York City won the Open Swiss Teams on Jan. 17 at the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y.

headline: SiriusXM to Introduce Alternative Morning Program
abstract: A homegrown talent, the comedian Pete Dominick, will move his radio show to a different channel to explore topics like religion, race and education policy.
lead_paragraph: In a quest to lure subscribers from free terrestrial radio, the pay satellite service SiriusXM is betting that some morning drive listeners want something other than straight news, partisan talk or local fluff, and it is backing a homegrown talent to develop the format.

headline: Models in Killer Shoes Totter Along a Runway to Death
abstract: “The House of Von Macramé” is a microbudget slasher movie spoof set in the backbiting world of fashion.
lead_paragraph: It’s probably not a good thing when the shoes almost steal the show. Then again, the spectacular array of high heels worn in “The House of Von Macramé,” a microbudget slasher movie spoof set in the backbiting world of fashion, could probably transfix the attention even in the middle of a first-rate Shakespeare production, though it would be hard to fathom what they were doing there.

headline: Macdougal Street Homesick Blues
abstract: Joel Coen sheds some light on “Inside Llewyn Davis,” the Coen brothers’ forthcoming film about a musician trying to make it in the 1960s Greenwich Village folk music scene.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — What if a folk singer got beat up outside a Greenwich Village nightclub in 1961?

headline: Common Put-Down
abstract: In which Jaime Hutchison and Victor Fleming insult us.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Yes, I know. You’re wondering how the put-down “WHAT A TOOL” got into a New York Times crossword puzzle. And you’re wondering how I can write about a theme that involves what I will call a fairly colorful phrase and maintain my journalistic obligation to write in a sophisticated and professional manner, especially when Phil the Standards Guy is looking.

headline: Newspapers Vie for Reality Show
abstract: NBC said more than 150 have responded to a casting call.
lead_paragraph: Who knew that ink-stained newsmen and newswomen would be so eager to break into show business?

headline: Flowers From the Cotton Fields
abstract: The world premiere of Robert Wilson’s opera “Zinnias: The Life of Clementine Hunter” is presented at Montclair State University in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The most startling moment in “Zinnias: The Life of Clementine Hunter,” a genial new opera conceived, directed and designed by Robert Wilson, comes near the beginning.

headline: Across the Generations, Advice on the Proper Shave
abstract: Barbasol shaving cream is beginning a cheeky campaign in which an Oregon Trail pioneer, a 1920s baseball player and a World War II soldier speak to today’s men.
lead_paragraph: A BRAND born in 1919 is joining the parade of products hoping to define what it means to be a man today.

headline: Strategies for Facing a Nashville Paradigm
abstract: New releases from Gary Allan and Randy Houser show how smooth exteriors can put complex interiors at risk.
lead_paragraph: Men have been having a tough time in Nashville for nearly a decade now, since Gretchen Wilson staked out “Redneck Woman” territory and took back women’s claim on the genre’s grit. For the last few years especially the masculinity crisis has been flaring up, leading to a spate of singers reduced to lightly felt songs thin on muscle.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
keywords: ['Government Bonds', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'States (US)']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Worthy of a Workout, Melodies From the Days Before Bach and Handel
abstract: Jordi Savall led Juilliard415 in a German-theme concert, “Ludi Musici,” at the Metropolitan Museum.
lead_paragraph: The Juilliard School had a busy night on Friday. While Joel Sachs and the New Juilliard Ensemble were opening Focus! 2013, a contemporary-music festival presenting works from postwar Britain, at Alice Tully Hall, the school’s early-music contingent, Juilliard415, was exploring a terrain more remote in space, time and familiarity in the Vélez Blanco Patio of the Metropolitan Museum.

headline: U.S. Reassures an Impatient Europe on Trade
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The United States trade representative, Ron Kirk, reaffirmed that Washington still wants a deal with Europe to cut tariffs. But objections from farmers and other constituencies need to be addressed first, he said.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — President Barack Obama is committed to reaching an agreement to smooth trade with the European Union, the United States’ top negotiator has said, but only if it is constructed in a way that would overcome objections from farm groups and that could win congressional approval.

headline: Bodies and Voices Riff on ‘Rite of Spring’
abstract: “A Rite” is a collaboration by dancers and actors to celebrate the centenary of Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring,” at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill.
lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — A hundred years on “The Rite of Spring” has become a popular commodity: not just Stravinsky’s score but the whole idea of its neobarbaric modernism and the myths surrounding its scandalous premiere. Like most dance critics, I’m all too used to seeing stagings of “The Rite” that trivialize its complexity: they coast on its music’s force without investigating its ingredients.

headline: Mary Jane Phillips-Matz, Verdi Biographer, Dies at 86
abstract: Ms. Phillips-Matz’s monumental “Verdi: A Biography,” the product of some 30 years’ research, was published in 1993 and spanned 941 pages.
lead_paragraph: Mary Jane Phillips-Matz, a biographer of Verdi and Puccini whose work sought, and by all accounts found, the flesh-and-blood men behind the music, died on Jan. 19 at her home in Manhattan. She was 86.

headline: Make Babies, Urges Saucy Public Radio Campaign
abstract: WBEZ of Chicago is beginning an initiative encouraging procreation to create the next generation of listeners.
lead_paragraph: Mention public radio to a teenager today and you might get an eye roll. Why listen to the radio when you can plug in to all things digital? But if those teenagers were born into a public radio-loving family, they might be persuaded to keep listening, even through their teenage years.

headline: Sharon Brain Scan Shows Response to Stimuli
abstract: The results of a brain scan performed on Ariel Sharon, the former Israeli prime minister who had a stroke seven years ago, raise the chances that he is able to hear and understand.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A brain scan performed on Ariel Sharon, the former Israeli prime minister who had a devastating stroke seven years ago and is presumed to be in a vegetative state, revealed significant brain activity in response to external stimuli, raising the chances that he is able to hear and understand, a scientist involved in the test said Sunday.

headline: Teaching an Old Tongue New Tricks
abstract: Encouraged by what it sees as renewed interest in Yiddish among younger people, The Forward newspaper plans to introduce a rejuvenated and enhanced Yiddish Web site on Feb. 4.
lead_paragraph: The fate of Yiddish is something of a question mark — perhaps fitting for a culture famous for answering questions with questions.

headline: Behind the Sale
abstract: With a third-party guarantee, an outside person promises to buy a work of art for a specific price should it fail to sell for more. While a small percentage of works sell with these types of guarantees, they are often the most expensive.
lead_paragraph: With a third-party guarantee, an outside person promises to buy a work of art for a specific price should it fail to sell for more. While a small percentage of works sell with these types of guarantees, they are often the most expensive.

headline: Before a Departure, a Rare Joint Interview
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidential Election of 2008', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Television']
abstract: President Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton, his departing secretary of state, sat for an interview with CBS News’s “60 Minutes” on Sunday.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Courting Future Cable Subscribers, a Newspaper Reality Show, and a Saucy Ad Campaign
abstract: Two Harvard graduates are trying to reconcile students’ viewing habits with the desire of cable companies and programmers to be paid for wireless content; NBC is looking for newsmen and newswomen to star in a planned reality show; and WBEZ, the Chicago public radio station, is hoping that Chicagoans will help create a new generation of listeners.
lead_paragraph: Tivli, a start-up founded by two Harvard graduates, is trying to reconcile students’ viewing habits, which increasingly involve mobile devices, with the desire of cable companies like Comcast and programmers like HBO to be paid for wireless content. As Brian Stelter reports, resident students at Harvard and, of as of last week, Yale, can use a service created by Tivli to stream local TV stations, a couple of dozen cable channels and the universities’ own in-house channels to computers, tablets or video game consoles. This ability, available anywhere on campus, may be part of the answer to a conundrum for the television industry. Young people watch less TV than they used to, and some say they do not see the point of an expensive cable or satellite subscription. If they become accustomed to viewing programming through services like HBO GO while in college, however, some believe it could lead them to become cable subscribers after they graduate.

As functional as its namesake, the purse features a removable, zip-off envelope pouch that sits atop a large tote without looking bulky. “I wanted to explore the simplicity of an elegant envelope shape,” the creative director Emma Hill says. “The idea of having two bags in one means you have a clutch bag at the ready and then the tote has plenty of space inside.” Hill confesses to hoarding an assortment of things for her son inside hers, but “it’s important that a bag becomes part of you, and not the other way around.” It’s available in three sizes — the smallest is a cross-body style and the biggest is weekend-ready. Hill’s favorite: “The Willow tote in black ostrich feels special, luxurious and a bag to keep for life.”

headline: The SAG Awards Get a Lift
abstract: With so much attention paid to the Golden Globes and the Oscars, the red carpet at the Screen Actors Guild awards always seemed a bit of a drag. But this time the stars were in sync with the recent haute couture shows.
lead_paragraph: With so much attention paid to the Golden Globes and the Oscars, the red carpet at the Screen Actors Guild awards always seemed a bit of a drag. But this time the stars were in sync with the recent haute couture shows. Jennifer Lawrence wore a navy silk taffeta dress from Dior’s spring couture runway. Shown last week in Paris, this dress was a beauty, because of the austere draping and the keyhole back. By adding a train to the original, Ms. Lawrence gave up some modernity, I thought. Perhaps she preferred not to look “straight from the runway.” For the Globes, Anne Hathaway wore Chanel haute couture; on Sunday, she had on a black tulle gown with black beaded underpinnings from Giambattista Valli’s spring couture runway. Ms. Lawrence and Ms. Hathaway are easily the top red-carpet favorites this year.

Though a deep freeze lingered Saturday night, customers eagerly fled the windy 19-degree temperature for the warmth and welcome of the new $3 million Bocuse Restaurant at the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y.

headline: Boy Scouts Join the Present
abstract: The youth organization may lift its ban on gay members.
lead_paragraph: Last July, the Boy Scouts of America were the target of richly deserved outrage when they announced that after two-years of soul searching, they had decided not to change their policy banning gay members and gay Scout leaders. The Supreme Court had said it was their right to do that — but what kind of post-19th century discussion could have led to that nonsensical decision? When President Obama publicly disagreed with the B.S.A.’s decision, the Scouts waved off his objections and said they would not reconsider.

headline: In a Quick Shift, Scouts Rethink a Ban on Gays
abstract: Under a new proposed policy, the Boy Scouts of America would allow local scouting groups to choose whether to allow gay members.
lead_paragraph: The Boy Scouts of America, with its traditions of youth in uniform and the character-building virtues of honor, has always looked back to an older, more structured image of America, when gay and lesbian people were invisible and silent. It was a view reaffirmed in Scout policy as recently as seven months ago. Openly gay scouts and scout leaders need not apply.

headline: U.C.L.A. Receives More Than 90,000 Applications for Fall 2013
abstract: While gathering The Choice blog’s annual application tally for the freshman class of 2013, one thing is clear: The competitive nature of college admissions has yet to reach a tipping point.

headline: An Italian Bank Caught in the Vortex of Election Politics

headline: What to Eat With Slovene White Wines
abstract: A dish with an Eastern European accent.
lead_paragraph: You’re bound to find a cheese — something hard, runny, funky, sharp or mild — to nibble with a Slovene white wine, so you could serve cheese and be done with it. But finding a dish is not a particular challenge, either. Just pick something pleasant and white-wine friendly, because what will be in the glass will be intriguing enough. The Eastern European geography led me to think of stuffed cabbage, but with a light chicken filling and dressed with sour cream. You may have to grind your own chicken; most butchers will not do it, but your food processor will. Freezing the cabbage overnight eliminates the need to boil the leaves to soften them. FLORENCE FABRICANT

headline: In Step With New Orleans’s Comeback

lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Tom Benson took his wife, Gayle, to Commander’s Palace last week, choosing that Garden District restaurant for dinner on the night when his basketball team was rebranded and a few days after his football team was reborn.

headline: Table Talk | Bones in Paris
abstract: A new restaurant by chef James Henry champions quality in-season ingredients, coupled with handmade in-house items such as bread, butter and charcuterie.
lead_paragraph: It was at the helm of the much-acclaimed Au Passage restaurant that James Henry first made ripples in the Paris food scene. His delectable small plates were so well received that he decided to venture on his own. The result is Bones, which Henry unveiled earlier this month. The décor is spare with overhanging industrial light fixtures being the prominent design feature. The interior (an Irish pub in its former life) was deconstructed so that only the raw framework of bricks, wood and tiles remain — hence the skeletal name, Bones.

A latecomer to the party unfolding inside, Stephanie Han-yu, was on the phone and reported that three squad cars were on the street.

headline: Between the Recipes, Scribbles Speak Volumes

Leafing through her mother’s cookbooks, she heard her mother’s Creole-inflected voice in the margins.

headline: Market for Bear Bile Threatens Asian Population
abstract: The extraction of the substance from their gall bladders on makeshift farms causes deep suffering. And some bears’ organs are harvested through poaching.
lead_paragraph: The six bears that arrived this month at Animals Asia, an animal rescue center in China, had the grisly symptoms of inhumane bile milking. Greenish bile dripped from open fistulas used to drain gall bladders; teeth were broken and rotted from gnawing on the bars of tiny cages.

headline: Toasted Chiles Add Complexity to a Dish

lead_paragraph: Making short ribs chili nachos is the subject of this week’s column and video, and I mention that the chili part of the dish was inspired by a recipe I learned from my friend Nick. Nick’s chili is an extremely complexly flavored dish because instead of chile powder, he uses a combination of whole dried chiles.

headline: San Francisco Players Carry On Legacy They Know Little About

lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The San Francisco 49ers last won a Super Bowl on Jan. 29, 1995. Colin Kaepernick, the team’s current starting quarterback, was 7. The team may have five Super Bowl wins, but Joe Looney, San Francisco’s youngest player, was alive for just one of them. The same is true for three other members of the active roster.

headline: Hide and Seek With Deer Mice
abstract: Deer mice make an appealing subject of genetic studies because they are widely prevalent and that they have adapted to their environments in both coat color and behavior in tunnel-making.
lead_paragraph: In the annals of genetics, the deer mouse has so far played only a small role. The major work has been done in nematodes, fruit flies or laboratory mice — a variety of inbred strains coming originally from the house mouse (Mus musculus) — with a few other species, like the three-spined stickleback, finning in the background.

headline: Interpreting Brain Waves
abstract: A new study, suggesting data misinterpration, disputes findings published in 2011 that EEGs had found brain activity similar to that of healthy people in some patients in a vegetative state.
lead_paragraph: In late 2011, Canadian researchers using a novel method of interpreting electroencephalograms asked 16 patients in an irreversible “vegetative” state to move their hands or toes. In three people, the scientists found brain activity similar to that of healthy people given the same instructions. The result suggested that the “vegetative” patients in fact might be hearing and understanding what was said.

headline: Vain Glorious | Get Your Glow On
abstract: T asked five dermatologists to reveal which face products they trust to gently bring healthy radiance out of hibernation.
lead_paragraph: The Northeast is finally emerging from last week’s deep freeze, but the skin-battering effects of frigid temperatures and arctic winds continue to wreak havoc on the face. “It’s been a dry season without much rain or snow, so the air is especially low in humidity. When you combine that with all the time spent indoors, where we’re subject to radiant heaters, it’s causing very dry skin,” explains the Manhattan dermatologist Anne Chapas. While slathering on a rich cream every day might seem like the best fix, hydration is only half the battle. “You really need to exfoliate to remove the dead cells on the surface, which will in turn allow your moisturizer to penetrate better,” Dr. Chapas says. T asked five dermatologists to reveal which face products they trust to gently bring healthy radiance out of hibernation.

headline: In Plain Sight, but Somehow Unseen
abstract: At the Huntington Theater Company in Boston, staging Ralph Ellison’s “Invisible Man,” about a young black man trying to navigate a racist world, proves to be a challenging task.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The ringing speeches and singing sermons never seem to stop in the stage version of “Invisible Man,” Ralph Ellison’s landmark 1952 novel about a young African-American in search of himself, now at the Huntington Theater Company’s Boston University Theater after stints in Chicago and Washington. Although the book’s protagonist does not find his voice as a professional orator until midway through his harrowing journey in a racially divided America, in Oren Jacoby’s faithful but lifeless theatrical adaptation the hero often seems to be presiding at an invisible podium, providing us with crisp talking points about the cruel truths of the black experience.

headline: Precautions Urged for Drivers With Diabetes
abstract: Drivers who have diabetes face the hazard of hypoglycemia, or low blood sugar, which can impair their driving abilities.
lead_paragraph: Dan Fried, a 47-year-old videographer who has Type 1 diabetes, never made it to the diner to meet his brother. As he drove through New Jersey that night in November 2010, he said his blood sugar fell and he became disoriented. He pulled his van to the side of the road, where state troopers, who had received a call about an erratic driver, found him slumped behind the wheel, barely coherent.

headline: The Drug-Dose Gender Gap
abstract: A recent advisory reducing the dosage of sleeping aids for women highlights how men and women often respond differently to various medicines.
lead_paragraph: Most sleeping pills are designed to knock you out for eight hours. When the Food and Drug Administration was evaluating a new short-acting pill for people to take when they wake up in the middle of the night, agency scientists wanted to know how much of the drug would still be in users’ systems come morning.

headline: Shaken but Determined, the Bolshoi Dances On
abstract: The Bolshoi Ballet carries on even as a scandal swirls around it following an acid-throwing attack on its artistic director, possibly ordered by a rival.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — At 7 p.m. on Sunday, the vast and intricate machine that is the Bolshoi Ballet swung into motion here. A fan switched on, sending the sacred flame that is the centerpiece of Act I flickering upward; the ropy vines of a primeval forest were pulled down taut with weights. Dancers peeled off layers of wool and took their positions with fixed professional smiles, rib cages pumping the air, as if everything were normal.

headline: Changes at the Top, but the Dancers Endure
abstract: In a transitional time for the Miami City Ballet, with the departure of the artistic director Edward Villella, the performers look fine in works by Balanchine and Liam Scarlett.

Its repertory for the 2012-13 season was chosen by its departed artistic director, Edward Villella, but the company is led by his successor, Lourdes Lopez. While it’s too early to tell how the change in leadership will affect the company’s style, a recent visit showed the dancers in fine fettle.

headline: Chile: Former Leaders of German Sect Sentenced
abstract: The Supreme Court announced Monday that six former leaders of Colonia Dignidad, a German sect in southern Chile, had been sentenced to 5 to 11 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court announced Monday that six former leaders of Colonia Dignidad, a German sect in southern Chile, had been sentenced to 5 to 11 years in prison for acting as accomplices to the sect’s leader, Paul Schäfer, in the sexual abuse of minors in the 1990s. Ten other defendants received suspended sentences. One of the six, Dr. Harmut Hopp, fled to Germany in 2011, and the German government has denied Chile’s requests for his extradition. Mr. Schäfer founded the self-sufficient religious sect in 1961 after fleeing West Germany, where he was accused of sexually abusing boys. He died in prison in 2010 while serving a 20-year sentence for the sexual abuse of 25 minors at the sect’s compound. Colonia Dignidad also served as a clandestine torture center during the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, according to official human rights reports.

headline: Venezuela: Official Death Toll in Prison Clash Is 58
abstract: The minister of prisons, Iris Varela, said Monday that a prison clash that broke out Friday between inmates and National Guard soldiers had killed 58 people and injured 95.
lead_paragraph: The minister of prisons, Iris Varela, said Monday that a prison clash that broke out Friday between inmates and National Guard soldiers had killed 58 people and injured 95. The director of a hospital where the bodies were taken had previously said that 61 people had been killed and 120 injured. Most of the dead were inmates. On Sunday, officials said that they had moved more than 2,000 prisoners from the prison in Barquisimeto, a northwestern city, and sent them to other prisons around the country. The mayhem occurred after troops were sent to search the notoriously violent prison for weapons and establish order. Government opponents have criticized the handling of the episode and say that moving prisoners to other overcrowded facilities will make conditions at those prisons worse.
